questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Left horn of sinus venosus gives rise to
questions.ref_book: During heart development, the left horn of the sinus venosus becomes greatly reduced and forms two key venous structures: the coronary sinus, which drains most of the blood from the heart wall into the right atrium, and the oblique vein of the left atrium, a small vein that joins the coronary sinus.(Human Embryology by Inderbir Singh 13th Edition, Page No - 247)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Cricothyroid muscle develops from
questions.ref_book:
Fourth Pharyngeal Arch Derivatives
Skeletal-lamina of thyroid cartilage.
Muscle-cricothyroid muscle.
Nerve-superior laryngeal nerve.
Artery-right subclavian artery, and left side part of
arch of aorta.(Human Embryology by Inderbir Singh 13th Edition, Page No - 351)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: All are cells of the epidermis except
questions.ref_book: The epidermis contains four main cell types: keratinocytes, melanocytes, Langerhans cells, and Merkel cells. These are involved in protection, pigmentation, immune defense, and sensory function. Monocytes, on the other hand, are white blood cells found in blood and connective tissue-not in the epidermis-making them the correct exception(Human Embryology by Inderbir Singh 13th Edition, Page No - 133)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: The parotid gland develops from
questions.ref_book: The parotid gland, the largest salivary gland, arises from ectoderm near the angle of the primitive mouth. This is in contrast to submandibular and sublingual glands, which are endodermal in origin. Thus, its origin is ectodermal, not endodermal or mesodermal(Human Embryology by Inderbir Singh 13th Edition, Page No - 182)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Failure of fusion of the lateral nasal process with the maxillary processes results in
questions.ref_book: During embryological development of the face, the lateral nasal process should fuse with the maxillary process. If this fusion fails, it leads to an oblique facial cleft, which runs from the upper lip toward the eye. This is distinct from hare lip (cleft lip) or cleft palate, which result from failure of fusion in other facial prominences(Human Embryology by Inderbir Singh 13th Edition, Page No - 169)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: The auricle develops from
questions.ref_book: The auricle (pinna) of the external ear develops from six hillocks, known as the hillocks of His, located on the first and second pharyngeal arches. These hillocks gradually fuse and remodel to form the external ear. The first branchial cleft contributes to the external auditory canal, not the auricle(Human Embryology by Inderbir Singh 13th Edition, Page No - 147)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: What is the embryological source of the nasolacrimal duct?
questions.ref_book: The nasolacrimal duct originates from a solid cord of ectodermal cells that forms in the groove between the lateral nasal process and maxillary process (the naso-optic groove). This epithelial cord later canalizes to form the nasolacrimal duct and sac. Therefore, its embryological origin is ectodermal(Human Embryology by Inderbir Singh 13th Edition, Page No - 167)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: What is the result of failure of obliteration of the cervical sinus?
questions.ref_book: The cervical sinus is a temporary cavity formed during the development of the branchial apparatus. It normally disappears as the neck develops. If it fails to obliterate, it results in a branchial cyst, often presenting as a painless swelling in the lateral neck in young adultsThe cervical sinus is a temporary cavity formed during the development of the branchial apparatus. It normally disappears as the neck develops. If it fails to obliterate, it results in a branchial cyst, often presenting as a painless swelling in the lateral neck in young adults(Human Embryology by Inderbir Singh 13th Edition, Page No - 147)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Rathke's pouch gives rise to the development of
questions.ref_book: Rathke's pouch is an ectodermal diverticulum from the roof of the embryonic mouth (stomodeum). It gives rise to the anterior pituitary (adenohypophysis). In contrast, the posterior pituitary develops from a downward extension of the neuroectoderm from the diencephalon. Rathke's pouch has no connection to the thalamus or hypothalamus(Human Embryology by Inderbir Singh 13th Edition, Page No - 329)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: The wall of the fossa ovalis in an adult atrium represents the
questions.ref_book: In fetal life, septum primum forms the initial partition between the atria. After birth, the foramen ovale closes as the septum primum fuses with the septum secundum. The fossa ovalis, seen in the right atrium, is the remnant of this closure and is formed by the septum primum(Human Embryology by Inderbir Singh 13th Edition, Page No - 248)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Embryologically, the tympanic membrane is derived from
questions.ref_book: The tympanic membrane (eardrum) has a trilaminar embryological origin, meaning it develops from all three germ layers. The ectoderm from the first branchial cleft forms the outer layer, the endoderm from the first pharyngeal pouch forms the inner layer, and mesoderm between them contributes connective tissue. This unique origin allows the membrane to serve as a boundary between the external ear and middle ear, transmitting sound vibrations efficiently(Human Embryology by Inderbir Singh 13th Edition, Page No - 343)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Which layer of deep cervical fascia gives rise to axillary sheath?
questions.ref_book:
The prevertebral layer of the deep cervical fascia extends laterally over scalene muscles and forms the axillary sheath, enclosing the brachial plexus and subclavian artery as they pass toward the upper limb.
(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 74)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Axillary sheath is derived from
questions.option_b: Prevertebral layer of deep cervical fascia
questions.option_c: Investing layer of deep cervical fascia
questions.ref_book: The axillary sheath is formed as a lateral extension of the prevertebral layer of the deep cervical fascia. It encloses the brachial plexus and the axillary artery as they pass from the neck into the axilla between the scalene muscles.(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 74)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: The muscle inserted into the anterior margin of the coronoid process of the ramus of the mandible is
questions.ref_book: The temporalis muscle, a fan-shaped muscle of mastication, inserts on the medial surface, apex, and anterior border of the coronoid process of the mandible, extending onto the anterior border of the ramus. This powerful muscle is responsible for elevating and retracting the mandible during chewing(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 147)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: The narrowest space of the laryngeal cavity, separating the vocal folds and vocal processes is
questions.ref_book: The rima glottidis is the narrowest part of the larynx, bounded by the vocal folds and vocal processes. It plays a critical role in voice production, respiration, and protection of the lower airway. Its shape changes with different vocal cord positions like breathing, phonation, and whispering(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 220)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Spinal nucleus of trigeminal nerve receives the following sensations from trigeminal areas.
questions.ref_book: The spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve processes pain and temperature sensations from the face, scalp, oral and nasal cavities. It is part of the trigeminal sensory pathway that includes main sensory (touch) and mesencephalic (proprioception) nuclei(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 329)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Depression of the mandible is produced by contraction of
questions.ref_book: While temporalis, masseter, and medial pterygoid all contribute to elevation (closing) of the mandible, it is the lateral pterygoid that actively depresses (opens) the mandible by pulling the condylar process forward, enabling mouth opening(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 133)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Anterior ethmoidal nerve is a
questions.ref_book: The anterior ethmoidal nerve is a sensory continuation of the nasociliary nerve, itself a branch of the ophthalmic division (V1) of the trigeminal nerve. It passes through the anterior ethmoidal foramen to supply parts of the nasal cavity and external nose(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 248)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Scalenus medius is pierced by
questions.ref_book:
Dorsal scapular nerve arises from C5 root. It pierces the
scalenus medius and runs laterally across it to pass deep
to levator scapulae, which it supplies

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Lingual artery is divided into three parts by
questions.ref_book: The lingual artery, a branch of the external carotid, is surgically and anatomically divided into three parts relative to the hyoglossus muscle(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 232)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Nerve passing between the superior and the middle constrictor is
questions.ref_book: The glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) exits the skull via the jugular foramen and passes between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictors along with the stylopharyngeus muscle. This anatomical relationship is important for locating the nerve during surgery or understanding referred pain from the pharynx(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 201)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Stylohyoid ligament is derived from
questions.ref_book: The stylohyoid ligament is one of the components of the styloid apparatus, extending from the styloid process to the lesser cornu of the hyoid bone. It develops from Reichert's cartilage, which is the cartilaginous component of the second pharyngeal arch(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 147)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: The shape of the lens of the eye is altered by the action of
questions.ref_book: The ciliaris muscle, part of the ciliary body, alters the shape of the lens by modifying the tension on the suspensory ligaments (zonule of Zinn). When this muscle contracts, it reduces the tension, allowing the lens to become more convex (spherical), which is essential for focusing on near objects - a process known as accommodation. This role is distinct from pupillary muscles, which regulate the size of the pupil, and extraocular muscles like the superior oblique, which move the eyeball but don't affect the lens shape

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Torticollis is caused by
questions.ref_book: Torticollis (wry neck) is caused by involuntary contraction or spasm of the sternocleidomastoid muscle, leading to the head tilting toward the affected side and the chin rotating to the opposite side. The most common cause is spasmodic torticollis(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 80)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: The Passavant's ridge is formed by
questions.ref_book: The Passavant's ridge is a mucosal ridge that forms transiently on the posterior pharyngeal wall during swallowing. It is produced by the horizontal fibers of the palatopharyngeus muscle, which loop with the superior constrictor muscle. This muscular U-shaped loop acts like a sphincter, sealing the nasopharyngeal isthmus to prevent food from regurgitating into the nasal cavity during swallowing(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 195)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: The skin over the angle of the mandible is supplied by
questions.ref_book: The skin over the angle of the mandible lies in a transitional zone between facial and cervical territories. While most of the face is innervated by branches of the trigeminal nerve, the angle of the mandible is an exception-it is supplied by the great auricular nerve, a branch of the cervical plexus (C2, C3). This unique overlap explains the exception in sensory innervation and is important in surgical and clinical evaluations involving parotid and mandibular areas(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 60)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: The postural drainage of the maxillary sinus is best when
questions.ref_book: The maxillary sinus opens into the middle meatus near its roof, making drainage difficult when upright. For optimal postural drainage, the patient is positioned lying on the side opposite (unaffected side) of the diseased sinus(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 420)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: The supra-meatal triangle corresponds to
questions.ref_book: The suprameatal triangle, also called McEwen's triangle, is a surface landmark located just posterosuperior to the external acoustic meatus(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 266)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: How can the mastoid antrum, which lies deep to the suprameatal triangle, be approached?
questions.ref_book: The mastoid antrum lies deep to the suprameatal triangle, which is a bony surface landmark just above and behind the external auditory meatus. This triangle is surgically accessed via the cymba conchae, a depression in the pinna of the ear, making it a key approach point for mastoidectomy procedures. Accurate identification of this surface landmark avoids injury to nearby structures like the facial nerve or sigmoid sinus(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 258)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: What is the action of the genioglossus?
questions.option_c: Draws the tongue backwards and upwards
questions.option_d: Makes the tongue flat and wide
questions.ref_book: The genioglossus is the largest and most powerful extrinsic muscle of the tongue, originating from the superior mental spine of the mandible. Its primary action is to protrude the tongue by pulling it forward, which is essential for speech, swallowing, and preventing tongue fall in unconscious patients(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 123)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Which nerve runs with the posterior auricular artery to supply the scalp behind the ear?
questions.ref_book: The posterior auricular nerve, a branch of the facial nerve (CN VII), runs along with the posterior auricular artery (a branch of the external carotid artery) to supply the scalp behind the auricle (ear)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: In the dangerous zone of the face, which vein connects the facial vein to the cavernous sinus?
questions.ref_book:
In the cheek, the facial vein is joined to the pterygoid
venous plexus by the deep facial vein. The deep facial
vein passes backwards over the buccinator deep to the
ramus of the mandible and communicates with the
pterygoid venous plexus around the lateral pterygoid
muscle, which in turn communicates with the cavernous
sinus through an emissary vein(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 61)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: The common carotid artery pulsation can be compressed against the prominent transverse process of
questions.ref_book: The common carotid artery can be palpated in the neck by pressing it against the anterior tubercle of the transverse process of the 6th cervical vertebra, also known as the carotid tubercle or Chassaignac's tubercle. This landmark lies approximately 4 cm above the sternoclavicular joint, near the cricoid cartilage. It is the most reliable site for checking the carotid pulse due to its superficial position and stability. This is a critical surface landmark used in clinical examinations and emergency medicine(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 91)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: The safety muscle of the tongue is
questions.ref_book: The genioglossus is the most important extrinsic tongue muscle responsible for protruding the tongue forward. It is aptly named the "safety muscle of the tongue" because it prevents the tongue from falling back into the oropharynx, which could lead to airway obstruction, especially in unconscious or anesthetized patients. This vital role in maintaining airway patency is why it is tested clinically during hypoglossal nerve evaluation(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 187)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Which is not related to the temporomandibular joint laterally?
questions.ref_book:
Lateral Relations:
(a) Skin and fasciae.
(b) Parotid gland.
(c) Temporal branches of the facial nerve.
Medial Relations 
(a) Tympanic plate separating it from internal carotid
artery.
(b) Spine of sphenoid.
(c) Auriculotemporal nerve.
(d) Middle meningeal artery.
(e) Sphenomandibular ligament
(f) Chorda tympani nerve(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 144)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Horner's Syndrome is characterized by all except
questions.ref_book: Horner's syndrome results from disruption of sympathetic innervation to the head and neck, often due to lesions affecting the cervical sympathetic trunk. The classical triad includes ptosis (due to paralysis of M?ller's muscle), miosis (due to unopposed sphincter pupillae), and anhidrosis (lack of sweating due to sudomotor denervation). Enophthalmos (sunken eyeball) may also be observed. However, exophthalmos (protrusion of the eyeball) is not a feature of Horner's syndrome; it occurs in conditions like thyrotoxicosis(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 171)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Structures related to the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus are all except
questions.ref_book: The cavernous sinus contains multiple cranial nerves. The oculomotor (III), trochlear (IV), ophthalmic (V1), and maxillary (V2) nerves run in the lateral wall of the sinus. However, the abducent nerve (VI) passes through the body of the sinus alongside the internal carotid artery, not in the lateral wall. This anatomical separation makes the 6th cranial nerve more vulnerable to injury in cavernous sinus pathology such as thrombosis or aneurysm(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 316)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Which artery is not involved in the formation of Kiesselbach's plexus in the nasal septum?
questions.ref_book:
Kiesselbach's plexus is a richly vascularized area in the anteroinferior part of the nasal septum known as Little's area, and is a common site for epistaxis (nosebleeds). It is formed by the anastomosis of four arteries:

Anterior ethmoidal artery (from ophthalmic artery)

Sphenopalatine artery (from maxillary artery)

Greater palatine artery (from maxillary artery)

Superior labial artery (from facial artery)

The posterior ethmoidal artery, although it supplies the nasal septum, does not participate in the formation of Kiesselbach's plexus(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 248)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Name the unsupported pharyngeal mucosa that lies between thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus
questions.ref_book: Killian's dehiscence is an anatomical weak area located between the thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus parts of the inferior constrictor muscle of the pharynx. This region lacks muscular support and is therefore prone to herniation of the mucosa, resulting in a pharyngeal pouch or Zenker's diverticulum. This pouch can cause symptoms such as dysphagia, regurgitation, and aspiration(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 199)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: The muscle which opens the inlet of the larynx is
questions.ref_book: The thyroepiglotticus muscle is a continuation of some fibers of the thyroarytenoid muscle that curve upward within the aryepiglottic fold to reach the epiglottis. It functions to pull the epiglottis forward, thus opening the laryngeal inlet, which facilitates breathing and voice production. In contrast, muscles like the oblique arytenoid and aryepiglotticus act to close the inlet during swallowing(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 217)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Which paranasal air sinus does not open into the middle meatus?
questions.ref_book: The middle meatus of the nasal cavity serves as the drainage area for most paranasal sinuses including the frontal, anterior ethmoidal, middle ethmoidal, and maxillary sinuses. However, the sphenoidal sinus opens into the sphenoethmoidal recess, which is located above and behind the superior nasal concha, not into the middle meatus.(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 255)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Which is a branch of the maxillary nerve?
questions.ref_book: The maxillary nerve (V2) is the second division of the trigeminal nerve and is purely sensory. One of its most prominent branches is the infraorbital nerve, which continues through the infraorbital canal and emerges onto the face. In contrast, the supraorbital, nasociliary, and lacrimal nerves are branches of the ophthalmic division (V1)(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 329)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: The dural venous sinus which is enclosed in the falx cerebelli is
questions.ref_book: The falx cerebelli is a small vertical dural fold situated between the two cerebellar hemispheres in the posterior cranial fossa. The occipital sinus runs within its attached margin and is the only dural venous sinus associated with the falx cerebelli(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 313)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Surgical layers of the scalp exclude
questions.ref_book: The scalp consists of five layers: 1) Skin, 2) Connective tissue (dense), 3) Aponeurotic layer, 4) Loose areolar tissue, and 5) Pericranium. The first three layers are tightly bound together and form what is clinically known as the "surgical layers" or "scalp proper". These layers move as a single unit and are surgically significant because they are lifted together in scalp flaps. The loose areolar layer, although part of the scalp anatomy, is not considered a surgical layer, as it forms a plane of separation beneath the scalp proper(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 49)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: The duct of the parotid gland opens into
questions.ref_book: The parotid duct (Stensen's duct) is a 5 cm long excretory duct of the parotid salivary gland. It follows a characteristic course, passing over the masseter muscle, then turning medially to pierce the buccinator muscle. Finally, it opens into the oral vestibule through a small papilla located opposite the crown of the upper second molar tooth. This specific location is an important clinical landmark for examining salivary duct infections and blockages. Hence, the correct answer is opposite the upper 2nd molar tooth(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 114)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: All of the following are components of the uveal tract EXCEPT
questions.ref_book: The uveal tract is the vascular middle coat of the eyeball and includes three key components: the choroid, ciliary body, and iris. These structures play vital roles in nourishing the eye, controlling the shape of the lens, and regulating the amount of light that enters through the pupil. The cornea, on the other hand, is part of the outer fibrous coat of the eyeball along with the sclera and is avascular. Thus, it is not part of the uveal tract, making it the correct answer(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 285)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: The structure which separates the middle ear from the middle cranial fossa is
questions.ref_book: The middle ear is a six-walled box-like cavity located within the petrous part of the temporal bone. Its roof is called the tegmen tympani, which is a thin bony plate that serves as a barrier between the middle ear and the middle cranial fossa of the brain. This anatomical relationship is clinically significant because infections of the middle ear (otitis media) can spread to the cranial cavity, causing complications like meningitis(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 263)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Which is the main lymph node group draining the tonsil?
questions.ref_book: The palatine tonsil, located in the tonsillar fossa of the oropharynx, drains its lymph into the upper deep cervical lymph nodes, especially the jugulodigastric node. This node lies just below the angle of the mandible and is often referred to as the tonsillar lymph node because it enlarges prominently in tonsillitis(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 205)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Orbicularis oculi is supplied by
questions.ref_book: The orbicularis oculi, responsible for closing the eyelids, is a muscle of facial expression and is therefore innervated by the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII). Specifically, its upper part is supplied by the temporal branch, and the lower part by the zygomatic branch of the facial nerve. This is why patients with Bell's palsy, a condition affecting the facial nerve, cannot close their eyes properly. The ophthalmic, maxillary, and mandibular nerves are divisions of the trigeminal nerve, which is mainly sensory, not motor to facial muscles. Hence, the correct answer is facial nerve(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 58)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: The pain from the tongue is referred to the ear through
questions.ref_book: Referred pain from the tongue to the ear is primarily due to the lingual nerve, a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (V3). When pathology like cancer or inflammation affects the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, pain may be perceived in areas supplied by other branches of the mandibular nerve, such as the auriculotemporal nerve, which supplies the external ear and temporal region. This is a classic example of referred pain within the same nerve distribution.(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 190)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: The pigmented vascular coat of the eyeball consists of all of the following structures EXCEPT
questions.ref_book: The uveal tract, also called the vascular coat of the eyeball, includes three pigmented and vascular components: the choroid, ciliary body, and iris. These structures are crucial for nourishing the eye and adjusting the lens and pupil. The ora serrata, however, is the anterior edge of the retina, which marks the transition from the light-sensitive to the non-sensitive part of the retina. It does not form part of the uveal tract. Therefore, among the options listed, ora serrata is the correct exception(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 284)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: The space between the right and left vocal fold is called
questions.ref_book: The rima glottidis is the narrow slit-like space between the right and left vocal folds (true vocal cords) and represents the narrowest part of the laryngeal cavity. It plays a key role in voice production and respiration, as its shape changes during breathing, speaking, and whispering(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 226)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: The organ of Corti is located within
questions.ref_book: The organ of Corti, also known as the spiral organ, is the primary sensory structure for hearing. It is located inside the cochlear duct (scala media) of the inner ear, resting on the basilar membrane. This structure contains specialized hair cells that transduce mechanical vibrations caused by sound into nerve impulses. These impulses are then carried by the cochlear nerve to the brain(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 267)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: The common carotid artery usually bifurcates at the level of
questions.ref_book: The common carotid artery bifurcates into the internal and external carotid arteries at the level of the upper border of the thyroid cartilage, corresponding to the C3-C4 intervertebral disc. This anatomical landmark is essential in head and neck surgery and for locating the carotid pulse clinically(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 230)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: The artery of epistaxis is
questions.ref_book: The sphenopalatine artery, a terminal branch of the maxillary artery, is the chief artery involved in epistaxis (nosebleeds), especially in posterior bleeds. In the anterior part of the nasal septum, its septal branches contribute to Kiesselbach's plexus(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 248)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Cells present in thyroid gland includes
questions.ref_book: Inderbir Singh's Human Histology, 8 th Edition (2016), Page No : 376

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Mossy fibres are seen in
questions.ref_book: Inderbir Singh's Human Histology, 8 th Edition (2016), Page No : 186

questions.que: Lining Epithelium of Lung Alveolus is
questions.ref_book: Inderbir Singh's Human Histology, 8 th Edition (2016), Page No : 40

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: What is the lining epithelium of the anterior surface of the epiglottis?
questions.ref_book: The anterior (lingual) surface is exposed to friction from food and is lined by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium(Human Histology  by Inderbir Singh 10th Edition, Page No - 157)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: The cell type lining the central canal of the spinal cord and the ventricular system of the brain
questions.ref_book: Ependymal cells are specialized glial cells that form the ependyma, a thin epithelial membrane lining the ventricular system of the brain and the central canal of the spinal cord. They help in the circulation and regulation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).(Human Histology  by Inderbir Singh 10th Edition, Page No - 105)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: One of the following statements is incorrect about Hassall's corpuscle.
questions.option_a: Present in the medulla of thymus
questions.option_c: Formed by concentric layers of macrophages and T-lymphocytes
questions.ref_book: Hassall's corpuscles are characteristic structures found in the medulla of the thymus. They are round and acidophilic, composed of concentric layers of epithelial reticular cells, not macrophages or T-lymphocytes. They tend to increase in number with age. Therefore, the statement about their formation from macrophages and T-lymphocytes is incorrect(Human Histology  by Inderbir Singh 10th Edition, Page No - 96)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: All of the following are the components of gray matter except
questions.ref_book: Gray matter in the CNS contains neuronal cell bodies, dendrites, unmyelinated axons, and neuroglia, responsible for synaptic processing. In contrast, myelinated nerve fibers are mainly found in the white matter, where they facilitate rapid signal conduction. Hence, myelinated fibers are not a component of gray matter(Human Histology  by Inderbir Singh 10th Edition, Page No - 105)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Function of dust cell is
questions.ref_book: Dust cells, also known as alveolar macrophages, are free-floating immune cells within the alveoli. Their primary function is phagocytosis-they ingest and remove inhaled particles like dust and pathogens, helping to keep the alveolar space sterile. They are not involved in gas exchange or surfactant secretion

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Surfactant is secreted by
questions.ref_book: Type II pneumocytes are cuboidal epithelial cells found in the alveoli of the lungs. They synthesize and secrete surfactant, a substance crucial for reducing surface tension in the alveoli, preventing collapse during expiration(Human Histology  by Inderbir Singh 10th Edition, Page No - 164)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Example of an elastic artery is
questions.ref_book: Elastic arteries, such as the aorta, are large arteries close to the heart that help maintain continuous blood flow by stretching and recoiling with each heartbeat. Their tunica media contains abundant elastic fibers, unlike muscular arteries (e.g., femoral or coronary), which primarily distribute blood to specific regions and have more smooth muscle(Human Histology  by Inderbir Singh 10th Edition, Page No - 120)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Lining epithelium of alveoli is
questions.ref_book: The alveoli are the terminal air sacs of the lungs where gas exchange occurs. They are primarily lined by type I pneumocytes, which are simple squamous epithelial cells that form a thin barrier to facilitate efficient diffusion of gases between air and blood(Human Histology  by Inderbir Singh 10th Edition, Page No - 163)

questions.ref_book: Textbook Of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 3rd Edition (Vol 2), Page No : 447

questions.ref_book: Textbook Of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 3rd Edition (Vol 2), Page No : 347

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Which muscle bounds the femoral ring posteriorly?
questions.ref_book: The posterior boundary of the femoral ring is formed by the pecten pubis, which is covered by the pectineus muscle(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-2, Page No  - 328)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: 4th perforating artery is a
questions.option_b: Branch from medial circumflex femoral artery
questions.option_c: Branch from lateral circumflex femoral artery
questions.ref_book: The fourth perforating artery is not a separate branch from the profunda femoris, but rather its terminal part. It pierces the adductor magnus to reach the posterior compartment of the thigh and acts as the final perforating artery(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-2, Page No  - 360)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Which tarsal bone has a tunnel for the passage of the tendon of Peroneus Longus?
questions.ref_book: The cuboid bone on the lateral side of the foot has a groove on its plantar surface called the peroneal sulcus, which forms a tunnel for the passage of the tendon of peroneus longus. This tendon crosses from lateral to medial side of the sole to insert at the base of the 1st metatarsal and medial cuneiform(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-2, Page No  - 390)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Which bursa is affected in Clergyman's knee?
questions.ref_book: The subcutaneous infrapatellar bursa is situated between the skin and the tibial tuberosity. Its inflammation causes a condition called Clergyman's knee(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-2, Page No  - 431)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: What is the root value of the sciatic nerve?
questions.option_a: Ventral rami of L4 to S3
questions.option_b: Dorsal rami of L4 to S3
questions.option_c: Ventral rami of L2 to S4
questions.option_d: Dorsal rami of L2 to S4
questions.ref_book: The sciatic nerve is the largest nerve in the body, originating from the sacral plexus. It is formed from the ventral (anterior) rami of spinal nerves L4, L5, S1, S2, and S3(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-2, Page No  - 358)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Nerve piercing the femoral sheath is
questions.ref_book: The femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve (L1, L2) pierces the femoral sheath and enters the lateral compartment alongside the femoral artery, supplying the skin over the femoral triangle and upper part of the femoral sheath(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-2, Page No  - 326)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Which nerve supplies most of the skin over the femoral triangle?
questions.ref_book: The intermediate cutaneous nerve of the thigh, a branch of the femoral nerve, supplies the anterior and medial thigh, including the major part of the skin over the femoral triangle(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-2, Page No  - 458)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Which muscle initiates flexion of the knee joint?
questions.ref_book:
Its primary function is to "unlock" the fully extended knee joint by laterally rotating the femur on the tibia when the leg is fixed (or medially rotating the tibia when the femur is fixed).

This action initiates flexion of the knee joint, allowing larger muscles like the hamstrings to continue the movement(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-2, Page No  - 403)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Pes anserinus do not include insertion of
questions.ref_book:
Pes anserinus (Latin for "goose's foot") is a conjoined tendon formed by the insertion of three muscles on the medial surface of the upper tibia:

Sartorius (from anterior compartment)

Gracilis (from medial compartment)

Semitendinosus (from posterior compartment)(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-2, Page No  - 394)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Gemellus inferior is supplied by
questions.ref_book: The inferior gemellus muscle is a small lateral rotator of the hip located below the obturator internus. It shares common embryological and functional features with the quadratus femoris, and both are innervated by the nerve to quadratus femoris (L4, L5, S1).(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-2, Page No  - 348)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Name the ligament attached to the Anterior superior iliac spine
questions.ref_book:
The anterior end of iliac crest presents a bony projection
called anterior superior iliac spine, which provides attachment
to the lateral end of the inguinal ligament(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-2, Page No  - 20)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Which artery runs between anterior and posterior divisions of Femoral nerve?
questions.ref_book:
In the femoral triangle, the femoral nerve divides into anterior and posterior divisions approximately 2 cm below the inguinal ligament. According to Vishram Singh:

"The two divisions straddle the lateral circumflex femoral artery."(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-2, Page No  - 327)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Content of adductor canal is
questions.ref_book:
Contents of the adductor canal include:
Femoral artery

Femoral vein

Saphenous nerve

Nerve to vastus medialis (a branch of femoral nerve)(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-2, Page No  - 331)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Avascular necrosis of the head of femur is due to damage to which artery?
questions.ref_book: The medial circumflex femoral artery is the main blood supply to the head and neck of the femur, primarily through its retinacular branches (posterior retinacular arteries). These arteries course along the neck beneath the capsule to reach the femoral head(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-2, Page No  - 374)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Nerve of Adductor compartment of thigh
questions.ref_book: The obturator nerve is the primary motor nerve to the medial (adductor) compartment of the thigh. It arises from the lumbar plexus (L2-L4) and supplies(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-2, Page No  - 453)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Ankle joint is most stable in following position
questions.ref_book:
In the fully dorsiflexed position, the wide anterior part of the talus fits tightly between the malleoli of the tibia and fibula.

This leads to a "wedge effect", where the talocrural joint becomes mechanically locked, making it most stable.(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-2, Page No  - 435)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: All are guy ropes muscles EXCEPT
questions.ref_book:
Guy rope muscles are the three muscles that form the "pes anserinus" and act like guy ropes stabilizing the medial side of the knee joint. These are:

Sartorius

Gracilis

Semitendinosus(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-2, Page No  - 393)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: The expansion of which tendon forms Oblique Popliteal ligament?
questions.ref_book:
The oblique popliteal ligament is a thickening of the posterior capsule of the knee joint.

It is formed by the tendinous expansion of the semimembranosus muscle.(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-2, Page No  - 430)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Principal muscle for Unlocking knee joint
questions.ref_book:
The popliteus muscle is responsible for unlocking the knee joint from its fully extended (locked) position.

It does so by:

Medially rotating the tibia on the femur (in non-weight-bearing limb), or

Laterally rotating the femur on the tibia (in weight-bearing limb)(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-2, Page No  - 432)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Sacrotuberous ligament is a morphological remnant of
questions.ref_book: The sacrotuberous ligament is considered a morphological remnant of the long head of the biceps femoris muscle. During development, this portion of the muscle loses its contractile elements and transforms into a fibrous ligament connecting the sacrum to the ischial tuberosity(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-2, Page No  - 356)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Sensory innervation to the dorsum of the first intermetatarsal space is
questions.ref_book: The deep peroneal nerve (a branch of the common peroneal nerve) supplies a small cutaneous area on the dorsum of the foot-specifically the first interdigital cleft (between the first and second toes).(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-2, Page No  - 378)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Muscle of deep perineal pouch is
questions.ref_book:
The deep perineal pouch (also called the urogenital diaphragm) contains key muscles related to voluntary control of urination:

Muscles of the deep perineal pouch:
Sphincter urethrae (external urethral sphincter)

Deep transverse perineal muscle(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-2, Page No  - 214)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: The tarsal bone which does not have muscular attachment is
questions.ref_book:
The talus is unique among the tarsal bones because it:

Does not give attachment to any muscle.(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-2, Page No  - 310)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Sural nerve is a branch of
questions.ref_book: The sural nerve is primarily a cutaneous branch of the tibial nerve(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-2, Page No  - 397)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: In between which tendons, pulsations of Dorsalis pedis artery can be felt?
questions.option_a: Tibialis Anterior and Extensor Hallucis Longus
questions.option_b: Extensor Hallucis Longus and Extensor Digitorum Longus
questions.option_c: Extensor Digitorum Longus and Peroneus Tertius
questions.option_d: Tibialis Anterior and Extensor Digitorum Longus
questions.ref_book: Its pulsations are best felt just lateral to the tendon of extensor hallucis longus and medial to the tendon of tibialis anterior, as it lies on the navicular and intermediate cuneiform bones(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-2, Page No  - 406)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Trochanteric anastomosis is formed by the union of all the following arteries except
questions.option_a: Descending branch of superior gluteal artery
questions.option_b: Ascending branch of medial circumflex artery
questions.option_d: Transverse branch from lateral circumflex artery
questions.ref_book:
The trochanteric anastomosis is located near the greater trochanter and plays a vital role in supplying the head of the femur via retinacular arteries.

It is formed by:
Descending branch of superior gluteal artery 

Ascending branch of medial circumflex femoral artery 

Branch from inferior gluteal artery 

Sometimes also contribution from ascending branch of lateral circumflex femoral artery

The transverse branch of the lateral circumflex femoral artery is not part of this anastomosis. It instead contributes to the cruciate anastomosis around the hip(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-2, Page No  - 362)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Root value of femoral nerve
questions.option_a: Ventral rami of L1, L2, L3
questions.option_c: Ventral rami of L2, L3, L4
questions.ref_book:
The femoral nerve is the largest branch of the lumbar plexus.

It arises from the posterior divisions of the ventral rami of L2, L3, and L4(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-2, Page No  - 452)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: The third ventricle communicates with the fourth ventricle through
questions.ref_book: The cerebral aqueduct of Sylvius (also called the aqueduct of midbrain) is a narrow channel that connects the third ventricle (located in the diencephalon) to the fourth ventricle (situated between the pons and cerebellum). It allows the flow of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) between these ventricles. This passage is crucial for maintaining proper CSF circulation and pressure in the brain(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 350)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Internal arcuate fibers after decussation ascend to form
questions.ref_book: The internal arcuate fibers originate from the nucleus gracilis and nucleus cuneatus in the medulla after receiving proprioceptive and discriminative touch inputs via the dorsal columns. These fibers decussate (cross over) in the sensory decussation and continue their ascent as the medial lemniscus, which is a major ascending sensory pathway(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 356)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: All are tributaries of the cavernous sinus except
questions.ref_book: The deep middle cerebral vein drains into the basal vein, not the cavernous sinus. The listed tributaries-superior ophthalmic vein, superficial middle cerebral vein, and sphenoparietal sinus-all communicate directly with the cavernous sinus(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 317)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: The area of the lateral aspect of the skull that overlies the anterior division of the middle meningeal artery is known as
questions.ref_book: The pterion is the H-shaped junction of frontal, parietal, temporal, and sphenoid bones and is clinically significant as it lies directly over the anterior division of the middle meningeal artery, making it prone to epidural hematoma if fractured(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 20)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Great cerebral vein of Galen is formed by the union of
questions.ref_book: The great cerebral vein of Galen is a short venous trunk formed by the union of two internal cerebral veins, which drain deep structures of the brain. It empties into the straight sinus, playing a vital role in deep cerebral venous drainage(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 410)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: The trochlear nerve nucleus is present at the level of
questions.option_a: Midbrain at the level of Superior colliculus
questions.option_b: Midbrain at the level of Inferior colliculus
questions.ref_book: The trochlear nerve (CN IV) is the only cranial nerve to emerge dorsally and decussate completely. Its nucleus is located posterior to the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) in the midbrain, specifically at the level of the inferior colliculi(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 361)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Charcot's artery of cerebral hemorrhage belongs to
questions.ref_book: Charcot's artery, a lateral striate artery (from the middle cerebral artery), is a common site of spontaneous cerebral hemorrhage, especially in hypertensive individuals. It supplies the internal capsule and basal ganglia, making rupture clinically significant.(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 400)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Which fibres of the corpus callosum form the tapetum that forms the boundary of the lateral ventricle?
questions.ref_book: The tapetum is a thin sheet of white matter formed by fibers from the trunk and splenium of the corpus callosum. It lines the lateral wall and roof of the posterior and inferior horns of the lateral ventricles, providing structural support. These fibers sweep laterally and inferiorly into the temporal and occipital lobes, forming the tapetum that separates the ventricular cavity from adjacent cortical areas. Hence, the correct anatomical origin of the tapetum is the trunk and splenium of the corpus callosum(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 383)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Vascular lesion involving the crus cerebri of midbrain and 3rd cranial nerve is
questions.ref_book: Weber's syndrome results from infarction of the crus cerebri and oculomotor nerve (usually by posterior cerebral artery branch). It presents with ipsilateral 3rd nerve palsy and contralateral hemiplegia, making it a classic brainstem stroke syndrome(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 362)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Precentral gyrus is the centre for
questions.ref_book: The precentral gyrus, located immediately anterior to the central sulcus in the frontal lobe, functions as the primary motor cortex. It controls voluntary movements, especially skilled actions of the contralateral side of the body(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 381)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Filum terminale is a modification of spinal ??
questions.ref_book: The filum terminale anchors the spinal cord inferiorly. It is a fibrous extension of the pia mater, not a nerve or component of dura/arachnoid. It ensures the longitudinal stability of the spinal cord within the vertebral canal(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 294)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Damage to which of the following structures leads to bitemporal hemianopia in the visual field?
questions.ref_book: The optic chiasma is where the nasal retinal fibers cross. Since these fibers carry impulses from the temporal visual fields, a lesion at the chiasma (often due to a pituitary tumor) causes bitemporal hemianopia, the classic "tunnel vision" presentation(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 322)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Which segment of the spinal cord gives rise to the thoracolumbar outflow?
questions.ref_book: The sympathetic nervous system, also called the thoracolumbar outflow, originates from the lateral horn of the spinal cord segments T1 to L2. It supplies the body's fight-or-flight response, including structures in the head, thorax, abdomen, and limbs(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 298)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Fibres arising from Edinger-Westphal nucleus relay in
questions.ref_book: The Edinger-Westphal nucleus, located in the midbrain, gives rise to preganglionic parasympathetic fibers that travel via the oculomotor nerve (CN III) and synapse in the ciliary ganglion. Postganglionic fibers then control pupil constriction and lens accommodation(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 325)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: The dura mater extends up to which vertebral level?
questions.ref_book: The dura mater, along with the arachnoid mater, forms the dural sac that encloses the spinal cord and cauda equina. This sac typically terminates at the S2 vertebral level, which is important for procedures like lumbar puncture and caudal anesthesia(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 294)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Where is Broca's motor speech area represented in the cerebral hemisphere?
questions.option_a: Pars triangularis of inferior frontal gyrus
questions.option_b: Posterior part of superior temporal gyrus
questions.ref_book: Broca's area is responsible for motor aspects of speech production. It is located in the inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant (usually left) hemisphere, specifically in the pars triangularis and pars opercularis. Damage to this area causes Broca's aphasia (expressive aphasia), where comprehension is intact but speech is non-fluent(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 381)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Which nerve encircles the middle meningeal artery in the infratemporal fossa?
questions.ref_book: The auriculotemporal nerve, a branch of the posterior division of the mandibular nerve (V3), arises as two roots that split and loop around the middle meningeal artery in the infratemporal fossa(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 136)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Which of the following structures contain Herring bodies?
questions.ref_book: Herring bodies are found in the posterior pituitary (neurohypophysis) and represent sites where oxytocin and vasopressin are stored before release(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 320)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Which cranial nerve represents the efferent pathway for the pupillary light reflex?
questions.ref_book: In the pupillary light reflex, light entering one eye leads to constriction of both pupils. The optic nerve (CN II) carries the sensory input (afferent limb), while the oculomotor nerve (CN III) carries motor signals (efferent limb) to the sphincter pupillae, causing pupil constriction(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 326)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Which structure is not present between the cranial base and the upper border of the superior constrictor?
questions.ref_book: The buccopharyngeal fascia lies superficial to the muscular layer of the pharynx and is not located in the gap between the skull base and the superior constrictor. That gap is filled by the pharyngobasilar fascia and allows passage of specific structures like the pharyngotympanic tube and levator veli palatini.(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 76)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Which of the following structures has a blood-brain barrier?
questions.ref_book: Among the options provided, the anterior lobe of the pituitary (adenohypophysis) has a blood-brain barrier (BBB), while the others-pineal gland, posterior pituitary, and area postrema-are part of the circumventricular organs, which lack a blood-brain barrier.

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: The bulb of the posterior horn of the lateral ventricle is raised by
questions.ref_book: The bulb of the posterior horn is the upper elevation seen in the posterior horn of the lateral ventricle. This is formed by the forceps major, which is a bundle of commissural fibers from the splenium of the corpus callosum. The lower bulge, called calcar avis, is caused by indentation of the calcarine sulcus, not the bulb. Therefore, the correct structure elevating the bulb is forceps major(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 386)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Which nucleus lies beneath the facial colliculus?
questions.option_a: Motor nucleus of the facial nerve
questions.ref_book: The facial colliculus is a surface landmark in the floor of the fourth ventricle, located in the pons. It is formed by the internal genu of the facial nerve, which loops over the abducent nucleus. Thus, the abducent nucleus lies directly beneath the facial colliculus, while the fibers of the facial nerve pass over it.(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 327)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Type of fibers present in the internal capsule
questions.ref_book: The internal capsule is a dense collection of projection fibers that connect the cerebral cortex with lower centers like the brainstem and spinal cord. It carries both ascending (sensory) and descending (motor) tracts(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 384)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Which one of the following is an extrapyramidal tract?
questions.ref_book:
The rubrospinal tract arises from the red nucleus in the midbrain and is a part of the extrapyramidal system, which is involved in involuntary control of muscle tone, posture, and locomotion.
In contrast, the lateral and anterior corticospinal tracts are pyramidal tracts, responsible for voluntary motor control. The anterior spinocerebellar tract carries proprioceptive information to the cerebellum, not motor commands, and is neither pyramidal nor extrapyramidal.(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 300)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Lesion of which artery causes Lateral Medullary Syndrome?
questions.ref_book: Lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome) results from a vascular insult to the lateral medulla, most commonly due to occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA). This affects structures like the vestibular nuclei, spinal trigeminal nucleus, lateral spinothalamic tract, nucleus ambiguus, and sympathetic fibers, leading to a classical constellation of clinical signs (vertigo, ataxia, loss of pain/temp sensation, dysphagia, Horner's syndrome(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 357)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: The part devoid of the blood-brain barrier is
questions.ref_book: The ciliary body (part of the uveal tract in the eye) is devoid of a blood-brain barrier (BBB). It is involved in aqueous humor production and needs to allow free exchange of substances between the blood and the eye chambers, hence it has fenestrated capillaries

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: The cerebellar glomerulus is composed of all EXCEPT
questions.ref_book: Climbing fibers, on the other hand, do not participate in the cerebellar glomerulus. They directly synapse with Purkinje cell dendrites in the molecular layer

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Fibers arising from the Edinger-Westphal nucleus relay in the
questions.ref_book: The Edinger-Westphal nucleus is a parasympathetic nucleus located near the oculomotor nucleus in the midbrain. Its preganglionic fibers travel through the oculomotor nerve (CN III) and synapse in the ciliary ganglion(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 281)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Structure present in the interpeduncular fossa of the brain is
questions.ref_book:
The interpeduncular fossa is the space between the two cerebral peduncles (crura cerebri) on the ventral surface of the midbrain. It contains important structures such as:

Mammillary bodies (posterior part),

Posterior perforated substance, and

Basilar artery branches.(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 349)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Commonest site of fracture in the base of the skull is
questions.ref_book:
Fracture of middle cranial fossa: The middle cranial fossa
is the commonest site of fracture of the base of the skull. It is
partly because of its position but also because it is weakened
by numerous foramina and canals(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 310)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Extending up to the level of S2 vertebra
questions.option_c: Are the dura, arachnoid, and pia mater
questions.option_d: Are the dura and arachnoid mater
questions.ref_book: The dura mater and arachnoid mater extend from the foramen magnum down to the S2 vertebra, where they end as a blind sac. The pia mater, however, continues beyond S2 as the filum terminale, which anchors the spinal cord to the coccyx(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-3, Page No  - 294)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: All the following nerves cross the arch of aorta in front except
questions.option_d: Superior cervical cardiac branch of left sympathetic trunk
questions.ref_book: The left phrenic nerve, left vagus nerve, and the superior cervical cardiac branch of the left sympathetic trunk all cross anterior to the arch of aorta. In contrast, the left recurrent laryngeal nerve loops under the arch, behind the ligamentum arteriosum, and ascends in the tracheoesophageal groove. Thus, it lies inferior, not anterior, to the arch of aorta(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 290)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Intercostobrachial nerve is the
questions.option_b: Lateral cutaneous branch of 2nd intercostal nerve
questions.option_c: Anterior cutaneous branch of 2nd intercostal nerve
questions.ref_book: Second intercostal nerve: Its lateral cutaneous branch is called intercostobrachial nerve. It courses across the axilla and joins the medial cutaneous branch of the arm(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 223)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Horizontal fissure of the lung runs along the level of
questions.ref_book: The horizontal fissure of the right lung separates the superior and middle lobes and is found only in the right lung. It runs from the oblique fissure in the midaxillary line horizontally forward to the anterior border of the lung, at the level of the 4th costal cartilage(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 245)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Broncho-pulmonary lymph nodes lie in the
questions.ref_book: Bronchopulmonary (hilar) lymph nodes are located at the hilum of the lung, where they receive lymph from both the superficial and deep lymphatic plexuses of the lungs(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 250)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: All structures traverse the whole length of the mediastinum except
questions.ref_book: Among the options, the esophagus, thoracic duct, and sympathetic trunks extend from the superior to the posterior mediastinum, passing through the entire length of the mediastinum. In contrast, the trachea begins in the neck and only extends up to the level of the sternal angle (T4), where it bifurcates into the primary bronchi(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 260)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Aortic knuckle, a projection in the upper part of the left margin of the cardiac shadow in X-ray chest PA view is cast by
questions.ref_book: The aortic knuckle seen in the PA view of chest X-ray is a distinct rounded projection formed by the arch of the aorta. It is visible on the upper part of the left border of the cardiac shadow. This finding is a normal anatomical feature but can become prominent in conditions like aortic aneurysm or atherosclerosis(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 292)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: The lingual is a tongue-shaped projection from
questions.ref_book: The lingula is a small, tongue-shaped projection from the upper lobe of the left lung, located just below the cardiac notch. It corresponds anatomically to the middle lobe of the right lung and helps accommodate the space created by the heart(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 239)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Lymphatics from the lower end of the esophagus drain into
questions.ref_book: The lymph vessels from lower one-third of the esophagus descend through the esophageal opening of the diaphragm and drain into the celiac lymph nodes around the celiac trunk(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 303)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: The rib commonly fractures
questions.option_b: At the middle of its shaft
questions.ref_book: Rib fractures typically occur at the posterior angle, the point where the shaft bends sharply. This angle is biomechanically the weakest part of the rib, making it vulnerable to trauma(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 211)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: The musculophrenic artery is a branch of ?......
questions.ref_book: The musculophrenic artery is one of the two terminal branches of the internal thoracic artery, the other being the superior epigastric artery. It descends laterally and downward, behind the costal cartilages of the 7th to 9th ribs, and contributes to supplying the diaphragm and anterior abdominal wall. Its anatomical course and branching pattern are important during thoracic surgeries and in coronary artery bypass procedures using internal thoracic artery grafts(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 227)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Which nerve innervates the mediastinal pleura?
questions.ref_book: The mediastinal pleura, being a part of the parietal pleura, is derived from the somatopleuric mesoderm and is innervated by somatic nerves. Specifically, the phrenic nerve (C3-C5) supplies sensory innervation to the mediastinal pleura and also to the central diaphragmatic pleura. This explains why irritation of this region can cause referred pain to the shoulder, an area also innervated by C3-C5 (supraclavicular nerves)(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 237)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: What is a part of the lung aerated by a respiratory bronchiole called?
questions.ref_book: The respiratory bronchiole marks the beginning of the respiratory portion of the lung. It gives rise to alveolar ducts and alveoli where gaseous exchange occurs. The area of lung tissue ventilated by a single respiratory bronchiole is known as a pulmonary unit. This includes alveolar ducts, atria, air saccules, and alveoli, forming the basic functional respiratory unit of the lung(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 243)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Cardiac dominance depends on
questions.ref_book: Cardiac dominance refers to which coronary artery gives rise to the posterior interventricular artery, which supplies the posterior part of the interventricular septum. In about 90% of people, this artery arises from the right coronary artery (right dominance). In the remaining 10%, it arises from the circumflex branch of the left coronary artery (left dominance). Therefore, dominance is not about which artery is larger, but about the origin of the posterior interventricular artery(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 280)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Thoracic duct enters the thoracic cavity through the
questions.ref_book: The thoracic duct, the body's largest lymphatic channel, begins as the cisterna chyli in the abdomen and ascends through the aortic opening of the diaphragm at the level of T12 vertebra. This opening also transmits the aorta and azygos vein(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 306)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Which movement leads to an increase in the transverse diameter of the thoracic cage?
questions.ref_book: The bucket handle movement of the ribs occurs primarily in the vertebrochondral ribs (false ribs), which swing outward and upward during inspiration. This motion resembles the lifting of a bucket handle and leads to an increase in the transverse diameter of the thoracic cage(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 230)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Which nerve hooks around the ligamentum arteriosum?
questions.ref_book: The left recurrent laryngeal nerve, a branch of the left vagus nerve, loops under the arch of aorta, specifically around the ligamentum arteriosum, before ascending between the trachea and esophagus. This relationship is unique to the left side-on the right, the recurrent laryngeal nerve loops around the right subclavian artery. This anatomical loop is clinically important because aneurysms of the aortic arch or enlargement of lymph nodes near the ligamentum arteriosum may compress the nerve, leading to hoarseness of voice(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 291)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: What is the root value of cervical nerves that unite to form the phrenic nerve?
questions.ref_book: The phrenic nerve, essential for motor supply to the diaphragm, arises from C3-C5 cervical spinal nerves(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 311)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Which structure passes through the vena caval opening along with the inferior vena cava?
questions.ref_book: The vena caval opening (T8 level) transmits the inferior vena cava and the right phrenic nerve. The left phrenic nerve passes separately through the diaphragm near the apex of the heart(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 199)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Which is the feature of the interatrial septum?
questions.ref_book: The fossa ovalis is a prominent structure on the interatrial septum, marking the fetal location of the foramen ovale. It is bordered superiorly by the annulus ovalis (limbus)(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 270)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Structures related to the mediastinal surface of the right lung are all EXCEPT
questions.ref_book: The mediastinal surface of the right lung is related to several mediastinal structures including the right atrium, SVC, IVC, esophagus, and azygos vein. However, the thoracic duct runs to the left of the vertebral column and ascends into the superior mediastinum to reach the left venous angle(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 242)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Which is not a tributary of the coronary sinus?
questions.option_d: Posterior vein of the left ventricle
questions.ref_book: The coronary sinus is the main venous channel of the heart and receives blood from multiple cardiac veins, including the great cardiac vein, small cardiac vein, middle cardiac vein, posterior vein of the left ventricle, and oblique vein of left atrium. However, the anterior cardiac veins are an exception - they drain directly into the right atrium instead of passing through the coronary sinus(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 282)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Which of the following is a vertebrochondral rib?
questions.ref_book:
Ribs are classified based on how they connect to the sternum:

True ribs (1st-7th): Connect directly to the sternum.

False ribs (8th-12th): Do not connect directly to the sternum.

Vertebrochondral ribs (8th-10th): A subset of false ribs that connect indirectly to the sternum via the costal cartilage of the rib above.

Floating ribs (11th-12th): Have no anterior attachment.

Hence, the 9th rib, which connects anteriorly to the costal cartilage of the 8th rib, is a vertebrochondral rib(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 206)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: The structures in the midline at the thoracic inlet include all of the following EXCEPT
questions.ref_book: The thoracic inlet (also called the superior thoracic aperture) allows midline structures such as the trachea, esophagus, and thoracic duct to pass from the neck into the thorax. Although the thymus lies in the superior mediastinum, it is not situated in the midline at the thoracic inlet and does not traverse through it. Hence, among the listed options, thymus is the exception(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 197)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: What is false about the opening for the inferior vena cava?
questions.option_a: It lies at the level of T8 vertebra
questions.option_b: It is the highest of the three major openings of the diaphragm
questions.option_c: It transmits the right phrenic nerve
questions.ref_book: The vena caval opening of the diaphragm is located at the T8 vertebral level and transmits the inferior vena cava along with the right phrenic nerve. It is the highest of the three major diaphragm openings (others being esophageal at T10 and aortic at T12). However, the azygos vein does not pass through this opening - it passes through the aortic opening, along with the aorta and thoracic duct. Thus, the statement that the vena caval opening transmits the azygos vein is false(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 199)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: The lobe of the azygos vein is related to a projection of
questions.ref_book: The azygos lobe is an anatomical variant seen in some right lungs where a part of the mediastinal pleura folds around the terminal part of the azygos vein, creating a fissure. This leads to the appearance of an accessory lobe(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 244)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Bifurcation of the trachea is at the level of
questions.option_a: Upper border of T5 Thoracic vertebrae
questions.option_b: Upper border of T4 Thoracic vertebrae
questions.option_c: Upper border of T3 Thoracic vertebrae
questions.option_d: Upper border of T2 Thoracic vertebrae
questions.ref_book: The trachea bifurcates into right and left principal bronchi at the lower border of the T4 vertebra, which corresponds to the sternal angle of Louis, a key clinical landmark(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 297)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: The central part of the dome of the diaphragm is at the level of
questions.ref_book: The central tendon of the diaphragm forms the central part of the dome, and is positioned anteriorly at the level of the xiphisternal joint, making it a key landmark in imaging and surgery(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 198)

questions.ref_book: Textbook Of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 3rd Edition (Vol 1), Page No : 38

questions.ref_book: Textbook Of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 3rd Edition (Vol 1), Page No : 76

questions.ref_book: Textbook Of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 3rd Edition (Vol 1), Page No : 37

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Which muscle is supplied by two different nerves?
questions.ref_book: Textbook Of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 3rd Edition (Vol 1), Page No : 95

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Flexion at interphalangeal joint and extension of metacarpo phalengeal joints of 4th x 5th fingers is
questions.ref_book: Textbook Of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 3rd Edition (Vol 1), Page No : 182

questions.ref_book: Textbook Of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 3rd Edition (Vol 1), Page No : 118
