questions.ref_book: Textbook Of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 3rd Edition (Vol 1), Page No : 97

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Which of the following is a branch of upper trunk of brachial plexus?
questions.ref_book: Textbook Of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 3rd Edition (Vol 1), Page No : 54

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Tendon of which muscle lies in the Radial bursa
questions.ref_book: Textbook Of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 3rd Edition (Vol 1), Page No : 140

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: The muscle inserted into the radial side of the base of the first metacarpal bone is
questions.ref_book: The abductor pollicis longus is the only muscle among the listed options that inserts on the radial side of the base of the first metacarpal. The other muscles insert either on the proximal or distal phalanx of the thumb, or on a different part of the metacarpal. This muscle plays a key role in thumb abduction and is located in the deep group of extensor muscles of the posterior forearm(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 123)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Flexor digitorum profundus is inserted into
questions.ref_book: Flexor digitorum profundus forms four tendons that pass deep to the flexor retinaculum and insert into the distal phalanges of the medial four fingers. It perforates the tendon of flexor digitorum superficialis before reaching its insertion.(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 114)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Saturday nerve palsy is due to compression of
questions.ref_book: Saturday night palsy results from compression of the radial nerve, commonly when a person falls asleep with their arm hanging over a chair, leading to wrist drop due to extensor muscle paralysis.(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 171)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Ape thumb deformity is due to injury of
questions.ref_book: Ape thumb deformity occurs due to paralysis of the thenar muscles (especially opponens pollicis), which are supplied by the median nerve. This leads to inability to oppose the thumb, causing it to lie in the plane of the palm(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 177)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: All the muscles are supplied by Musculocutaneous nerve EXCEPT
questions.ref_book: Although brachioradialis is a flexor at the elbow joint, it lies in the extensor compartment and is supplied by the radial nerve, not the musculocutaneous nerve. This makes it the exception(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 120)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Which carpal bone is more prone for avascular necrosis
questions.ref_book: The scaphoid bone, when fractured at its narrow waist, may have its proximal fragment deprived of blood supply-especially in 10-15% of individuals where vessels enter only through the distal pole-leading to avascular necrosis(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 30)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Which of the following statements is not correct regarding the anatomical snuff box?
questions.option_a: Medially bound by extensor carpi radialis longus
questions.option_b: Laterally bound by abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis
questions.option_c: Roof is crossed by superficial branch of radial nerve
questions.ref_book: The medial boundary is formed by the extensor pollicis longus, not extensor carpi radialis longus. So, statement (a) is incorrect. All other options are correctly describing the snuff box(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 157)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Which nerve innervates adductor pollicis?
questions.ref_book: The adductor pollicis, although located in the thenar region, is unique as it is innervated by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve, unlike other thenar muscles which are mostly supplied by the median nerve(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 179)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Nerve supply of Teres major is
questions.ref_book: The teres major muscle receives its motor innervation from the lower subscapular nerve, which arises from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus. This differentiates it from the nearby teres minor, which is supplied by the axillary nerve.(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 69)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: What type of joint is wrist joint?
questions.ref_book: The radiocarpal (wrist) joint is classified as an ellipsoid synovial joint. It permits biaxial movement including flexion-extension and abduction-adduction, but not axial rotation. This joint type is distinct from hinge (uniaxial) and saddle (reciprocally concave-convex) joints.(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 160)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: First carpometacarpal joint is a
questions.ref_book: The first carpometacarpal joint (thumb joint) is a synovial saddle joint formed between the trapezium and the base of the first metacarpal. Its unique saddle-shaped, reciprocally concavo-convex articular surfaces allow a wide range of thumb movements including opposition, which is crucial for grasping(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 164)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: What is the action of palmar interossei?
questions.ref_book: Palmar interossei are unipennate muscles that originate from the palmar aspects of metacarpals and insert into the extensor expansions. Their primary action is adduction of fingers toward the middle finger (midline of hand), often remembered by the mnemonic "PAD" (Palmar = ADduction).(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 149)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Tennis elbow is due to
questions.option_a: Tear of the radial collateral ligament
questions.option_b: Tear of the medial collateral ligament
questions.ref_book: Tennis Elbow Due to : a.Sprain of radial collateral ligament, b.Tearing of fibers of the extensor carpi radialis brevis. (BD, Chaurasia's Anatomy, 7th Edition, Vol 3, Page No -172)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Policeman's tip deformity occurs due to
questions.ref_book: Policeman's tip deformity results from Erb's palsy, due to injury to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus (C5-C6), commonly affecting muscles like deltoid, biceps, and brachialis. The limb hangs by the side, medially rotated and extended(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 57)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: The structures which do not pierce the clavipectoral fascia
questions.ref_book: The medial pectoral nerve does not pierce the clavipectoral fascia. Instead, it supplies the pectoralis major and minor from behind. The cephalic vein, thoracoacromial vessels, and lateral pectoral nerve all pierce the fascia.(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 39)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Paralysis of which muscle leads to Winging of scapula?
questions.ref_book: The serratus anterior stabilizes the scapula against the thoracic wall. Paralysis (often due to long thoracic nerve injury) causes the scapula to protrude like a wing, especially when pushing against resistance.(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 38)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: What is the level of termination of the axillary artery?
questions.ref_book: The axillary artery transitions into the brachial artery at the lower border of teres major, not at coracobrachialis or pronator teres. This anatomical landmark is crucial for surgical and clinical relevance(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 50)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Retraction of scapula is produced by
questions.option_a: Upper fibers of trapezius and levator scapula
questions.option_b: Middle fibers of trapezius and rhomboids
questions.option_c: Upper and lower fibers of trapezius and serratus anterior
questions.option_d: Lower fibers of trapezius and pectoralis minor
questions.ref_book: Retraction of the scapula (bringing it medially toward the vertebral column) is chiefly accomplished by rhomboids and middle fibers of trapezius, not the upper or lower fibers(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 62)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Which nerve terminates as a pseudoganglion?
questions.ref_book: The axillary nerve gives a branch to teres minor, and notably, the nerve to teres minor ends in a structure called a pseudoganglion, which is a fusiform swelling of the nerve resembling a ganglion but does not contain any nerve cell bodies(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 71)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: First bone to ossify in the body and last to complete ossification
questions.ref_book: The clavicle is the first bone to begin ossification, starting during the 5th to 6th week of intrauterine life, and it is also the last to complete ossification, as its sternal (medial) epiphysis fuses around 25 years of age. This makes it unique among all bones in terms of timing of ossification initiation and completion(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 12)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Which of the following pierces the interosseous membrane?
questions.ref_book: The anterior interosseous artery, a branch of the common interosseous artery, passes from the anterior to the posterior compartment by piercing the interosseous membrane in the distal third of the forearm. It anastomoses with the posterior interosseous artery(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 115)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Which nerve gives rise to the lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm?
questions.ref_book: The musculocutaneous nerve (C5-C7), after supplying the coracobrachialis, biceps brachii, and brachialis, continues as the lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm, which supplies the skin on the lateral side of the forearm.(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 172)

questions.subject: ANATOMY
questions.que: Which thoracic vertebra corresponds to the root of the spine of the scapula?
questions.ref_book:
T2: level of the superior angle of the scapula

T3: level where the crest (root) of the spine of the scapula meets the medial border

T7: level of the inferior angle of the scapula(Text Book of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Vol-1, Page No  - 60)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que:
A 11 year old boy presented with a massive elevation of AFP. He has had recurrent
episodes of jaundice since birth. At the age of 9, he was diagnosed with porphyria. His
urine shows high succinylacetone. What is your diagnosis?
questions.ref_book: Tyrosinemia Type I (HT1). HT1 is a genetic disorder due to deficiency of enzyme fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase (FAH) where the body can't properly break down the amino acid tyrosine, leading to the buildup of toxic byproducts like succinylacetone. The buildup of succinylacetone disrupts porphyrin metabolism, leading to increased levels of porphyrin precursors and sometimes even the porphyria-like symptoms. These symptoms can include jaundice, abdominal pain, peripheral neuropathy, and neurological crises. (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK1515/)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: Function of glutamine in blood:
questions.ref_book: Glutamine is hydrolysed to glutamate and ammonia. The ammonia is later buffered by H+ ions and excreted by urine.(Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Seventh Edition - Pg no : 225)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: All of the following are actions of Epinephrine, EXCEPT
questions.ref_book: Catecholamines namely epinephrine and nor-epinephrine are synthesised from aminoacid Tyrosine in adrenal medulla. They are responsible for increase in blood pressure. Epinephrine increases the rate and force of myocardial contraction, causes relaxation of smooth muscles and bronchi and in general anti-insulin in nature.(Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Seventh Edition - Pg no : 236)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que:
The thyroid hormones T3 and T4 are synthesized in the follicular cells of the thyroid
gland. From which of the following essential amino acids are the thyroid hormones
synthesized?
questions.ref_book: Thyroid hormone is synthesised from the non-essential aminoacid tyrosine. The aminoacid tyrosine is synthesised from the essential aminoacid Phenylalanine which makes it essentail for the synthesis of thyroid hormones. The otjer major products synthesised from tyrosine are catecholamines and melanin.(Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Seventh Edition - Pg no : 236)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que:
A 20 year old boy with severe mental retardation, mousy odour in body fluids,
hypopigmentation. Patient has frequent episodes of seizures and aggressive behaviour.
What is your diagnosis?
questions.ref_book: Phenylketonuria(PKU) is due to deficiency of enzyme Phenylalanine hydroxylase causes accumulation of aminoacid Phenylalanine. As a result the aminoacid will enter into alternate pathways and produce phenyl lactate, phenylacetate and phenylpyruvate. Phenyllactate in sweat gives us mousy body odour. the disorder is also characterised by hypopigmentation due to defective melanin synthesis and mental reatadation. (Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Seventh Edition - Pg no : 236)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: Specialized products obtained from tyrosine exclude:
questions.ref_book: The specialised products formed from tyrosine includes melanin, thyroxine and catecholamines.(Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Seventh Edition - Pg no : 233)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY

questions.ref_book: Porphyria is seen in type - I Tyrosinemia. Type II tyrosinemia is due to deficiency of tyrosine transaminase and is characterised by corneal ulcers, palmar keratosis, mental retardation and photophobia(Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Seventh Edition - Pg no : 239)

questions.ref_book: Alkaptonuria is a disorder due to deficiency of enztne homogentisate oxidase which causes accululation of Homogentisate and its excretion in urine. On oxidation homogentisate is converted to benzoquinone which causes darkening of urine.(Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Seventh Edition - Pg no : 238)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: FIGLU Test is done after a load of
questions.ref_book:
The metabolism of histidine is important for
 the generation of one-carbon unit, namely
 formimino group. The enzyme histidase acts on
 histidine to split off ammonia. Urocanate formed
 in this reaction is acted upon by urocanase to
 produce 4-imidazole 5-propionate. Imidazole
 ring of the product is cleaved by a hydrolase to
 give N-formiminoglutamate (FIGLU). Tetra
hydrofolate (THF) takes up the formimino group
 to form N5-formimino THF, and glutamate is
 liberated. Deficiency of folate blocks this
 reaction and causes elevated excretion of FIGLU
 in urine. (Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Tenth Edition - Pg no : 343)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que:
A couple of African American descent gives birth to a boy after an otherwise
uneventful pregnancy. The child is exceptionally fair- skinned and has almost white
hair. Further examination reveals red pupils. A postnatal screen is likely to confirm the
deficiency of which of the following enzymes in the child?
questions.ref_book:
The most common cause of albinism is a
 defect in tyrosinase, the enzyme most responsible
 for the synthesis of melanin. The most important
 function of melanin is the protection of the body
 from sun radiation. Lack of melanin in albinos
 makes them sensitive to sunlight. Increased
 susceptibility to skin cancer (carcinoma) is
 observed. Photophobia (intolerance to light) is
 associated with lack of pigment in the eyes.(Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Tenth Edition - Pg no : 339)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: Hartnup's disease is associated with defective absorption of:
questions.ref_book:
It is characterized by the inability of intestinal and
 renal epithelial cells to absorb neutral amino
 acids (tryptophan, alanine, serine, threonine,
 valine). Tryptophan absorption is most severely
 affected with a result that typical symptoms of
 pellagra are observed in the patients of Hartnup's
 disease.(Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Tenth Edition - Pg no : 342)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: Nitric oxide is synthesized from
questions.ref_book:
Arginine is the substrate
 for the production of nitric oxide (NO), a wonder
 molecule with a wide range of functions. The
 enzyme nitric oxide synthase (three isoenzymes
 known) cleaves the nitrogen from the guanidino
 group of arginine to form NO. This reaction
 requires NADPH, FMN, FAD, heme and
 tetrahydrobiopterin. (Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Tenth Edition - Pg no : 322)

All the above mentioned proteins are seen in Alpha 2 region while seperation except antitrypsin which is seen in alpha 1 region.(Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: Deficiency leading to Emphysema:
questions.ref_book: Alpha 1 Antitrypsin (AAT) inhibits all serine proteases mainly elastase. So its deficiency leads to unopposed action of elastase in lungs and causes emphysema and damage to lung tissue.(Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Seventh Edition - Pg no : 384)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: The electrophoretic pattern in multiple myeloma is
questions.ref_book:
Electrophoresis of serum proteins is
 conveniently used for the diagnosis of certain
 diseases
 1. Multiple myeloma : A sharp and distinct
 M band appears in the -globulin fraction.
 2. Acute infections :  Alpha 1- and alpha 2- globulins
are increased.
3. Nephrotic syndrome : Decreased albumin
 with sharp and prominent alpha  2-globulin.
 4. Primary immune deficiency : Diminished- gamma globulin band.
 5. Alpha 1-Antitrypsin deficiency : Diminished alpha 1 
globulin band.(Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Tenth Edition - Pg no : 445)

Seventh Edition - Pg no : 221)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: Example for Bond specificity of enzymes is
questions.ref_book:
Bond specificity means the enzyme acts on a specific type of chemical bond, regardless of the rest of the molecule.

Urease ? Example of absolute specificity (acts only on urea).

Trypsin ? ? Example of bond specificity (acts on peptide bonds specifically at the carboxyl side of lysine and arginine residues).

Hexokinase ? Example of group specificity (acts on hexoses like glucose, fructose, mannose).

Lactate dehydrogenase ? Example of stereospecificity (acts only on L-lactate, not D-lactate).

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: Enzymes catalyzing antioxidant reactions exclude:
questions.ref_book:
Enzymes that catalyze antioxidant reactions protect the cell from reactive oxygen species (ROS):

Glutathione peroxidase ? ? Antioxidant (reduces H?O? and lipid peroxides).

Superoxide dismutase (SOD) ? ? Antioxidant (converts superoxide radicals to H?O?).

Catalase ? ? Antioxidant (breaks down H?O? to water and oxygen).

Glutathione reductase ? ? Not directly antioxidant - it regenerates reduced glutathione (GSH) from oxidized glutathione (GSSG), enabling glutathione peroxidase to function, but it does not directly neutralize ROS.

Answer: ? Glutathione reductase

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: The human oncogenic virus associated with Kaposi sarcoma is
questions.ref_book:
For Kaposi sarcoma, the human oncogenic virus is Human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8), also called Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV).

HHV-8 is often seen in immunocompromised patients, especially those with HIV/AIDS, but HIV itself is not the oncogenic virus - it's the immunosuppression from HIV that allows HHV-8 to cause disease.

Since HHV-8 isn't in your options, the closest correct choice in this list (if your exam expects the AIDS association) would be:
? d) Human immunodeficiency virus - as it is epidemiologically linked through immunosuppression, even though the actual oncogenic virus is HHV-8

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: Deficiency of Alpha Galactosidase leads to
questions.ref_book: Sphingolipidoses or Lipid storage disorderscare group of lysosomal storage disorders due to deficiency of a particular enzyme which leads to failure in the breakdown of particular sphingolipid. The common features include accumulation of particular sphingolipid, mental retardation, cherry red spot in retina in some types.(Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Seventh Edition - Pg no : 193)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: Action of Prostacyclin include
questions.ref_book: Prostacyclin (PGI2) is synthesised by vascular endothelium. Major effect is vasodilation. It also inhibits platelet aggregation and has a protective effect on vessel wall against deposition of platelets. (Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Seventh Edition - Pg no : 191)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: Deficiency of Beta Glucosidase leads to
questions.ref_book: Gaucher's disease is an inborn error of metabolism due to failure in degradation of glucocerebrosides. The disease is characterised by hepatosplenomegaly, erosion of bone and moderate anemia. The disease is of three types - Adult, Infantile and Juvenile.(Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Seventh Edition - Pg no : 193)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: In a well-fed state, all of the following changes occur in adipose tissue, EXCEPT
questions.ref_book: Under well fed conditions, active lipogenesis happens in adipose tissue. The dietary TAG transported by chylomicrons and endogenous TAG brought by VLDL are both taken by adipose tissue and stored there. The lipoproteins are broken down by lipoprotein lipase on capillary wall. Increased insulin levels leads to inhibition of hormone sensitive lipase (Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Seventh Edition - Pg no : 161)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: The DNA polymerase which helps in mitochondrial DNA synthesis is
questions.ref_book:
1.DNA polymerase alpha  is responsible for the
 synthesis of RNA primer for both the leading and
 lagging strands of DNA.
 2. DNA polymerase beta  is involved in the
 repair of DNA. Its function is comparable with
 DNA polymerase I found in prokaryotes.
 3. DNA polymerase gamma  participates in the
 replication of mitochondrial DNA.
 4. DNA polymerase delta  is responsible for the
 replication on the leading strand of DNA. It also
 possesses proof-reading activity.                                         5.DNA polymerase epsilon  is involved in DNA
 synthesis on the lagging strand and proof-reading
 function.(Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Tenth Edition - Pg no : 643)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: The Histone that is not present in a nucleosome is
questions.ref_book:
The DNA double helix is wrapped around the
 core proteins namely histones which are basic in
 nature. The core is composed of two molecules
 of histones (H2A, H2B, H3 and H4). Each core
 with two turns of DNA wrapped round it
 (approximately with 150 bp) is termed as a
 nucleosome, the basic unit of chromatin.(Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Tenth Edition - Pg no : 637)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: Which of the following is true about eukaryotic replication?
questions.option_b: Requires a 5'3' strand to act as a template
questions.ref_book:
The telomerase RNA base pairs to the end of
 the DNA molecule with telomeres and extends
 to a small distance. Then translocation of
 telomerase occurs and a fresh extension of DNA
 takes place. This process of DNA synthesis and
 translocation is repeated several times until the
 chromosome gets sufficiently extended. The
 extension process gets completed through
 the participation of DNA polymerase and
 primase complex and sealing of the new DNA
 formed(Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Tenth Edition - Pg no : 647)

questions.ref_book: Refer TABLE 34.4(Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Tenth Edition - Pg no : 647)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: The most common form of DNA is
questions.ref_book:
TheB-form of DNA double helix, described by
 Watson and Crick (discussed above), is the most
 predominant form under physiological
 conditions. Each turn of the B-form has 10 base
 pairs spanning a distance of 3.4 nm. The width
 of the double helix is 2 nm.(Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Tenth Edition - Pg no : 637)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: The features of B DNA include all EXCEPT
questions.option_b: One full turn has 10 nucleotides and measures 34? width 20?
questions.ref_book:
TheB-form of DNA double helix, described by
 Watson and Crick (discussed above), is the most
 predominant form under physiological
 conditions. Each turn of the B-form has 10 base
 pairs spanning a distance of 3.4 nm. The width
 of the double helix is 2 nm. Broad major groove and short minor groove.(Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Tenth Edition - Pg no : 637)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: Base excision repair is done by
questions.ref_book:
A defective DNA in which cytosine is
 deaminated to uracil is acted upon by the
 enzyme uracil DNA glycosylase. This results in
 the removal of the defective base uracil. An
 endonuclease cuts the backbone of DNA strand
 near the defect and removes a few bases. The
 gap so created is filled up by the action of repair
 DNA polymerase and DNA ligase.(Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Tenth Edition - Pg no : 646)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: Which enzyme actively enhances DNA strand separation during replication?
questions.ref_book:
These enzymes bind to both
 the DNA strands at the replication fork.
 Helicases move along the DNA helix and
 separate the strands. Their function is
 comparable with a zip opener. Helicases are
 dependent on ATP for energy supply.(Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Tenth Edition - Pg no : 640)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: DNA synthesis extent can be determined by measuring incorporation of radio labeled:
questions.ref_book: (Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Seventh Edition - Pg no : 581)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: True regarding DNA structure:
questions.option_a: The double helical structure is stabilised by covalent bonds
questions.option_b: The individual strands are stabilized by 5'3' phosphodiester linkage
questions.option_c: The individual strands are stabilized by 3'5' phosphodiester linkage
questions.option_d: The term 5' end indicates that the 5' end is linked to kinetochore
questions.ref_book: DNA is a polymer of deoxyribonucleoside phosphated covalently linked by 3'5' phosphodiester bonds. The double helical structure is stabilised by hydrogen bonds(Lippincott's illustrated reviews- Biochemistry - Denise R Ferrier- Sixth edition- Pg no : 396)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: Mismatch repair defect causes:
questions.ref_book: Sometimes replication errors escape proff reading function during DNA synthesis, causing mismatch of one to several bases. The cells are efficient enough to identify it and the repair systems involve recognition of damage and correct it.(Lippincott's illustrated reviews- Biochemistry - Denise R Ferrier- Sixth edition- Pg no : 411)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: The backbone of a DNA strand is composed of:
questions.ref_book:
Each strand of DNA has a hydrophilic
 deoxyribose phosphate backbone (3-5 phospho
 diester bonds) on the outside (periphery) of the
 molecule while the hydrophobic bases are
 stacked inside (core).(Lippincott's illustrated reviews- Biochemistry - Denise R Ferrier- Sixth edition- Pg no : 396)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: Most common error in DNA:
questions.ref_book:
Damage to DNA caused by
 replication errors or mutations may have serious
 consequences. The cell possesses an inbuilt
 system to repair the damaged DNA. This may
 be achieved by four distinct mechanisms
 1. Base excision-repair
 2. Nucleotide excision-repair
 3. Mismatch repair
 4. Double-strand break repair.(Biochemistry -  U Sathyanarayana- Fourth edition. Pg no : 537)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: Drug inhibiting DNA replication in prokaryotes:
questions.ref_book:
Bacteria contain a specific type II
 topoisomerase namely gyrase. This enzyme cuts
 and reseals the circular DNA (of bacteria), and
 thus overcomes the problem of supercoils.
 Bacterial gyrase is inhibited by the antibiotics
 ciprofloxacin, novobiocin and nalidixic acid.
 These are widely used as antibacterial agents(Biochemistry -  U Sathyanarayana- Fourth edition. Pg no : 528)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: Codon consists of:
questions.ref_book: A triplet sequence of nucleotides on the m RNA is known as codon. Each codon codes for a specific aminoacid. There are totally 64 codons out of which 3 codons UAA,UAG,UGA are stop codons which doesnot code for any aminoacids and stops the translation process.(Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Seventh Edition - Pg no : 599)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: Diphtheria toxin inhibits:
questions.ref_book: Diptheria toxin liberated by corynebacterium diptheria causes inactivation of Elongation factor 2 and consequent  inhibition of translation process in mammalian cells.(Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Seventh Edition - Pg no : 605)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: Stop codon:
questions.ref_book: A triplet sequence of nucleotides on the m RNA is known as codon. Each codon codes for a specific aminoacid. There are totally 64 codons out of which 3 codons UAA,UAG,UGA are stop codons which doesnot code for any aminoacids and stops the translation process.(Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Seventh Edition - Pg no : 599)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: Lac A in lac operon codes for
questions.ref_book:
The lac operon consists of a
 regulatory gene (I; I for inhibition), operator gene
 (O) and three structural genes (Z, Y, A). Besides
 these genes, there is a promoter site (P), next to
 the operator gene, where the enzyme RNA
 polymerase binds. The structural genes Z, Y
 and A respectively, code for the enzymes-beta galactosidase, galactoside permease and
 thiogalactoside transacetylase. (Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Tenth Edition - Pg no : 684)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: Methotrexate inhibits cells in which part of the cell cycle?
questions.ref_book:
Majority of the drugs used for cancer therapy
 are designed to block DNA replication or inhibit
 the enzymes that participate in replication
 (directly or indirectly). Methotrexate (inhibits
 dihydrofolate reductase) and 5-fluorouracil
 (inhibits thymidylate synthase) block nucleotide
 synthesis(Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Tenth Edition - Pg no : 680)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: The mutation seen in sickle cell anemia is
questions.ref_book:
The changed base may code for a different amino
 acid. For example, UCA codes for serine while
 ACA codes for threonine. The mistaken (or missense) amino acid may be acceptable,partially acceptable or unacceptable with regard to the function of protein molecule. Sickle-cell anemia is a classical example of missense.mutation.(Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Tenth Edition - Pg no : 677)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: Absent histone in a nucleosome:
questions.ref_book:
The DNA double helix is wrapped around the
 core proteins namely histones which are basic in
 nature. The core is composed of two molecules
 of histones (H2A, H2B, H3 and H4). Each core
 with two turns of DNA wrapped round it
 (approximately with 150 bp) is termed as a
 nucleosome, the basic unit of chromatin.(Biochemistry -  U Sathyanarayana- Fourth edition. Pg no : 79)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: Left handed helix seen in:
questions.ref_book:
The Z-form (Z-DNA) is a left-handed helix
 and contains 12 base pairs per turn. The polynucleotide strands of DNA move in a
 somewhat ?zig zag' fashion, hence the name
 Z-DNA.(Biochemistry -  U Sathyanarayana- Fourth edition. Pg no : 76)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: Structure in tRNA where an amino acid is attached:
questions.ref_book: The acceptor arm : This arm is capped with a sequence CCA (5 to 3 ). The amino acid is attached to the acceptor arm.(Biochemistry -  U Sathyanarayana- Fourth edition. Pg no : 81)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: The amino acid is attached to which arm of tRNA
questions.ref_book: The acceptor arm : This arm is capped with a sequence CCA (5 to 3 ). The amino acid is attached to the acceptor arm.(Biochemistry -  U Sathyanarayana- Fourth edition. Pg no : 81)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: Purine bases exclude:
questions.ref_book: Uracil is a pyrimidine base. The major purine bases are adenine and guanine and the minor purine bases are hypoxamthine, xanthine and uric acid.(Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Seventh Edition - Pg no : 560)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: Linkage present in a nucleoside:
questions.ref_book: Nucleosides are formed when the bases are attached to pentose sugar. The attachment is between the 1st carbon of pentose sugar with N9 of purine or N1 of pyrimidine(Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Seventh Edition - Pg no : 560)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY

questions.option_d: High activity of PRPP amido transferase
questions.ref_book: The causes of primary hyperuricemia includes abnormal 5-Phosphoribosyl amidotransferase, Abnormally active PRPP synthetase, deficiency of enzymes of salvage pathway and Glucose 6 phosphatase deficiency.(Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Seventh Edition - Pg no : 567)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que:
A 42-year-old male patient undergoing radiation therapy for prostate cancer develops severe
pain in the metatarsal phalangeal joint of his right big toe. Monosodiumurate crystals are
detected by polarized light microscopy in fluid obtained from this joint by arthrocentesis. Uric
acid crystals are present in his urine. This patient's pain is directly caused by the over
production of the end product of which of the following metabolic pathways?
questions.ref_book: Purine degradation results in formation of Uric acid. Overproduction of uric acid leads to its accumulation in joints causes severe pain and the disorder is known as gout.(Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Seventh Edition - Pg no : 567)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: Orotic aciduria due to deficiency of which enzyme:
questions.ref_book: Orotic aciduria is the disorder of pyrimidine metabolism due to deficiency of OPRTase and OMP decarboxylase enzyme.(Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Seventh Edition - Pg no : 571)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: The source of N3 and N9 for synthesis of purine nucleotide is
questions.ref_book:
N1 of purine is derived from amino group
 of aspartate.C2 and C8 arise from formate of N10
formyl THF. N3 and N9 are obtained from amide group
 of glutamine. C4, C5 and N7 are contributed by glycine.
 C6 directly comes from CO2.(Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Tenth Edition - Pg no : 622)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: The most used plasmid vector is
questions.ref_book:
pBR322- the most common plasmid vector :
 pBR322 of E.coli is the most popular and widely
 used plasmid vector, and is appropriately regarded
 as the parent or grand parent of several other
 vectors.pBR322 has a DNA sequence of 4,361 bp. It
 carries genes resistance for ampicillin (Ampr) and
 tetracycline (Tetr) that serve as markers for the
 identification of clones carrying plasmids.(Biochemistry -  U Sathyanarayana- Fourth edition. Pg no : 582)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: Reverse transcriptase among the options:
questions.ref_book:
Telomeres are the special structures that
 prevent the continuous loss of DNA at the end
 of the chromosomes during the course of
 replication. Thus, they protect the ends of
 the chromosomes, and are also responsible
 to prevent the chromosomes from fusing with
 each other. Telomeres are many repeat
 sequences of six nucleotides present at the
 ends of eukaryotic chromosomes. (Biochemistry -  U Sathyanarayana- Fourth edition. Pg no : 530)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: True about transcription:
questions.option_a: The two strands of DNA are transcribed simultaneously
questions.option_c: RNA polymerase needs the template strand in 5' to 3' direction
questions.option_d: RNA polymerase synthesises the primary transcript in 5' to 3' direction
questions.ref_book:
RNA is synthesized from 5' end to 3' end (5' 3')
 antiparallel to the DNA template. RNA
 polymerase utilizes ribonucleotide triphosphates
 (ATP, GTP, CTP and UTP) for the formation of
 RNA. (Biochemistry -  U Sathyanarayana- Fourth edition. Pg no : 544)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: Amino acid not following degeneracy of codon:
questions.ref_book:
Most of the amino acids have
 more than one codon. The codon is degenerate
 or redundant, since there are 61 codons
 available to code for only 20 amino acids. For
 instance, glycine has four codons. (Biochemistry -  U Sathyanarayana- Fourth edition. Pg no : 551)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY

questions.ref_book:
The binding of the enzyme RNA polymerase
 to DNA is the prerequisite for the transcription to
 start. The specific region on the DNA where the
 enzyme binds is known as promoter region.
 There are two base sequences on the coding
 DNA strand which the sigma factor of RNA
 polymerase can recognize for initiation of
 transcription (Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Tenth Edition - Pg no : 653)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: Chaperone plays a role in
questions.ref_book:
Chaperonesare heat shock proteins (originally discovered in response to heat shock). They facilitate
 and favour the interactions on the
 polypeptide surfaces to finally give the
 specific conformation of a protein.
 Chaperones can reversibly bind to
 hydrophobic regions of unfolded proteins and
 folding intermediates. They can stabilize
 intermediates, prevent formation of
 incorrect intermediates, and also prevent
 undesirable interactions with other proteins.(Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Tenth Edition - Pg no : 665)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: Denaturation of DNA not done by:
questions.ref_book:
Denaturation of DNA means separation of the two strands by breaking hydrogen bonds between base pairs.

Increasing temperature ? ? causes denaturation (heat breaks H-bonds).

Decreasing salt concentration ? ? promotes denaturation (less shielding of negative charges on phosphate backbone, more repulsion).

Formamide ? ? promotes denaturation (disrupts H-bonds).

Increasing salt concentration ? ? does not denature DNA; in fact, it stabilizes the double helix by shielding negative phosphate charges.

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: Fidelity of gene is conferred by
questions.ref_book:
Aminoacyl tRNA synthetases are enzymes that attach the correct amino acid to its corresponding tRNA.

This step is crucial for translational fidelity - if the wrong amino acid is attached, the ribosome will insert the wrong residue into the growing polypeptide chain, even if the mRNA codon is correct.

These enzymes have proofreading activity to ensure the correct amino acid-tRNA pairing.

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: The template strand is GGCTATAT. What is the RNA sequence?
questions.ref_book:
To get the RNA sequence from a template strand, we follow these steps:

Complementary base pairing rules (DNA ? RNA):

G ? C

C ? G

T ? A

A ? U

Write the complementary RNA sequence to the template strand in the 5? ? 3? direction.

Template strand: 3?-GGCTATAT-5?

Complementary RNA: 5?-CCGAUAUA-3?

Correct asswer is : CCGAUAUA

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: C2 of pyrimidine ring is donated by
questions.ref_book:
For "C2 of pyrimidine ring is donated by" among your given options, the correct answer is:

? Carbon dioxide

Explanation:

In pyrimidine synthesis, the C2 atom (and N3) come from carbamoyl phosphate.

The carbon in carbamoyl phosphate is derived from CO? (carbon dioxide) via the action of carbamoyl phosphate synthetase II.

The folate derivatives you listed (N5,N10-methylene THFA, N10-formyl THFA, N5,N10-methenyl THFA) are used in purine and thymidylate synthesis, not for C2 of pyrimidines.

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que:
A 56-year-old woman with no known medical conditions presents to the emergency
room with pain in the upper arm. She denies any trauma; however, a fracture of the
humerus is found on radiograph. She is found to have an elevated PTH level. Which
of the following statements best describes PTH?
questions.ref_book:
PTH increases the Ca
 reabsorption by kidney tubules. This is the most
 rapid action of PTH to elevate blood Ca levels.
 However, quantitatively, this is less important
 compared to the action of PTH on bone.
 PTH promotes the production of calcitriol
 (1,25 DHCC) in the kidney by stimulating
 1-hydroxylation of 25-hydroxycholecalciferol.(Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Tenth Edition - Pg no : 562)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: Selenium is a cofactor in which enzyme?
questions.ref_book: Glutathione peroxidase is the important selenium containing enzyme(Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Tenth Edition - Pg no : 577)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: The vitamin needed for oxidative decarboxylation of alpha keto acids is
questions.ref_book: The active form of Vitamin B1 is Thiamine Pyrophosphate (TPP).  The main physiological role of TPP is , its action as a coenzyme in Pyruvate dehydrogenase and alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex enzymes and involved in oxidative decarboxylation of alpha ketoacids such as pyruvate and alpha ketoglutarate respectively.(Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Seventh Edition - Pg no : 477)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: The Vitamin needed for Transamination reactions is
questions.ref_book: The active form of Vitamin B6 is Pyridoxal phosphate (PLP).  The main physiological role of PLP is , its action as a coenzyme in trnsamination reaction, decarboxylation of aminoacids and also involved in metabolism of sulphur- containing aminoacids(Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Seventh Edition - Pg no : 482)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: The vitamin that is necessary for hydroxylation of Proline and Lysine is
questions.ref_book: Ascorbic acid is essential for post-translational hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues. Hydroxy proline and hydroxy lysine are necessary for the formation of cross-links in collagen, which gives tensile strength to the fibres.(Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Seventh Edition - Pg no : 496)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: Barlow's disease is due to deficiency of
questions.ref_book: Barlow's disease also known as Infantile Scurvy is due to deficiency of vitamin C. In infants during weaning period (6months - 12 months), supplementation of vitamin C is very essential.(Textbook of Biochemistry - DM.VASUDEVAN. Seventh Edition - Pg no : 497)

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que:
A 26-year-old woman meets with her family physician to discuss family planning. She is
interested in starting a family soon and is looking for advice on what nutritional supplements
would be beneficial during pregnancy. The physician suggests which two of the following
supplements as being the most important for the health of the fetus?
questions.ref_book: During pregnancy, folic acid supplementation prevents neural tube defects, while iron prevents maternal anemia and supports increased blood volume and fetal growth. These are the two most important and universally recommended supplements for fetal and maternal health

questions.subject: BIOCHEMISTRY
questions.que: All of the following lead to hypernatremia EXCEPT:
questions.ref_book:
Hypernatremia = serum sodium >145 mEq/L, usually due to water loss > sodium loss or excess sodium gain.

Vomiting and diarrhea ? ? Can cause hypernatremia (water loss exceeds sodium loss in some cases).

Burns ? ? Can cause hypernatremia (loss of hypotonic fluid from damaged skin).

Cushing's syndrome ? ? Can cause hypernatremia (excess cortisol ? mineralocorticoid effect ? sodium retention).

Addison's disease ? ? Causes hyponatremia (aldosterone deficiency ? sodium loss).

Answer: ? Addison's disease

questions.subject: COMMUNITY MEDICINE
questions.que: Cluster testing is useful in detecting cases of
questions.ref_book: Cluster testing refers to the epidemiological strategy where testing is focused on a group (or "cluster") of individuals in close contact with a confirmed case. It is particularly useful in detecting outbreaks of infectious diseases like measles, which spread rapidly in clusters such as households, schools, or communities. This method helps in early detection, containment, and vaccination response during measles outbreaks

questions.ref_book: The Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act, 2012 was passed by Parliament in June 2012 and received Presidential assent on 19th June 2012. It was officially notified and brought into force on 14th November 2012 (Children's Day), symbolically chosen to emphasize child protection.

questions.option_b: Tactile hallucination seen in chronic cocaine poisoning
questions.ref_book: The Essentials Of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology by  K S Narayan Reddy 35th Edition Page No : 459

questions.subject: FORENSIC MEDICINE
questions.que: Hippus is seen in poisoning with
questions.ref_book: The Essentials Of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology by  K S Narayan Reddy 35th Edition Page No : 472

questions.subject: FORENSIC MEDICINE
questions.que: In cyanide poisoning not used is
questions.ref_book:
Amyl nitrite - used (inhaled) to produce methemoglobin, which binds cyanide.

Oxygen - given as supportive therapy (though ineffective alone, it helps after antidotes).

Thiocyanate - not given directly, but cyanide is detoxified into thiocyanate (with sodium thiosulfate as sulfur donor). So this is part of the detoxification pathway.

BAL (Dimercaprol) - contraindicated because it forms toxic complexes with cyanide and worsens the poisoning.

?? Hence, the only one not used is BAL. (The Essentials Of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology by  K S Narayan Reddy 35th Edition Page No : 478)

questions.subject: FORENSIC MEDICINE
questions.que: Pupils are constricted in the following poisoning EXCEPT
questions.ref_book:
Carbolic acid (phenol): Causes miosis (constricted pupils) due to CNS depression.

Organophosphorus compounds: Produce pinpoint pupils (miosis) due to excessive cholinergic stimulation.

Morphine (opioid): Classic cause of pinpoint pupils due to parasympathetic overactivity.

Organochloride compounds (DDT, aldrin, dieldrin, etc.): Typically cause mydriasis (dilated pupils) along with tremors, convulsions, and CNS hyperexcitability, not constricted pupils.

questions.subject: FORENSIC MEDICINE
questions.que: All are true about atropine poisoning, except
questions.ref_book:
Atropine is an anticholinergic drug. In poisoning, it causes parasympathetic blockade leading to the classical picture:

Dilated pupils (mydriasis) ? due to paralysis of sphincter pupillae.

Dysarthria & Dysphagia ? from dryness of mouth, throat, and difficulty in swallowing/speaking.

Hyperthermia (increased temperature) ? because atropine inhibits sweating, leading to heat retention

questions.subject: FORENSIC MEDICINE
questions.que: Urine appears 'liquid gold' in which poisoning
questions.ref_book: In arsenic poisoning, the urine may appear like "liquid gold" due to the presence of sulphydryl compounds and arsenic metabolites that give it a characteristic golden-yellow appearance.

questions.subject: FORENSIC MEDICINE
questions.que: Sweet poison is
questions.ref_book: Cerbera thevetia, commonly called Yellow Oleander, is known as the "Sweet Poison" because of its deceptively pleasant-tasting seeds.

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Drug contraindicated in breast feeding
questions.ref_book: Among the drugs listed, methotrexate is explicitly contraindicated during breastfeeding due to its potential for serious toxicity, including immunosuppression and hepatotoxicity in the infant.(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1274)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Adverse drug reactions account for up to what percentage of admissions in geriatric patients?
questions.ref_book: Adverse drug reactions (ADRs) are a major contributor to hospital admissions in elderly patients, accounting for up to 20% (Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1307)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Which is a pre-renal cause of acute kidney injury in pregnancy?
questions.ref_book: Septic abortion is listed as a pre-renal cause of AKI in pregnancy because systemic infection and inflammation can lead to hypovolemia and reduced renal perfusion. This results in a functional drop in glomerular filtration without direct injury to the kidney parenchyma-hallmarks of pre-renal AKI. In contrast, pre-eclampsia, TTP, and acute fatty liver of pregnancy are classified under renal causes due to their intrinsic effects on renal vasculature, glomeruli, or tubules(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1277)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: First-line investigation for suspected pulmonary embolism in pregnancy with a normal chest X-ray?
questions.ref_book: For pregnant patients with suspected pulmonary embolism (PE) and a normal chest X-ray, a V/Q scan is preferred because it has lower radiation to maternal breast tissue than CTPA. If the chest X-ray is abnormal, CTPA is chosen due to clearer visualization of pathology.(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1268)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: SLE in pregnancy with proteinuria
questions.ref_book: In a pregnant woman with SLE, new-onset proteinuria can result from either lupus flare or pre-eclampsia. However, additional features like presence of urinary red cell casts, rising anti-dsDNA, and falling complement levels (C3, C4) indicate a lupus flare(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1277)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: The 4A test is used in the assessment of
questions.ref_book:
The 4A Test (4AT) is a validated bedside tool used for rapid screening of delirium. It assesses alertness, orientation, attention, and evidence of acute change. A score ?4 is suggestive of delirium, especially useful in elderly inpatients with fluctuating mental status.
(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1305)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: About 65% of filtered sodium is reabsorbed in
questions.option_c: Ascending Limb of Loop of Henle
questions.option_d: Descending Limb of Loop of Henle
questions.ref_book: The majority of sodium reabsorption (about 65%) occurs in the proximal convoluted tubule. This segment of the nephron is responsible for reabsorbing sodium along with water and other solutes, making it essential for volume and electrolyte regulation. The thick ascending limb reabsorbs about 25%, and the distal tubule and collecting duct together handle the remaining 10%(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 617)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: 'U' wave in ECG is a feature of
questions.ref_book: Hypokalemia characteristically produces prominent U waves on ECG, especially in the precordial leads. These waves follow the T wave and represent delayed repolarization of the Purkinje fibers. Hyperkalemia, by contrast, leads to peaked T waves and eventually to QRS widening and sine-wave patterns(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 628)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Cause of Euvolemic Hyponatremia?
questions.ref_book: Hypothyroidism is a recognized cause of euvolemic hyponatremia, typically via reduced cardiac output or inappropriate ADH secretion. Other causes include SIADH and polydipsia. In contrast, diuretics, adrenal failure, and burns are typically hypovolemic causes.(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 624)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Which drug causes Hyperkalemic Distal Renal Tubular Acidosis?
questions.ref_book: Amiloride, a potassium-sparing diuretic, causes type IV RTA by blocking sodium channels and reducing aldosterone sensitivity, leading to hyperkalemia and impaired acid secretion. Other drugs include spironolactone and calcineurin inhibitors(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 632)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Which one of the following is a cause of Secondary Hypercholesterolaemia?
questions.ref_book: Hypothyroidism is a well-recognized and moderately common cause of secondary hypercholesterolaemia, due to reduced clearance of LDL cholesterol. It differs from conditions like chronic renal disease, hepatocellular disease, and abdominal obesity, which are listed under causes of secondary hypertriglyceridaemia, not hypercholesterolaemia(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 638)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Syncope is not a feature of
questions.ref_book: Syncope, or transient loss of consciousness, is a recognized symptom in several cardiovascular conditions, including aortic stenosis, where it typically occurs on exertion due to fixed cardiac output; massive myocardial infarction, where it results from acute pump failure or arrhythmia; and atrial myxoma, where mechanical obstruction of the mitral valve or embolism can lead to syncope. However, in mitral regurgitation, the hallmark features include dyspnea, fatigue, and pulmonary edema, but syncope is not a characteristic symptom. Hence, mitral regurgitation is the correct answer(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 459)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: First heart sound is soft in
questions.ref_book: A soft first heart sound (S1) is heard in conditions where the mitral valve closes poorly due to weak ventricular contraction, such as in heart failure. In contrast, S1 is typically loud in mitral stenosis and hyperdynamic states like anaemia and pregnancy(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 400)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: All are features of infective Endocarditis except
questions.ref_book: Infective endocarditis commonly presents with peripheral signs such as petechiae, digital clubbing, and splenomegaly, especially in subacute or long-standing cases. These features are either due to embolic phenomena or immune complex deposition. Clubbing and splenomegaly are documented signs in chronic presentations, while petechiae are frequently seen in both acute and subacute forms. However, hepatomegaly is not a characteristic feature of infective endocarditis(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 464)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Which is true about Ventricular Tachycardia?
questions.ref_book: Atrioventricular (AV) dissociation is a hallmark of ventricular tachycardia (VT) and is considered pathognomonic. VT typically presents with broad QRS complexes and does not respond to carotid massage or adenosine, distinguishing it from supraventricular tachycardias(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 417)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Which microorganism is not included in the HACEK organisms?
questions.ref_book: The HACEK group includes Haemophilus (now Aggregatibacter), Actinobacillus (now part of Aggregatibacter), Cardiobacterium, Eikenella, and Kingella. These are all Gram-negative organisms that commonly inhabit the oropharynx and are known to cause endocarditis. Staphylococcus aureus, although a major cause of acute infective endocarditis, is not part of the HACEK group(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 464)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Which of the following is not seen in Eisenmenger's syndrome
questions.ref_book:
Eisenmenger syndrome is a late complication of a long-standing large left-to-right shunt (e.g., VSD, PDA) that leads to irreversible pulmonary vascular remodeling and pulmonary hypertension, ultimately reversing the shunt to right-to-left. It features:

Central or differential cyanosis

Elevated pulmonary vascular resistance

Presence of an intra-cardiac communication (e.g., VSD, ASD, PDA)

However, pulmonary stenosis is not a feature-it is actually a cause of cyanosis in Tetralogy of Fallot(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 470)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: All the following drugs have anti-arrhythmic property except
questions.ref_book: Amiodarone (Class III), Atenolol (Class II ?-blocker), and Diltiazem (Class IV calcium channel blocker) are all established anti-arrhythmic agents used to treat various types of arrhythmias. Amlodipine, however, is a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker used mainly for hypertension and angina due to its vasodilatory effect. It does not possess significant anti-arrhythmic properties and is not classified as an anti-arrhythmic drug(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 430)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Serum Troponin is not elevated in
questions.ref_book: Cardiac troponins are released during myocardial injury and can be elevated in various conditions including heart failure, renal failure, and severe burns. However, subdural haemorrhage typically does not involve cardiac muscle damage, so troponin levels remain normal, distinguishing it from other critical systemic or cardiac conditions(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 393)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: In heart failure, aldosterone secretion is elevated due to
questions.ref_book: In heart failure, aldosterone secretion is increased due to multiple mechanisms. These include increased secretion triggered by renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) activation, prolongation of aldosterone's biological half-life, and reduced hepatic clearance resulting from hepatic congestion. All these contribute to elevated aldosterone levels, which in turn exacerbate fluid retention, potassium loss, and progression of heart failure(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 403)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: The commonest valve affected in Rheumatic Heart Disease is
questions.ref_book: The mitral valve is most commonly affected in rheumatic heart disease, typically presenting as mitral stenosis. The pathological process involves progressive fibrosis and calcification of the valve apparatus. Aortic and tricuspid valves may also be involved but far less frequently than the mitral valve(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 451)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: P-pulmonale in ECG is seen in
questions.ref_book: P-pulmonale refers to tall, peaked P waves on ECG, which signify right atrial enlargement. This is a hallmark of chronic lung disease affecting the heart, such as in cor pulmonale, where pulmonary hypertension from chronic lung pathology causes right atrial and ventricular strain. Hydropneumothorax, pleural effusion, and tuberculosis may show secondary effects on ECG but do not specifically cause P-pulmonale(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 402)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Which is not a feature of Benign/Innocent Heart Murmur?
questions.ref_book: Benign or innocent murmurs are soft, mid-systolic, and non-radiating, usually heard best at the left sternal border. Murmurs that radiate (e.g., to the neck or axilla) are typically pathological, such as those from valvular lesions like aortic stenosis or mitral regurgitation(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 400)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Which of the following is a cause of Left Bundle Branch Block
questions.ref_book: Hypertension is a recognized structural cause of Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB). It leads to left ventricular hypertrophy, which can interfere with the conduction system.(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 412)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Heart failure due to Diastolic Dysfunction is caused by
questions.ref_book: Cardiac tamponade causes diastolic heart failure by restricting ventricular filling due to pressure from accumulated pericardial fluid. This leads to poor preload, reduced stroke volume, and hypotension. Other conditions like myocarditis, pulmonary hypertension, and ASD affect different aspects of heart function but are not primary causes of diastolic dysfunction(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 403)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Sacubitril is,
questions.ref_book: Sacubitril inhibits neprilysin (neutral endopeptidase), which breaks down natriuretic peptides like ANP and BNP. It's used in combination with valsartan in heart failure. It is not an ACE inhibitor or calcium channel blocker(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 407)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: With hand grip exercise, murmur due to which condition DECREASES in intensity
questions.ref_book: In HOCM, the outflow tract obstruction is dynamic and worsens with reduced preload or afterload. Hand grip increases afterload, which reduces the obstruction, hence the murmur becomes softer. In contrast, murmurs of AR, MR, and VSD become louder due to increased regurgitant/left-to-right flow

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: For patients with ST-segment elevation Myocardial Infarction (STEMI), Fibrinolysis should ideally be initiated within
questions.ref_book: In STEMI management, timely reperfusion is critical. If primary PCI is unavailable within 120 minutes, fibrinolysis should be initiated within 30 minutes of hospital arrival ("door-to-needle" time). Delays reduce myocardial salvage and increase mortality(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 437)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Shagreen patches are classically seen in
questions.ref_book: Shagreen patches are distinctive skin lesions composed of connective tissue naevi that appear as thickened, leathery, and irregularly textured plaques, typically located on the lower back. They are a hallmark cutaneous feature of tuberous sclerosis(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1114)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Nicolsky's sign is typically positive in
questions.ref_book: Nikolsky's sign, which refers to epidermal detachment upon gentle lateral pressure, is typically positive in pemphigus(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1107)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: White frontal forelock is found in
questions.ref_book: The characteristic white frontal forelock is a hallmark feature of Piebaldism, a rare autosomal dominant congenital disorder of melanocyte development. It typically presents with a localized patch of white hair at birth, most often over the frontal scalp, due to a localized absence of melanocytes.

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Pitting nail is found in all except
questions.ref_book: Pitting of the nails refers to small depressions on the nail surface and is characteristically seen in conditions like psoriasis, eczema, and alopecia areata. It results from defective keratinization of the proximal nail matrix. However, urticaria is a transient dermal hypersensitivity reaction and does not involve the nail matrix, hence does not cause nail pitting. Therefore, urticaria is the correct answer as the exception(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1109)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: A circumscribed flat area of color change ?1 cm in diameter is termed as?
questions.ref_book: A macule is a flat, non-palpable lesion with a change in skin color, less than or equal to 1 cm in diameter. If it exceeds 1 cm, it's termed a patch. Papules are raised, petechiae are pinpoint hemorrhages, and purpura are larger hemorrhagic lesions. Thus, the correct term is macule(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1065)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Fir-tree pattern on the trunk is seen in?
questions.ref_book: The classic ?fir tree' distribution on the trunk is a hallmark of pityriasis rosea, especially following the appearance of a herald patch. The pattern is due to alignment along skin tension lines. It helps distinguish pityriasis rosea from psoriasis, eczema, or lichen planus, which have different morphologies and distributions(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1071)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Causes of localized pruritus include?
questions.ref_book: Pediculosis (lice infestation) causes localized itching, especially in areas like the scalp, pubic region, or body folds depending on the species. Other listed conditions like urticaria and psoriasis typically produce generalized pruritus, not localized(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1072)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: A 30 year old woman came with flaccid bullae on her skin which were easy to rupture. Biopsy of the lesion revealed a suprabasal split. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.ref_book: Pemphigus vulgaris is characterized by flaccid bullae that rupture easily and show a suprabasal split on biopsy due to antibodies against desmogleins. It distinguishes from pemphigus foliaceus (more superficial), pemphigus vegetans (rare vegetating form), and erythema multiforme (target lesions without bullae)(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1106)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Erythema Nodosum is an example of
questions.ref_book: Erythema nodosum is a septal panniculitis, meaning inflammation of subcutaneous fat lobules, not of blood vessels (vasculitis) or the dermis (erythroderma). It commonly presents as tender red nodules on the shins and is often associated with systemic illnesses or infections(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1114)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Cause of acquired vesicular blister
questions.ref_book: Eczema herpeticum is a vesicular blistering condition caused by herpes simplex virus, often seen in individuals with pre-existing eczema. It is an acquired and potentially severe viral infection distinguished from other blistering diseases like erythema multiforme or lupus, which do not characteristically present with vesicles(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1072)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Insulin is secreted by
questions.ref_book: Insulin is produced by Beta-cells in the islets of Langerhans in the pancreas. These cells account for about 70% of islet cell population. In contrast, Alpha-cells produce glucagon, Delta-cells produce somatostatin, and PP cells secrete pancreatic polypeptide(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 707)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: A cause of Hypoxaemia due to Ventilation-Perfusion Mismatch?
questions.ref_book: Ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) mismatch occurs when regions of the lung receive oxygen but not enough blood flow, or vice versa. In acute exacerbation of asthma, bronchoconstriction causes under-ventilated alveoli while perfusion continues, leading to areas of low V/Q ratio and hypoxaemia. This distinguishes it from causes of shunt, like lung collapse or alveolar haemorrhage, and aspiration, which typically result in alveolar filling and true shunting rather than mismatch(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 196)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Which vasoactive agent has inotropic & chronotropic actions but no vasoconstrictor action?
questions.ref_book: Dobutamine is a ?1-adrenergic agonist with strong inotropic and chronotropic effects, making it highly effective at increasing cardiac output in conditions such as cardiogenic shock or heart failure. Importantly, unlike agents like epinephrine, norepinephrine, or vasopressin, dobutamine does not exert vasoconstrictive effects. In fact, it may cause mild vasodilation, which distinguishes it as the drug of choice when inotropy is needed without increasing systemic vascular resistance(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 210)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: One of the following is a Diethyl Organophosphorus compound
questions.ref_book: Among the listed compounds, Chlorpyrifos is classified as a diethyl organophosphorus insecticide. This classification is important because the rate of "ageing" of the enzyme-inhibitor complex in organophosphate poisoning varies with structure: diethyl compounds like chlorpyrifos have a slower ageing rate compared to dimethyl compounds like dichlorvos, malathion, and methamidophos. This has implications for the timing and effectiveness of antidotes such as oximes(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 232)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Catecholamine storm-like syndrome is classically seen after
questions.ref_book: A catecholamine storm-like syndrome, featuring symptoms such as tachycardia, hypertension or hypotension, profuse sweating, salivation, and potentially cardiac dysfunction and pulmonary oedema, is classically seen in scorpion stings. The neurotoxic venom triggers excessive stimulation of the autonomic nervous system. This is distinct from bee or wasp stings, which primarily cause allergic (anaphylactic) reactions, and snake bites, which have diverse effects but typically do not trigger a catecholamine storm(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 249)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Core Temperature between 28-32?C corresponds to which stage of Hypothermia?
questions.ref_book: According to standard classification, a core temperature between 28-32?C defines moderate hypothermia, also referred to as Stage II in the Swiss Staging System. This stage typically presents with drowsiness and absence of shivering(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 253)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: All are primary headache except
questions.ref_book: Migraine, tension-type headache, and cluster headache are all classified as primary headache disorders, which occur without an identifiable structural cause. In contrast, temporal arteritis (a manifestation of giant cell arteritis) is a secondary cause of headache, resulting from an inflammatory vascular disease. It typically presents in older adults and may lead to visual loss if untreated. Therefore, temporal arteritis is not a primary headache syndrome, making it the correct exception(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 186)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: The clinical manifestations of anaphylaxis include
questions.ref_book: Anaphylaxis is a life-threatening hypersensitivity reaction presenting with multiple symptoms including urticaria, hypotension, and wheeze. All listed options are correct and commonly seen during anaphylactic episodes due to the systemic release of histamine and other mediators(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 183)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Symptoms of abdominal pain, ptosis, and flaccid paralysis in a farmer are most likely due to
questions.ref_book: A classic presentation of krait bite includes abdominal pain, bilateral ptosis, and flaccid paralysis with minimal or no local signs. Bites often occur at night when victims are asleep on the ground, making them less likely to notice the bite until systemic symptoms develop(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 244)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Which organ demonstrates significant changes in response to cold, similar to hemorrhage/sepsis?
questions.ref_book: Exposure to cold leads to sympathetic activation causing vasoconstriction. The kidneys exhibit the most significant reduction in blood flow, mimicking changes seen in haemorrhagic shock or sepsis, thus affecting filtration and fluid balance.(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 252)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: A 50-year-old patient presented to the Emergency Room with hypotension. On examination, his peripheries were warm with a high-volume pulse and low venous pressure. The probable cause among the following:
questions.ref_book: Allergic shock (anaphylaxis) is a high-output circulatory failure with warm extremities, bounding pulse, and low CVP due to vasodilation from histamine release. It contrasts with cold extremities seen in hypovolemic or cardiogenic shock(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 196)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Red Flag symptoms in headache are all EXCEPT
questions.ref_book: New-onset Headache  aged > 60 years is a redflag(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 187)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: A 25-year-old male, Mr. X, is brought to the Emergency Room with weakness which spread rapidly from ocular muscles to proximal limb muscles and respiratory failure. The patient's bystanders gave a history of Organophosphorus compound ingestion three days back. What is the diagnosis?
questions.ref_book: The patient's symptom pattern-progressive weakness from ocular to respiratory muscles following OP ingestion three days prior-is characteristic of Intermediate Syndrome, a delayed complication of OP poisoning. It typically occurs 1-4 days after exposure, following resolution of the acute cholinergic phase, and may cause respiratory failure requiring ventilatory support. This distinguishes it from the acute cholinergic and delayed neuropathic syndromes(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 233)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Latrodectism is caused by
questions.ref_book: Latrodectism refers to the clinical syndrome caused by envenomation from widow spiders, particularly of the Latrodectus genus. It presents with severe pain, sweating, nausea, and hypertension, starting locally and potentially becoming systemic. It is not caused by scorpion stings, bee stings, or snake bites.(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 249)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Which one of the heat-related illnesses presents with thirst, lethargy, headache, nausea, and normal mental status
questions.ref_book: Heat exhaustion is caused by salt and fluid depletion due to prolonged heat exposure. It typically manifests with symptoms such as thirst, lethargy, headache, and nausea, while mental status remains normal-a key distinction from more severe conditions like heat stroke, which includes neurological impairment. This makes it a self-limiting condition unless progression to heat stroke occurs(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 254)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Q-T prolongation is seen in which drug?
questions.ref_book: Quinidine, a Class Ia antiarrhythmic, significantly prolongs the QT interval by prolonging the action potential. This may lead to torsades de pointes, a potentially fatal ventricular arrhythmia. Amiodarone also prolongs QT but with a lower pro-arrhythmic risk. Lignocaine shortens QT, and magnesium sulfate is used to treat torsades, not cause it.(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 225)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: All the following hormones are stored in secretory granules before release except
questions.ref_book: Steroid hormones (like cortisol, aldosterone, estrogen, testosterone) are not stored in granules. They are synthesized on demand from cholesterol and diffuse through the cell membrane into the blood. In contrast, peptide and protein hormones like insulin, GH, and GnRH are stored in granules and released via exocytosis(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 650)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: A 25-year-old female's thyroid function tests showed TSH - normal, T4 low, T3 low. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.ref_book: When both T3 and T4 are low, but TSH is normal or low, this strongly suggests secondary (central) hypothyroidism, due to failure of TSH production from the pituitary or hypothalamus. In contrast, primary hypothyroidism shows high TSH, and subclinical hypothyroidism shows elevated TSH with normal T4/T3(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 654)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Cause of secondary hyperaldosteronism (renin high and aldosterone high)?
questions.ref_book:
In secondary hyperaldosteronism, both renin and aldosterone are elevated, typically as a compensatory response to low effective blood volume. Diuretic therapy causes intravascular volume depletion, triggering increased renin and aldosterone. In contrast, Liddle syndrome, ectopic ACTH, and liquorice ingestion are associated with low renin states.
(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 687)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que:
A 25-year-old female who is a known hypothyroid patient, is now 6 weeks pregnant.
She is on 50 micrograms of Levothyroxine. What is the dose adjustment needed in this patient?
questions.ref_book: Pregnancy increases thyroxine-binding globulin and metabolic demand. Therefore, levothyroxine dose should be increased by 30-50% early in pregnancy to maintain euthyroidism and prevent fetal neurodevelopmental impairment. Regular TSH monitoring is essential throughout gestation(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 658)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Flapping tremor is a feature of all the following conditions except
questions.ref_book: Asterixis (flapping tremor) is a motor sign seen in metabolic encephalopathies like hepatic, uremic, and CO? narcosis, where there's a temporary lapse in muscle tone. It is not seen in cerebellar disease, which instead presents with features like ataxia, dysmetria, and intention tremor(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 878)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Length of adult esophagus is
questions.ref_book: The adult oesophagus is typically around 25 cm long, beginning at the cricoid cartilage and ending at the cardiac orifice of the stomach. This measurement supports the range of 18-26 cm, accounting for individual variability in height and body size. Hence, among the given options, 18-26 cm is correct(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 784)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
