questions.que: Which hormone secreted by oxyntic glands stimulates acid secretion, appetite, and gastric emptying?
questions.ref_book: Ghrelin is a hormone secreted from oxyntic glands in the stomach. It plays a key role in promoting gastric acid secretion, appetite stimulation, and gastric emptying, making it central to digestive and energy-regulatory processes. Unlike gastrin or histamine, which primarily regulate acid, ghrelin influences appetite and motility as well.(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 785)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: The most common cause of acute severe lower gastrointestinal bleed?
questions.ref_book: Diverticular disease is the leading cause of acute severe lower GI bleeding, often presenting with painless, profuse rectal bleeding. It accounts for two-thirds of such cases, especially in elderly populations. The bleeding is arterial and originates at the neck of a diverticulum. Other causes like angiodysplasia or ischemia are less common(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 800)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: A patient with a history of chronic liver disease presents with abdominal distension, jaundice, and pruritus. Ascitic fluid analysis revealed a neutrophil count >650 per cubic mm. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.ref_book: Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) occurs in patients with cirrhosis and ascites due to bacterial translocation. A neutrophil count >250/mm? in ascitic fluid is diagnostic; this patient had >650/mm?. SBP commonly presents with nonspecific signs like abdominal distension or encephalopathy rather than classic peritonitis features(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 876)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: The feature of Crohn's disease include all except
questions.ref_book: Although Crohn's disease shares many features with ulcerative colitis, bloody diarrhoea is not a typical symptom. Instead, Crohn's patients generally have watery diarrhoea, abdominal pain, weight loss, and extraintestinal symptoms. Other listed features such as skip lesions, granulomas, and increased prevalence in smokers are classical for Crohn's(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 836)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: The commonest indicator of chronic liver disease is
questions.ref_book:
In chronic liver disease, especially cirrhosis, thrombocytopenia is often the earliest haematological abnormality due to hypersplenism and reduced thrombopoietin production. Anaemia and leucopenia may also occur but less commonly or at later stages. Thrombocytosis is rare in liver disease.
(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 867)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Chromosomal translocation in chronic myeloid leukaemia is
questions.ref_book: Chronic myeloid leukaemia (CML) is characterized by the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome, which results from a translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22. This translocation leads to the formation of the BCR-ABL fusion gene, which encodes a protein with constitutive tyrosine kinase activity, driving leukemic cell proliferation(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 967)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Drugs causing haemolysis in G6PD deficiency are all except
questions.ref_book:
In G6PD deficiency, oxidant drugs can precipitate haemolytic anemia. The commonly implicated agents include:

Dapsone (a sulfone antibiotic),

Primaquine (an antimalarial),

Nitrofurantoin (a urinary antiseptic).

Erythromycin, a macrolide antibiotic, is not associated with haemolysis in G6PD-deficient patients and is generally considered safe.(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 958)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: All are features of Iron Deficiency Anemia, except
questions.ref_book:
Iron Deficiency Anemia is characterized by the following laboratory features:

Serum ferritin ? - Ferritin reflects iron stores and is typically low in iron deficiency.

Serum iron ? - Reduced due to decreased availability of iron.

TIBC ? - Increased because the body tries to capture more iron by increasing transferrin (iron-binding protein) capacity.

Microcytic hypochromic anemia - Seen due to defective hemoglobin synthesis from iron deficiency

Thus, the statement "Total iron binding capacity decrease" is incorrect in the context of iron deficiency anemia.(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 953)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: A software engineer presented to OPD with complaints of easy fatiguability, He gives a history of sitting in front of the computer for 12-14 hrs a day and consuming junk food and less fruits and vegetables. CBC picture showed Hb concentration as 7gm%, MCV-120. What is the most likely cause of anemia?
questions.ref_book: This patient has macrocytic anemia (MCV >100 fL) and dietary risk factors-high junk food, low fruits/vegetables-making folate deficiency most likely. It's a common cause of megaloblastic anemia in such lifestyles. Sideroblastic anemia is rare and hemolysis or acute blood loss typically causes normocytic anemia(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 954)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: The clinical features of haemophilia include all except
questions.ref_book: Haemophilia typically causes deep tissue bleeds like haemarthroses and muscle or retroperitoneal haematomas. Bleeding often follows trauma or spontaneously in severe cases. Macular (superficial, flat) bruising, typical of platelet disorders, is not a classical feature of haemophilia, making it the correct exception.(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 923)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Which organism is the most common cause of central venous catheter infection?
questions.ref_book: Coagulase-negative staphylococci (e.g. Staphylococcus epidermidis) are the most common cause of central venous catheter infections. These organisms are skin commensals and frequently contaminate catheter lines during insertion or maintenance(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 271)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: All of the following can cause Infectious Mononucleosis Syndrome EXCEPT
questions.ref_book: The infectious mononucleosis syndrome can be caused by EBV, CMV, HIV-1, HHV-6/7, and Toxoplasmosis. HHV-3 (Varicella zoster virus) is not a cause(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 285)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: The most sensitive test for the diagnosis of HIV is
questions.ref_book: PCR (polymerase chain reaction) detects HIV RNA and is the most sensitive test, especially for diagnosing early infection before antibodies or p24 antigen appear. While ELISA and p24 antigen are used for screening and early detection respectively, PCR surpasses both in sensitivity. Western blot is confirmatory but not more sensitive than PCR(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 355)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Post-Transplant Lymphoproliferative Disorder (PTLD) is associated with
questions.ref_book: PTLD is a serious complication in organ transplant recipients and is most commonly associated with EBV infection. Immunosuppression permits unchecked B-cell proliferation following EBV infection, resulting in a range of lymphoproliferative disorders from benign hyperplasia to aggressive lymphoma(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 270)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que:
A 15 year old boy presented with fever for three days associated with nausea,
vomiting and rashes. He was brought to the hospital in view of persistent
abdominal pain and vomiting. On examination his breath sounds are absent
in Right infra axillary region and hepatomegaly of 3cms with minimal ascites.
His investigations showed a rapid increase in haematocrit with fall in platelet
count. According to the WHO case definition of Dengue he fits to which one of
the following:
questions.ref_book: The boy meets criteria for Dengue with warning signs as per WHO definitions: he has probable dengue features (fever, nausea, rash), persistent vomiting, abdominal pain, hepatomegaly >2 cm, signs of fluid accumulation (pleural effusion and ascites), and a rising haematocrit with falling platelet count. These warning signs suggest plasma leakage but without the circulatory collapse required for a diagnosis of severe dengue or dengue shock syndrom(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 288)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Abdominal distension, splenomegaly, and cough in typhoid are seen by the end of
questions.ref_book: In typhoid fever, signs like abdominal distension, splenomegaly, and cough typically appear toward the end of the first week of illness. If untreated, the condition may worsen in the second week, leading to complications such as delirium and sepsis(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 308)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Tzanck test in negative in
questions.ref_book: The Tzanck test (smear) detects multinucleated giant cells in vesicular fluid, which is typically positive in infections such as Herpes simplex (HSV), Herpes zoster (VZV), and Varicella (chickenpox). However, HIV does not cause vesicular skin lesions showing these cytopathic changes, and the Tzanck test is not used in its diagnosis(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 357)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Which one of the following is a cause of infectious gastroenteritis with more than six hours incubation period
questions.ref_book: Clostridium difficile causes infectious gastroenteritis with a longer incubation period, usually 12-72 hours, especially following antibiotic use. In contrast, Bacillus cereus, Staphylococcus aureus, and other Clostridial enterotoxins lead to toxin-mediated food poisoning with a short incubation (<6 hours). This makes C. difficile the correct option when considering a delayed onset of symptoms(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 272)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: A 15-year-old boy presents to the outpatient department with high-grade fever for six days associated with muscle pain and tenderness, especially in the calf muscles and back, intense headache and photophobia. On examination, he had conjunctival congestion and otherwise unremarkable physical findings. His blood investigations showed a polymorphonuclear leucocytosis with thrombocytopenia. The probable diagnosis is
questions.ref_book: The clinical presentation-fever for 6 days, calf muscle pain, headache, photophobia, conjunctival congestion, and thrombocytopenia with neutrophil predominance-is highly suggestive of leptospirosis. This zoonotic disease commonly occurs in tropical settings and is often underdiagnosed. The presence of conjunctival congestion with muscle tenderness is particularly characteristic. Dengue may share some features but typically presents with leukopenia, not neutrophilia. Malaria and enteric fever usually lack the combination of prominent calf tenderness and conjunctival involvement(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 305)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: A 36 year old woman presents to the STD clinic with complaints of painless ulcer in the genital area. Non-tender inguinal adenopathy was made out on examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.ref_book: Primary syphilis presents with a painless indurated ulcer (chancre) and non-tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. This distinguishes it from chancroid (painful ulcer), herpes (painful multiple ulcers), and granuloma inguinale (beefy red painless ulcers but with different node involvement)(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 377)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Feature of Herpes Zoster except
questions.option_d: Acyclovir 5 times a day is the treatment
questions.ref_book: Herpes zoster presents with painful vesicles in a unilateral dermatomal distribution. The pain often precedes the rash. Thus, "painless vesicle" is not a feature and is the correct exception. Treatment includes acyclovir five times daily in appropriate clinical settings(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 282)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Which rash is not usually itchy?
questions.ref_book: The rash of scarlet fever is diffuse, erythematous, and blanching, but not typically itchy. In contrast, eczema, urticaria, and scabies are intensely pruritic. Scarlet fever is caused by a streptococcal exotoxin and resolves with characteristic peeling(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 301)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Causative organism in toxic shock syndrome
questions.ref_book: Toxic shock syndrome is primarily caused by toxin-producing strains of Staphylococcus aureus, especially those releasing TSST-1. It presents with fever, hypotension, rash, and multi-organ failure. Streptococcus pyogenes may also cause a similar syndrome, but in this context, Staphylococcus aureus is the most definitive answer(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 301)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Following are mood disorders except
questions.ref_book: Mood disorders, also known as affective disorders, primarily involve disturbances in emotional state. Davidson classifies unipolar depression, bipolar disorder, and dysthymia under mood disorders. However, Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD) is categorized separately under neurotic, stress-related and somatoform disorders and not under mood disorders(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1253)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Which is a first-rank symptom of acute schizophrenia?
questions.ref_book: Broadcasting of thoughts (belief that others can hear one's thoughts) is one of the first-rank symptoms of schizophrenia, indicating significant psychotic pathology. Blunted affect, alogia, and avolition are negative symptoms seen in chronic schizophrenia, not diagnostic first-rank signs(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1251)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Postpartum blues occur how many weeks after childbirth?
questions.ref_book: Postpartum blues typically begin within the first few days after childbirth, peak around day 4, and resolve spontaneously within 1-3 weeks. They are characterized by mood lability, tearfulness, and irritability. They differ from postpartum depression, which persists longer and requires intervention(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1260)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Common presentations of conversion disorder include all except?
questions.ref_book: All listed options - gait disturbance, motor loss, sensory loss, and blindness - are recognized presentations of conversion disorder, making none of them an exception. They reflect functional neurological symptoms without organic cause(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1256)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Which is a first-rank symptom of acute schizophrenia?
questions.ref_book: Delusional perception is one of the classic first-rank symptoms of acute schizophrenia, where a normal sensory experience is assigned an abnormal, delusional meaning. In contrast, flattened affect, apathy, and poor self-care are negative symptoms, more typical of chronic schizophrenia(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1251)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Vascular cause of dementia is?
questions.ref_book: Amyloid angiopathy is listed as a vascular cause of dementia. It involves deposition of amyloid in the cerebral vessels, leading to small vessel disease and often contributing to vascular dementia. In contrast, Alzheimer's is neurodegenerative, Huntington's is genetic with movement disorder features, and Multiple sclerosis is inflammatory but not primarily a cause of dementia.(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1247)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Drug of choice for Obsessive compulsive disorder is
questions.ref_book: Fluoxetine, an SSRI, is a well-established first-line drug for OCD. It is preferred for its safety profile and efficacy. Imipramine is a TCA, Alprazolam is a benzodiazepine, and Clozapine is an antipsychotic-none of which are first-line treatments for OCD(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1255)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: A 16 year old female patient presented with over familiarity, flight of ideas, elevated mood, increased sexual desire, pseudohallucinations. What will be the diagnosis?
questions.ref_book: The classic features-elevated mood, hypersexuality, pseudohallucinations, and flight of ideas-are diagnostic of mania, not hypomania (which lacks psychotic symptoms) or cyclothymia (which involves subthreshold mood swings).(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1242)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: A 22 year old female was referred to Psychiatry OPD with history of irresistible urge to eat (cravings) followed by episodes of self induced vomiting. She was also on appetite suppressants. What is the most likely diagnosis
questions.ref_book: Bulimia nervosa involves episodes of binge eating followed by purging, commonly by vomiting or appetite suppressant abuse. Unlike anorexia, weight is usually normal. PICA involves non-food substances, and binge eating disorder lacks compensatory behaviors like vomiting(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1258)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: A woman, who is 4 days postpartum, presented with tearfulness, mood swings, and occasional insomnia. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.ref_book: This woman's symptoms of tearfulness, mood swings, and insomnia occurring on day 4 postpartum are classic for postpartum blues-a transient, self-limiting mood disturbance affecting up to 80% of new mothers. Unlike depression or psychosis, symptoms are mild and resolve without treatment(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1260)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Repeated attacks of severe anxiety not restricted to any situation
questions.ref_book: Panic disorder involves sudden, intense episodes of anxiety with physical symptoms like palpitations and breathlessness, unrelated to specific triggers. This distinguishes it from phobic disorders and generalized anxiety, which are more persistent or context-specific(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1255)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: A 25-year-old woman presents with irritability, labile mood and tearfulness soon after childbirth. Her symptoms peaked on the fourth day and then gradually resolved in a few weeks.The probable diagnosis is
questions.ref_book: Post-partum blues is a common, transient mood disturbance seen in new mothers, usually peaking around day 4 postpartum and resolving within 2-3 weeks. Unlike post-partum depression or psychosis, it is self-limited and requires only support and reassurance(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1260)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: A 82-year-old woman who is a retired school teacher is brought with progressive memory loss. Her daughter states that the patient often gets lost while going out.The probable diagnosis is
questions.ref_book: Dementia presents as progressive decline in memory and function, often with patients getting lost in known places. Unlike mild cognitive impairment, which lacks functional impact, dementia affects daily life. Delirium is acute and fluctuating, while conversion disorder involves neurologic symptoms with no organic basis.(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1246)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Increased capillary permeability causes oedema in
questions.ref_book: Oedema due to increased capillary permeability occurs primarily in inflammatory states such as local infection or inflammation. In contrast, cardiac failure, nephrotic syndrome, and malignancy cause oedema via different mechanisms like increased hydrostatic pressure, low oncotic pressure, or lymphatic obstruction(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 567)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Which is a relative contraindication for Renal Biopsy?
questions.ref_book: A solitary kidney is a relative contraindication to renal biopsy because of the increased risk of complications and the lack of a backup organ. Absolute contraindications include uncontrolled hypertension, thrombocytopenia, and kidneys <60% predicted size. However, renal transplant kidneys are an exception where biopsy may still be performed under careful supervision(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 566)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: What is the multiplication factor for women while calculating GFR by Cockcroft-Gault formula
questions.ref_book:
Cockcroft-Gault formula-another widely used method for estimating GFR-uses a multiplication factor of 0.85 for females. This factor adjusts for the typically lower muscle mass in women, which affects serum creatinine levels and thus the estimated GFR. The formula is:
Creatinine clearance (mL/min) = [(140 - age) ? weight (kg)] / (72 ? serum creatinine (mg/dL)) ? 0.85 (if female).
This adjustment is clinically important for accurate dosing of renally excreted drugs.

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Features of Renal Artery Stenosis except
questions.ref_book: Asymmetrical kidneys are a clue to renal artery stenosis, typically due to reduced perfusion and resulting atrophy in the affected kidney. Other common features include refractory hypertension, flash pulmonary oedema, and renal bruits. Hence, symmetrical kidneys are not a feature of the condition(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 581)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Which one of the following does NOT cause Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis?
questions.ref_book: Mesangioproliferative Glomerulonephritis is generally associated with mild nephritic syndrome and follows a slowly progressive course. It does not typically cause crescentic GN or the rapid renal decline that defines RPGN. In contrast, Post-infectious GN, Anti-GBM disease, and Small-vessel vasculitis are established causes of RPGN, commonly featuring necrotising and crescentic glomerular lesions on biopsy. Therefore, mesangioproliferative GN is correctly identified as the exception(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 573)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Identify the drug causing Acute Tubular Necrosis among the following
questions.ref_book: Amphotericin B is a well-established nephrotoxic agent that causes acute tubular necrosis (ATN) through direct toxicity to the renal tubules. Although ACE inhibitors and NSAIDs are more common contributors to renal dysfunction via hemodynamic mechanisms, amphotericin B specifically damages the tubules themselves. In contrast, Ampicillin and Amlodipine do not typically cause ATN. ACE inhibitors affect glomerular hemodynamics rather than directly injuring the tubules(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 599)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: All of the following conditions cause ptosis, except
questions.ref_book: Ptosis, or drooping of the eyelid, is a feature of several neurological and muscular conditions. Third cranial nerve palsy causes complete ptosis due to levator palpebrae superioris paralysis. Myasthenia gravis leads to fluctuating ptosis from fatigable weakness of ocular muscles. Horner syndrome, involving sympathetic disruption, results in partial ptosis. However, the second cranial nerve (optic nerve) is purely sensory and has no motor function affecting eyelid elevation, and does not cause ptosis(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1147)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Drug safe in epilepsy during pregnancy is
questions.ref_book: Among the listed options, levetiracetam is noted to have  a better safety profile in pregnancy compared to older antiepileptic drugs like phenytoin, primidone, and phenobarbital, which are enzyme-inducing and associated with teratogenicity. Levetiracetam is often preferred when substitution is possible because of its relatively low risk of fetal malformations and absence of major pharmacokinetic interactions. Therefore, levetiracetam is the safest among the given choices for use in pregnancy(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1158)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: All are function of Dominant frontal lobe except
questions.ref_book: The dominant frontal lobe primarily handles higher-order cognitive activities such as logic, judgement, decision-making, emotional regulation, and planning. These are grouped under executive functions. In contrast, long-term memory is not a function of the frontal lobe; it is primarily associated with the limbic system, including structures like the hippocampus and parahippocampal cortex in the temporal lobes(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1124)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: First line of drug for absence seizure
questions.ref_book: Ethosuximide is the first-line treatment for typical absence seizures, especially in childhood absence epilepsy, due to its efficacy and relatively benign side effect profile. Sodium valproate is also effective but is typically avoided in females of childbearing potential due to teratogenicity(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1157)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Features of upper motor neuron involvement are all except
questions.ref_book: Upper motor neuron (UMN) lesions are characterized by spasticity, hyperreflexia, clonus, and the presence of Babinski sign, with typically no fasciculations. Although muscle atrophy may be present in chronic UMN lesions, it is mild compared to the marked atrophy and fasciculations seen in lower motor neuron (LMN) involvement. Fasciculations, which are spontaneous visible twitches of muscle fibers, are a hallmark of LMN disease, not UMN.(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1139)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: All drugs are used in thrombolytic therapy of stroke except
questions.ref_book: Alteplase, tenecteplase, and reteplase are tissue plasminogen activators used in thrombolytic therapy for acute ischaemic stroke. Streptokinase, although historically used for thrombolysis in myocardial infarction, is not used in stroke due to higher risk of bleeding and lower efficacy in cerebral circulation(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1211)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Which of the following about Spasticity  is false
questions.ref_book:
All three features listed in the question are correct features of spasticity:

Velocity-dependent: Spasticity increases with the speed of passive movement.

Sudden release at maximum: This refers to the clasp-knife phenomenon, a classic component of spasticity.

Affects antigravity muscles: Characteristically involves upper limb flexors and lower limb extensors.

Thus, none of the statements are false, making "None of the above" the correct answer.

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Ptosis is a feature of
questions.ref_book: Ptosis is classically associated with 3rd cranial nerve (oculomotor) palsy, which innervates the levator palpebrae superioris. The palsy also typically presents with a "down and out" eye and a dilated pupil. It is not a feature of IV (trochlear), VI (abducens), or VII (facial) nerve palsies(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1147)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Lesion causing focal sensory seizures, spatial disorientation, and contralateral sensory loss?
questions.ref_book: A lesion in the non-dominant parietal lobe presents with focal sensory seizures, contralateral sensory loss, and spatial disorientation, making it the correct answer. Dominant parietal lesions involve language and calculation deficits, while temporal lesions are more associated with memory and hallucinations(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1124)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: All are mitochondrial disorders except?
questions.ref_book: CADASIL (Cerebral Autosomal Dominant Arteriopathy with Subcortical Infarcts and Leukoencephalopathy) is a nuclear gene disorder, not mitochondrial. The other options - MELAS, Kearns-Sayre, and CPEO - are classic mitochondrial disorders(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1197)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: A male patient presented to the emergency room with seizures. He has a history of fever, headache, and confusion. An MRI brain was done, and it showed inflammation involving the bitemporal lobe. What is the most likely aetiology for this presentation?
questions.ref_book: HSV encephalitis typically affects the temporal lobes and causes fever, confusion, seizures, and focal neurological signs. Bitemporal involvement on imaging is a hallmark finding. It's a medical emergency with high mortality unless treated early with aciclovir. Other options are less likely given the localization and presentation.(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1175)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Dopamine agonist drug used in Parkinson disease is
questions.ref_book: Pramipexole is a non-ergot dopamine agonist used in Parkinson's disease either as monotherapy or adjunct to levodopa. It mimics dopamine and helps relieve motor symptoms. Other options like Selegiline (MAO-B inhibitor), Tolcapone (COMT inhibitor), and Amantadine (NMDA antagonist) are not dopamine agonists(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1167)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: A 56-year-old man presents with contralateral homonymous upper quadrantanopia, impaired non-verbal memory & musical skills, complex hallucinations (smell, sound, vision). Which cortical lobe function is affected?
questions.ref_book: The constellation of upper quadrantanopia, non-verbal memory loss, and complex hallucinations points to a lesion in the non-dominant temporal lobe. Dominant lesions would involve language dysfunction, and parietal lesions cause spatial neglect or dyscalculia(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1124)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: A 28 year old female presents with bilateral proptosis, ptosis, headache, external and internal ophthalmoplegia, papilledema, reduced sensation in trigeminal first division. Where is the lesion?
questions.ref_book: Cavernous sinus thrombosis classically presents with bilateral eye signs, cranial nerve palsies (III, IV, VI, and V1), and signs of raised intracranial pressure. The involvement of multiple nerves with bilateral features and proptosis localizes the lesion to the cavernous sinus(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1145)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Condition due to vitamin deficiency presenting with ataxia, visual scotomas, and mild hemolytic anemia?
questions.ref_book: Vitamin E deficiency, though rare, leads to neurological symptoms like ataxia and visual disturbances, and oxidative damage to red blood cells, causing hemolytic anemia. These features help differentiate it from deficiencies of other fat-soluble vitamins like A, D, and K(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 776)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: A young patient started to take a weight loss medication that acts by inhibiting fat absorption from food. After a few weeks, she developed easy bruising and increased menstrual bleeding. Deficiency of which of the following vitamins is responsible for her condition?
questions.ref_book: Weight-loss medications that block fat absorption (like orlistat) can lead to malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins. Vitamin K is essential for synthesizing clotting factors (II, VII, IX, X), and its deficiency causes easy bruising, mucosal bleeding, and menorrhagia. This matches the clinical presentation(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 776)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que:
A 56-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Room in an acute confusional state.
History reveals that the patient is a chronic alcoholic.On examination, patient has ophthalmoplegia and ataxia.Which Vitamin needs to be supplemented?
questions.ref_book: Wernicke encephalopathy is a medical emergency classically seen in chronic alcoholics due to thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency. It presents with the classic triad of confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia, and requires immediate thiamine replacement to prevent irreversible damage such as Korsakoff psychosis(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 776)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Drug causing chronic cough
questions.ref_book: Enalapril, an ACE inhibitor, is a well-known cause of chronic dry cough due to increased bradykinin levels. This adverse effect is specific to the ACE inhibitor class and can persist for months after stopping the drug(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 489)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: All are features of pneumothorax except
questions.option_a: Apical impulse shift to opposite side
questions.option_c: Collapse of same side of lung
questions.ref_book: In pneumothorax, air enters the pleural space, causing collapse of the affected (same) lung. The percussion note over the affected side becomes resonant or hyper-resonant, and in tension pneumothorax, rising pressure shifts the trachea and apical impulse to the opposite side. A tracheal shift to the same side is not characteristic of pneumothorax-it is instead seen in lung collapse or fibrosis. Hence, the incorrect statement in the context of pneumothorax is: tracheal shift to the same side(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 481)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Juxtacapillary receptors are found in
questions.ref_book: Juxtacapillary (J) receptors, also known as pulmonary C-fiber receptors, are located in the alveolar interstitial space-specifically in the walls of alveoli, near the pulmonary capillaries. They are stimulated in conditions like pulmonary edema or fibrosis, where interstitial pressure rises

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Malt worker's lung is caused by
questions.ref_book: Malt worker's lung is a form of hypersensitivity pneumonitis caused by exposure to moldy malt. The causative organism responsible is Aspergillus clavatu(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 544)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Causes of asymmetric expansion of the chest includes
questions.option_a: Endobronchial obstruction of a large airway
questions.ref_book:
Asymmetric chest expansion can result from any pathology that unilaterally impairs ventilation mechanics. This includes:

Endobronchial obstruction of a large airway, which leads to atelectasis and reduced expansion on that side.

Unilateral parenchymal or pleural disease such as pleural effusion, fibrosis, or infarction which limits local lung expansion.

Phrenic nerve paralysis, resulting in elevation of the diaphragm and paradoxical movement, contributes to poor chest wall movement on the affected side.
Hence, all listed causes contribute to asymmetrical chest expansion(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 555)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Non-metastatic extra-pulmonary manifestations of lung cancer include all except?
questions.ref_book: Stroke is not listed as a non-metastatic extrapulmonary manifestation of lung cancer. It may occur due to metastatic spread or paraneoplastic coagulopathy but is not included in Davidson's list of recognized non-metastatic syndromes. Other options like carcinoid syndrome, gynaecomastia, and cerebellar degeneration are explicitly included(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 530)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Apnea-hypopnea index is used to indicate the severity of?
questions.ref_book: The apnea-hypopnea index (AHI) is used to quantify the severity of obstructive sleep apnea-hypopnea syndrome (OSAHS) by counting the number of apnea or hypopnea episodes per hour of sleep. It is not used in conditions like emphysema, asthma, or hyaline membrane disease(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 551)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: A patient presents to you with fever, night sweats, ptosis, and bilateral facial nerve palsy. Investigations showed leukocytosis and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.ref_book: Sarcoidosis is a multisystem granulomatous disorder. Its hallmark features include bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, facial nerve palsy, systemic symptoms like fever and night sweats, and lymphocytosis or leukocytosis. These features fit the clinical case best(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 538)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: A patient with a previous history of myocardial infarction and ventricular arrhythmia is on treatment for a few months. He developed fatigue, dyspnea, and weight gain. He had also developed pulmonary fibrosis. Which of the following drugs is responsible for the side effects mentioned above?
questions.ref_book: Amiodarone is a known cause of pulmonary fibrosis and systemic side effects such as fatigue, weight gain (from hypothyroidism), and dyspnea. This combination of symptoms strongly implicates it as the cause in this patient with prior cardiac issues(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 540)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Life-threatening feature in acute severe asthma
questions.ref_book: A silent chest signifies near-complete airway obstruction and is a marker of imminent respiratory failure in acute asthma. It is considered a life-threatening sign along with hypoxia and hypercapnia. SpO? >92% and PEF 33-50% are criteria for severe, not life-threatening asthma(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 504)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Risk factors for invasive Aspergillosis except
questions.ref_book: Bronchial asthma is associated with allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA), not invasive aspergillosis. The invasive form occurs in immunocompromised individuals, especially those with neutropenia, HIV, or chronic granulomatous disease. Hence, asthma is not a risk factor for invasive disease(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 527)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Antibody present in drug induced lupus
questions.ref_book: Anti-histone antibodies are found in approximately 80% of cases of drug-induced lupus and are considered a hallmark of the condition. This distinguishes it from systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), where antibodies such as anti-dsDNA or anti-Sm are more common. Anti-La (SS-B) and anti-RNA polymerase are not typically associated with drug-induced lupus. Thus, anti-histone antibody is the specific and correct marker in this context.(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 999)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Pseudogout is caused by
questions.ref_book: Pseudogout is a form of crystal-induced arthritis caused specifically by calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate (CPPD) crystals. These crystals deposit in cartilage and joints, especially in older individuals, and can mimic gout clinically. Unlike gout, which is caused by monosodium urate monohydrate, or basic calcium phosphate (BCP)-related diseases (like calcific periarthritis), pseudogout is uniquely linked to CPPD(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1021)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Takayasu arteritis affects
questions.ref_book: Takayasu arteritis is a large-vessel granulomatous vasculitis that primarily involves the aorta and its major branches, and in some cases, the pulmonary arteries.(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1045)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Cause of multiple fractures in infancy and childhood
questions.ref_book: Osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) is a genetic disorder of type I collagen characterized by severe osteoporosis and frequent fractures, especially in infancy and childhood, often occurring after minimal trauma. The clinical presentation is often mistaken for non-accidental injury.(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1058)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Following are features of Rheumatoid Arthritis except
questions.ref_book: Rheumatoid arthritis leads to persistent joint inflammation, which often results in residual deformities such as subluxation, ulnar deviation, and swan-neck or boutonni?re deformities. Early morning stiffness, raised ESR, and positive rheumatoid factor are classic features, making "no residual deformities" the incorrect option(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 1029)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Main effect of osteoprotegerin (a key regulator of bone remodeling)?
questions.ref_book: Osteoprotegerin (OPG) is a decoy receptor that binds to RANKL, preventing it from activating RANK on osteoclast precursors. This inhibits bone resorption by preventing osteoclast formation, helping maintain bone density. It plays a crucial role in balancing the activity of bone-forming and bone-resorbing cells in bone metabolism(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 994)

questions.subject: GENERAL MEDICINE
questions.que: Radiographic abnormality in Rheumatoid Arthritis
questions.ref_book: The most common early radiographic change in rheumatoid arthritis is periarticular osteoporosis, followed by joint space narrowing and marginal erosions. This helps differentiate it from psoriatic arthritis (which has enthesitis and bone proliferation), Paget's disease (with trabecular abnormalities), and others like pseudofractures(Davidson's Medicine 24th Edition, Page No : 996)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: All of the following statements are true regarding umbilical hernia except
questions.option_a: Umbilical hernia is common following incomplete closure of umbilical ring
questions.option_c: Umbilical hernia needs immediate repair in new born
questions.option_d: Umbilical hernia needs urgent repair in adults
questions.ref_book: Umbilical hernias in newborns are usually due to incomplete closure of the umbilical ring and often resolve spontaneously by 2 years of age. Hence, immediate repair is not indicated in neonates unless complications like incarceration arise. In contrast, adult umbilical hernias require prompt surgical repair due to higher risk of complications.(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 833)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: All of the following are boundaries of Hesselbach's Triangle, Except
questions.ref_book:
Hesselbach's triangle is an anatomical area of the lower abdominal wall through which direct inguinal hernias protrude. Its borders are:

Medially: Lateral border of rectus abdominis

Laterally: Inferior epigastric artery

Inferiorly: Inguinal ligament (Poupart's)
Cooper's ligament (pectineal ligament) is not a boundary of this triangle.(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 809)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Primary lumbar hernia occurs through?
questions.ref_book: Primary lumbar hernias most frequently occur through the superior lumbar triangle (Grynfelt's/Lesgaft's triangle), which is anatomically bounded by the 12th rib, sacrospinalis muscle, and posterior border of internal oblique. Though both superior and inferior triangles can be involved, the superior triangle is the more common site for primary hernias(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 837)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: In Sportsman's groin, there will be
questions.option_b: Tightening of hip flexor or thigh adductor muscles
questions.ref_book: Sportsman's groin (or sports hernia) is a soft tissue injury in the lower abdomen or groin without a visible hernia. The condition is due to repetitive stress, particularly involving the hip flexor or thigh adductor muscles. Pain is localized to the groin and worsens with activity. Since it's a musculoskeletal strain syndrome, tightness or overuse of hip/thigh musculature is a hallmark, not a scrotal, hernial, or pelvic ring problem

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: The following statements regarding hernia are true except
questions.option_a: Femoral hernia is more common in females than males
questions.option_b: The most common hernia in females is inguinal hernia
questions.option_c: Umbilical hernia in an infant is a surgical emergency
questions.option_d: Femoral hernia occurs below the inguinal ligament
questions.ref_book: Umbilical hernia in infants is usually not a surgical emergency. It often resolves by 2-3 years of age, and surgery is typically delayed unless complications (like strangulation) occur - which are rare. Therefore, the statement claiming it is a surgical emergency is incorrect. All other statements are true based on anatomy and epidemiology of hernias.

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Doughy consistency with dull percussion in a complete inguinal hernia suggests contents of?
questions.ref_book: A doughy, soft consistency with dullness on percussion in a complete inguinal hernia typically indicates that the omentum is the content. In contrast, bowel-containing hernias are often resonant on percussion due to gas within the intestine and may show gurgling. Omentum gives a characteristic soft, doughy feel due to its fatty texture(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 806)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Fourth degree haemorrhoids is
questions.ref_book: Fourth-degree hemorrhoids represent the most severe form, where the hemorrhoidal tissue remains constantly prolapsed outside the anal canal and cannot be manually reduced. This stage typically causes discomfort, bleeding, and may require surgical intervention like hemorrhoidectomy(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 1030)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Inter sphincteric anal fistula
questions.option_a: Does not cross the external sphincter
questions.option_b: Crosses both external and internal sphincters
questions.ref_book: Inter-sphincteric fistula is the most common variant of anal fistula. The tract lies between the internal and external anal sphincters, traveling through the intersphincteric plane, and exits near the anal verge. It does not cross the external sphincter, making it more straightforward to treat surgically(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 1040)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Condyloma acuminata is
questions.option_a: An intra epithelial neoplasm of Anus
questions.ref_book: Condyloma acuminata are benign lesions also known as anogenital warts, caused by Human Papilloma Virus (HPV)-particularly types 6 and 11. They present as soft, cauliflower-like growths in the perianal or genital region. They are not malignant but may co-exist with or predispose to neoplastic changes in high-risk HPV types(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 1045)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Lower GI bleeding is caused by all except?
questions.ref_book: Enterobacter is a bacterium and not a direct cause of lower GI bleeding. Hemorrhoids, diverticulosis, and angiodysplasia are established causes. Hence, Enterobacter is correctly excluded.(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 1050)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: In acute appendicitis, which sign is positive?
questions.ref_book: Blumberg's sign, or rebound tenderness, is elicited by pressing slowly over the right lower quadrant and then suddenly releasing. Increased pain on release indicates peritoneal inflammation, making it a classical sign of acute appendicitis(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 1000)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Blood-stained nipple discharge is present in the following conditions except?
questions.ref_book: Blood-stained nipple discharge is typically associated with intraductal papilloma, duct ectasia, and intraductal carcinoma. However, ductal hyperplasia is a benign proliferation of ductal epithelial cells and does not usually present with blood-stained discharge, making it the correct exclusion(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 573)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Luminal B classification of breast cancer is defined as?
questions.option_a: Positive ER/PR receptor, Negative HER2, Ki-67 low
questions.option_b: Negative ER/PR receptor, Negative HER2, Ki-67 low
questions.option_c: Positive ER/PR receptor, Negative HER2, Ki-67 high
questions.option_d: Positive ER/PR receptor, positive HER2, Ki-67 high
questions.ref_book: Luminal B breast cancer subtype is characterized by hormone receptor positivity (ER/PR), either HER2 positive or negative, and a high Ki-67 index, indicating higher proliferative activity and worse prognosis compared to Luminal A. The given option with all three features matches this profile best(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 586)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Rotter's node will come under
questions.ref_book: Rotter's nodes are interpectoral lymph nodes located between the pectoralis major and minor muscles. According to the axillary lymph node classification, they are grouped under Level II, which includes nodes beneath the pectoralis minor. Their involvement is clinically significant in breast cancer staging and surgical planning(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 559)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: The following statements are true about non-cyclical mastalgia except
questions.option_a: May be associated with periductal mastitis
questions.option_c: The pain is not localised often
questions.ref_book: Non-cyclical mastalgia differs from cyclical mastalgia in that the pain is usually localized to a specific area of the breast rather than being diffuse. It may be associated with periductal mastitis, can occur in post-menopausal women, and is often linked to trigger points in the chest wall or breast tissue. Therefore, the statement that the pain is not localized often is incorrect

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: The following are true about phyllodes tumour except
questions.option_a: Mastectomy is indicated in massive tumours
questions.option_b: Wide Local Excision (WLE) with 2cm margin clearance is given for benign tumours
questions.option_c: It frequently metastasises through blood stream
questions.option_d: They are classified according to histological behaviour
questions.ref_book: Phyllodes tumour is a fibroepithelial breast tumor that can be benign, borderline, or malignant, classified based on histological behavior. Treatment involves wide local excision with a 2?cm margin for benign or smaller tumors, and mastectomy for very large ones. While metastasis, when it occurs, is hematogenous, it is rare, not frequent.(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 564)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Sentinel node biopsy can be done in all EXCEPT?
questions.ref_book: Sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) is a minimally invasive procedure used to evaluate lymphatic spread in breast cancer, malignant melanoma, and carcinoma of the penis. It is not routinely done in carcinoma stomach due to complex lymphatic drainage and lower accuracy(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 589)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Black, green or muddy discharge' from nipple indicates
questions.ref_book: Duct ectasia is a benign breast condition where the large ducts behind the nipple become dilated and inflamed, often leading to black, green, or muddy nipple discharge. It may also present with nipple retraction and periductal mastitis. This type of discharge is not typical of ductal carcinoma or hyperplasia.(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 569)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Serous nipple discharge occurs in the following conditions except?
questions.ref_book: Ductal carcinoma more commonly presents with bloody discharge. Hence, it is not a cause of serous discharge

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: A tender thrombosed subcutaneous cord-like structure in the breast in a 40-year-old female is pathognomonic of?
questions.ref_book: Mondor's disease is a rare, benign condition involving thrombophlebitis of superficial subcutaneous veins in the breast. It typically presents as a painful, cord-like structure beneath the skin, which is pathognomonic in middle-aged women(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 569)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Oncoplastic procedure of cancer breast includes?
questions.ref_book: Oncoplastic surgery combines cancer surgery with plastic surgical techniques. Volume displacement surgery refers to reshaping the remaining breast tissue after wide excision and is a recognized form of oncoplastic technique. This is distinct from standard breast conservation or simple excision(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 608)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Traumatic fat necrosis is diagnosed by
questions.ref_book: Traumatic fat necrosis typically presents as a painless, hard, nonprogressive lump in the breast. While trauma may be a contributing factor, it is often not recalled by the patient. Imaging like mammography helps rule out malignancy, but definitive diagnosis is made via FNAC or biopsy, which reveals chalky material and fat globules(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 566)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Non-modifiable risk factors of carcinoma breast include all except
questions.ref_book: Non-modifiable risk factors for breast cancer include family history, early menarche, and late menopause, as they relate to genetic background and cumulative estrogen exposure. Breastfeeding, on the other hand, is a protective factor and not a risk(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 575)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Black muddy nipple discharge occurs in
questions.ref_book: Duct ectasia (also called plasma cell mastitis) typically presents in middle-aged to elderly women with thick, sticky, greenish-black or muddy nipple discharge. It results from dilatation and inflammation of the large ducts beneath the nipple

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: A person's hand corresponds to?
questions.ref_book: The "Rule of Nines" helps estimate burn surface area. In adults, the entire hand (palm + fingers) constitutes roughly 2% of the total body surface area, which is clinically useful for assessing burn extent(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 123)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Causes of cardiogenic shock include all except?
questions.ref_book: Hemorrhage leads to hypovolemic shock, not cardiogenic shock. Cardiogenic shock results from pump failure, such as in myocardial injury, cardiomyopathy, and arrhythmias. Therefore, hemorrhage is not a cause of cardiogenic shock.(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 83)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Complications of massive blood transfusion include all except?
questions.ref_book: Massive transfusion complications include hypocalcemia, hyperkalemia, and hypothermia. Hyponatremia is not a standard complication listed, making it the correct exception(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 99)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Which of the following criteria is NOT a part of the Quick Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (qSOFA) score for sepsis?
questions.ref_book:
The qSOFA score is a bedside tool used to quickly identify patients at risk for poor outcomes from sepsis. It includes three criteria:

Respiratory rate ? 22/min

Systolic blood pressure ? 100 mmHg

Glasgow Coma Scale < 15
White blood cell count is part of SIRS (Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome) criteria, not qSOFA(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 86)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: What is the primary goal in the initial management of haemorrhagic shock?
questions.option_b: Control bleeding and restore circulating volume
questions.ref_book: The cornerstone of haemorrhagic shock management is to rapidly control the source of bleeding and restore blood volume to maintain perfusion of vital organs. This is achieved through surgical or mechanical control of hemorrhage and fluid resuscitation with crystalloids and blood products. Vasopressors are not first-line and may worsen perfusion if used before volume restoration(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 88)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Central venous pressure is raised in which of the following shock?
questions.ref_book: Cardiogenic shock results from pump failure of the heart, leading to inadequate forward flow and backlog of blood in the venous system, which raises central venous pressure (CVP)(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 85)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Distributive shock includes the following conditions EXCEPT?
questions.ref_book: Distributive shock is characterized by vasodilation and abnormal distribution of blood flow, despite normal or increased cardiac output. It includes septic shock, anaphylaxis, and neurogenic shock (e.g., from spinal cord injury). Cardiac tamponade, on the other hand, causes obstructive shock by physically compressing the heart and reducing cardiac output, thus it is not part of distributive shock(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 85)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Complications from massive blood transfusion include the following EXCEPT?
questions.ref_book: Massive blood transfusion can lead to several metabolic and hematological complications due to the volume and age of stored blood. Hyperkalaemia occurs because potassium leaks out of red blood cells during storage. Coagulopathy develops due to dilution of clotting factors, and hypothermia results from transfusion of cold blood. Hypokalaemia, however, is not expected-transfused blood raises serum potassium rather than lowering it(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 99)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: The following are used for tube feeding except
questions.ref_book: Tube feeding involves delivering nutrition directly to the gastrointestinal tract and is done through nasojejunal, gastrostomy, or jejunostomy tubes. Colostomy, on the other hand, is a surgical opening of the colon used to divert feces and is not used for feeding purposes(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 114)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: The following statements is true regarding cardiogenic shock
questions.ref_book: In cardiogenic shock, cardiac output is low due to pump failure. To compensate, systemic vascular resistance and venous pressure increase, but tissue perfusion remains poor, leading to metabolic acidosis with a high base deficit(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 85)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Metabolic response to starvation is following except
questions.ref_book: In the starvation state, the body adapts by lowering insulin levels and increasing glucagon, promoting energy mobilization through glycogenolysis, gluconeogenesis, and protein catabolism. High insulin is inconsistent with the metabolic adaptation to starvation and is therefore the correct exception(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 113)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Achalasia cardia is treated by all except?
questions.ref_book: Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) are used to treat acid-related disorders such as GERD or peptic ulcer disease, but not for achalasia cardia. The main treatments for achalasia target LES relaxation, such as pneumatic dilatation, calcium channel blockers, and botulinum toxin injection(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 855)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: In achalasia cardia, there will be
questions.option_b: Increased contraction of lower oesophageal sphincter
questions.ref_book: Achalasia cardia is marked by a non-relaxing lower oesophageal sphincter (LOS) and loss of peristalsis in the oesophageal body. This results in functional obstruction and leads to progressive dysphagia for both solids and liquids(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 853)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: All are predisposing factors of Phytobezoars except
questions.ref_book: Phytobezoars are masses formed from undigested plant material. They commonly occur due to factors like inadequate chewing, high-fibre diets, hypochlorhydria (low stomach acid), and loss of normal gastric motility. On the contrary, hyperchlorhydria (high acid) is not a risk factor

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Which of the following are TRUE about Menetrier's disease
questions.option_c: Caused by Overexpression of TGF - alpha
questions.ref_book: Menetrier's disease is a rare premalignant condition of the stomach characterized by massive hypertrophy of gastric mucosal folds, leading to protein-losing gastropathy (hypoproteinaemia) and iron-deficiency anaemia. It is strongly linked to overexpression of transforming growth factor-alpha (TGF-?). All listed statements are correct.(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 900)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: A risk factor for Barrett's esophagus and related neoplasm is?
questions.ref_book: Chronic gastro-esophageal reflux disease (GERD) is the most important risk factor for Barrett's esophagus, which is a premalignant condition due to metaplasia of esophageal squamous epithelium to columnar epithelium. This transformation significantly increases the risk of developing adenocarcinoma of the esophagus(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 852)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: The gold standard investigation for carcinoma stomach is?
questions.ref_book: Upper gastrointestinal (UGI) endoscopy, also called gastroscopy, is considered the gold standard investigation for carcinoma stomach. It allows direct visualization of gastric mucosa, detection of suspicious lesions, and performance of multiple biopsies, which is essential for histopathological confirmation. Though CT is useful for staging, and USG/MRI have roles in evaluating metastasis or liver involvement, only endoscopy can confirm diagnosis via biopsy(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 908)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Complication of gastrectomy include
questions.ref_book: Vitamin B12 deficiency is a well-known late complication of gastrectomy, particularly total gastrectomy, due to loss of intrinsic factor, which is essential for B12 absorption in the terminal ileum. Without intrinsic factor (produced by gastric parietal cells), patients eventually develop pernicious anemia. While iron absorption may also be reduced, B12 deficiency is more specific and severe in this context. Deficiencies of fat-soluble vitamins like A and K are not directly linked to gastrectomy unless there is associated malabsorption or extensive small bowel resection(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 916)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Hepatocellular carcinoma is caused by
questions.ref_book: Hepatitis B virus (HBV) is a major cause of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) due to its ability to cause chronic liver inflammation and integrate into the host genome, promoting carcinogenesis. While Hepatitis C also contributes to HCC, Hepatitis B is more strongly and directly associated. Hepatitis A is an acute, self-limiting illness and does not lead to chronic liver disease or HCC. HIV is not directly linked to HCC(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 877)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is treated
questions.ref_book: Ramstedt's pyloromyotomy is the definitive surgical treatment for infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, a condition marked by hypertrophy of the pyloric muscle causing gastric outlet obstruction in infants. The procedure involves a longitudinal incision of the serosa and hypertrophied muscle, relieving the obstruction. Other options like Heller myotomy are for achalasia, and Nissen's fundoplication is used for gastroesophageal reflux(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 877)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Borrmann staging is done for which of the following cancer?
questions.ref_book: Borrmann classification is a system used specifically for gastric (stomach) carcinoma, categorizing tumors into types I to IV based on their gross morphology such as polypoid, ulcerative, infiltrative, etc. It is not used for oral, bladder, or colon cancers(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 904)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: The following is one of the symptoms of endoscopic oesophageal perforation
questions.ref_book: Subcutaneous emphysema is a classic symptom of oesophageal perforation, especially after endoscopic procedures. It results from escape of air into the surrounding soft tissues. Other signs include dysphagia, neck pain, and fever. Haematemesis, air under diaphragm, and bradycardia are not typical features of oesophageal perforation(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 868)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Which is the parotid duct?
questions.ref_book:
Stensen's duct is the excretory duct of the parotid gland, opening into the oral cavity opposite the upper second molar. The other options refer to ducts of submandibular or sublingual glands:

Wharton's duct - submandibular gland

Rivinus' duct - sublingual gland

Santorini's duct - accessory pancreatic duct(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 469)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Frey's Syndrome is due to injury of which of the following nerve branch?
questions.ref_book: Frey's Syndrome (gustatory sweating) occurs when parasympathetic fibers destined for the parotid gland regenerate abnormally and supply sweat glands of the overlying skin, usually after parotid surgery. Though the auriculotemporal nerve (from the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve) is injured(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 489)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Dry gangrene occurs due to?
questions.ref_book: Dry gangrene results from gradual arterial insufficiency, typically due to atherosclerosis, where there is no infection. The tissue dries, shrinks, and blackens. This contrasts with wet gangrene, which involves sudden occlusion or infection(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 231)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Following statements are true regarding Raynaud's disease except?
questions.option_b: Usually due to abnormal sensitivity to cold
questions.option_c: It is a manifestation of collagen disease
questions.option_d: It occurs in the use of vibrating tools
questions.ref_book: Primary Raynaud's phenomenon is an idiopathic vasospastic disorder withour underlying identifiable causes.. (SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 207)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Common site of aortic aneurysm
questions.ref_book: The abdominal aorta, especially the infrarenal segment, is the most common site for aortic aneurysm, accounting for the vast majority of cases. This is primarily due to the relative lack of vasa vasorum and structural weakness in the medial layer at this site. Although thoracic and abdominothoracic aneurysms also occur, they are far less common than abdominal aneurysms(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 223)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: All of the following are true about toxic adenoma except?
questions.option_a: It's a dominant nodule of multi-nodular goiter
questions.option_d: The hyperplasia is not due to TSH-rAb
questions.ref_book: Toxic adenoma refers to a single hyperfunctioning thyroid nodule that autonomously produces thyroid hormones independent of TSH. It is not part of a multinodular goitre; that condition is called toxic multinodular goitre. Thus, the statement that it is a dominant nodule of MNG is false(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 508)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: In hyperparathyroidism, there will be?
questions.ref_book: Hyperparathyroidism leads to elevated secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH), which increases bone resorption, calcium reabsorption in the kidney, and calcium absorption in the gut, resulting in hypercalcemia. It also reduces phosphate reabsorption, causing hypophosphatemia(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 541)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Secondary hyperparathyroidism is caused by
questions.ref_book: Secondary hyperparathyroidism is a compensatory response to hypocalcemia, most often caused by chronic kidney disease or vitamin D deficiency, leading to increased PTH secretion. It is not due to autonomous secretion (as in primary or tertiary types) and is not related to HRPT2 mutations, which are linked with parathyroid carcinoma(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 541)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Injury to Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve causes
questions.ref_book: The recurrent laryngeal nerve supplies all intrinsic muscles of the larynx (except cricothyroid). Injury to this nerve, commonly during thyroid surgery, leads to vocal cord paralysis, resulting in hoarseness of voice. It is one of the most recognized complications of thyroidectomy and other neck surgeries(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 536)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Most common thyroid malignancy is?
questions.ref_book: Papillary carcinoma is the most common type of thyroid cancer, especially in younger individuals and females. It has a good prognosis and spreads via lymphatics. Other types like follicular, medullary, and anaplastic are less common and may behave more aggressively.(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 518)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: All are true about MEN 1 except?
questions.option_c: Accounts for 40% of primary hyperparathyroidism in patients under 30 years
questions.ref_book: MEN 1 (Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1) is indeed a rare autosomal dominant disorder and is also referred to as Wermer's syndrome. However, it does not account for 40% of hyperparathyroidism in young patients(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 547)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Method of palpation of thyroid gland in Obese patients with short neck is
questions.ref_book: Palpation of the thyroid gland may be challenging in obese patients or those with short necks. Alternative techniques like Lahey's method (posterior approach), Crile's method (tracheal displacement), and Pizzillo's method (patient supine with neck extended) are recommended. Hence, all three methods are appropriate in such cases(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 501)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Zenker's diverticulum
questions.ref_book: Zenker's diverticulum is an acquired false diverticulum that arises from mucosal herniation through Killian's dehiscence, located between the oblique and transverse fibers of the inferior constrictor muscles. It occurs in older adults and typically presents with dysphagia, regurgitation, and halitosis(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 447)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Retrosternal goitre approach is?
questions.ref_book: Retrosternal goitre typically extends into the anterior mediastinum, but most cases can be managed via a transcervical approach, avoiding the morbidity of thoracic surgery. Sternotomy (trans-sternal) is reserved for cases where the goitre cannot be mobilized cervically, but this is rare(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 507)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: A middle-aged female with pulsatile neck swelling and potato-like consistency should not undergo?
questions.ref_book: A pulsatile, firm, potato-like neck swelling raises suspicion of a carotid body tumour. These are highly vascular paragangliomas, and performing a biopsy is contraindicated due to the risk of massive hemorrhage.(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 453)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Goitre and congenital deafness is called?
questions.ref_book: Pendred's syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive disorder where patients present with congenital sensorineural hearing loss and later develop a goitre(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 498)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Melanocytes are present in which layer of the skin?
questions.ref_book: Melanocytes are pigment-producing cells found in the stratum basalis (basal layer) of the epidermis. These cells synthesize melanin, which determines skin color and provides protection against UV radiation. They are not found in the upper layers such as spinosum, lucidum, or corneum(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 315)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) includes all of the flowing EXCEPT
questions.ref_book: The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is a clinical tool used to assess the level of consciousness in trauma and ICU patients. It evaluates three components: eye opening, verbal response, and motor response, with a total score ranging from 3 to 15. Pupillary reaction is important in neurological assessment but is not part of the GCS scoring system.(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 1153)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: The intra-cardiac lesions described in Tetralogy of Fallot are the following EXCEPT?
questions.ref_book: Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is a congenital heart defect involving four classic lesions: VSD, pulmonary stenosis, overriding aorta, and right ventricular hypertrophy. Coarctation of the aorta is a separate congenital condition characterized by narrowing of the aortic arch, and is not part of TOF, making it the correct exception(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 1195)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Lucid Interval is seen in?
questions.ref_book: A lucid interval refers to a temporary recovery of consciousness after an initial loss, followed by deterioration. This is classically associated with extradural (epidural) haematoma, typically due to middle meningeal artery rupture(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 1155)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: The following are Non-absorbable suture materials EXCEPT?
questions.ref_book: Polydioxanone (PDS) is a synthetic absorbable suture material used especially for deep tissue closure, offering prolonged strength before gradual absorption. In contrast, silk, nylon, and polypropylene are non-absorbable sutures commonly used for skin, vascular, and other permanent closures(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 1227)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Which is the most common cause for readmission after day care surgery?
questions.ref_book: Following day care (ambulatory) surgery, patients are discharged the same day, but some require unplanned readmission. The most frequent cause of readmission is post-operative nausea and vomiting (PONV), often triggered by anaesthetic agents or opioid use(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 1239)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: ERAS protocol includes all of the following except
questions.ref_book: The ERAS  (Enhanced Recovery After Surgery)protocol is a multimodal approach designed to improve recovery after surgery. It emphasizes minimally invasive surgery, pain control using nerve blocks, early mobilisation, and early feeding-not prolonged starvation.

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: DMAIC will come under which of the following performance methodology
questions.ref_book: DMAIC (Define, Measure, Analyze, Improve, Control) is a structured, data-focused methodology used in Six Sigma, which aims to improve processes by reducing variation and defects. It is not part of broader concepts like systems thinking or clinical microsystems, making Six Sigma the correct answer

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: The gastrinoma triangle is bounded by all except?
questions.option_a: Junction of the neck and body of the pancreas
questions.option_b: Junction between the pylorus and duodenum
questions.option_c: Junction of second and third part of duodenum
questions.option_d: Junction of cystic and common bile duct
questions.ref_book: "Gastrinoma triangle is bounded by: (1) junction of cystic and common bile duct, (2) junction of 2nd and 3rd part of duodenum, and (3) junction of neck and body of pancreas."(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 766)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Charcot's triad - Which is not a feature?
questions.ref_book:
Charcot's triad is a classical feature of acute cholangitis and includes:

Intermittent right upper quadrant pain

Intermittent fever with chills

Intermittent jaundice

Vomiting is not part of the triad, making it the correct exclusion.(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 702)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Most common organism causing ascending cholangitis is?
questions.ref_book:
E. coli is the predominant pathogen involved in ascending cholangitis, an infection of the biliary tract due to obstruction. Other organisms are also involved but less frequently.
(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 694)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: In obstructive jaundice, the gallbladder will not be palpable in?
questions.ref_book: In Klatskin tumors (hilar cholangiocarcinoma), the obstruction is proximal to the cystic duct entry, so the gallbladder does not distend, and thus is not palpable, unlike in lower biliary obstructions like carcinoma head of pancreas(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 713)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Moynihan's hump is a?
questions.ref_book: Moynihan's hump refers to a tortuous right hepatic artery that loops close to the cystic structures and can be mistaken for the cystic artery during cholecystectomy, posing a surgical risk(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 687)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Bile duct injury is classified by
questions.ref_book: Bismuth classification is the most widely used system to categorize bile duct injuries, especially post-cholecystectomy. It is based on the location of the stricture relative to the hepatic duct confluence, which is essential for planning reconstructive surgery(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 709)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Murphy's sign seen in
questions.ref_book: Murphy's sign is a key clinical sign in acute cholecystitis.
