It refers to pain and inspiratory arrest when the examiner's fingers palpating under the right costal margin come into contact with the inflamed gallbladder during deep inspiration.(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 695)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: According to AAST classification, grade 3 liver injury is?
questions.ref_book: The American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) classifies liver injuries from Grade I to VI. A Grade III liver injury includes a subcapsular hematoma involving more than 50% of the liver surface area or an intraparenchymal hematoma >10 cm, and/or a laceration >3 cm in depth.(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 645)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Biliary scintigraphy is useful in all except?
questions.ref_book: Biliary scintigraphy (HIDA or PIPIDA scan) is highly sensitive in diagnosing acute cholecystitis, bile leaks, and evaluating the functionality and patency of the biliary system, including bilioenteric anastomoses. However, it is not reliable for detecting choledocholithiasis (stones in the common bile duct), where ERCP, MRCP, or USG are more appropriate modalities. Therefore, option (d) is the correct exception(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 686)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Hepatocystic triangle is bounded by all except
questions.ref_book: The Calot's triangle (now often called the hepatocystic triangle) is a critical anatomical region in hepatobiliary surgery, especially during laparoscopic cholecystectomy, where the cystic artery is usually found. It is formed by the cystic duct, common hepatic duct, and inferior surface of the liver. The common bile duct lies outside this triangle, making it the correct exception(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 682)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: The following are true regarding pseudocyst of pancreas except
questions.ref_book: A pseudocyst of the pancreas is not a true cyst because it lacks an epithelial lining-instead, it is surrounded by granulation and fibrous tissue. It often contains amylase-rich fluid from pancreatic secretions. Smaller pseudocysts can resolve spontaneously, but those >6 cm or present for more than 6 weeks usually require intervention due to risk of infection, rupture, or pressure symptoms(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 746)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Obstructive shock is caused by all except
questions.ref_book: Obstructive shock results from physical blockage to blood flow in the heart or great vessels, such as in cardiac tamponade, tension pneumothorax, or massive pulmonary embolism. Myocardial infarction, on the other hand, causes cardiogenic shock due to pump failure, not mechanical obstruction. Therefore, MI is not a cause of obstructive shock(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 657)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: The following cancers can cause adrenal metastasis except
questions.ref_book: Adrenal metastases are frequently seen in malignancies such as lung, breast, colon, kidney, and melanoma. However, ovarian cancer is not a common source of adrenal metastasis. Therefore, it is correctly excluded from this list(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 766)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: The most common pancreatic neuroendocrine tumour is
questions.ref_book: Insulinomas are the most common type of pancreatic neuroendocrine tumour, typically benign and functional, arising from beta cells. They present with features of hypoglycemia due to inappropriate insulin secretion.

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: MEN type 4 is a
questions.option_b: It consists of MEN-I associated tumours
questions.option_c: Present with tumours of kidney and reproductive organs
questions.ref_book: Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 4 (MEN4) is a rare autosomal dominant syndrome caused by mutations in the CDKN1B gene (encoding p27, a cell-cycle regulator). It has clinical overlap with MEN1 (pituitary, parathyroid, and pancreatic tumors) but is distinguished by its association with tumors of the kidney, adrenal glands, and reproductive organs (ovaries, testes, uterus, cervix, prostate). It is not autosomal recessive, not limited to MEN1-type tumors, and is extremely rare, not common

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Rigler Triad is present in?
questions.ref_book: Rigler's triad is a diagnostic set of radiological features seen in gallstone ileus, a rare complication of chronic cholelithiasis where a gallstone enters the bowel via a fistula and causes obstruction. The triad includes: pneumobilia, ectopic gallstone, and intestinal obstruction(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 701)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: What is the ideal treatment for CE 5- Calcified hydatid cyst in liver?
questions.ref_book: CE5 hydatid cysts are completely calcified and considered inactive or dead cysts. Since they are unlikely to cause complications or recurrence, no active treatment is necessary. This conservative approach is called masterly inactivity. Invasive procedures like PAIR or surgery are not indicated unless complications develop(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 654)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Abdominal tuberculosis will present as all of the following except
questions.ref_book: Abdominal tuberculosis commonly affects the ileocaecal area and leads to ulcers, strictures, mass formation, and in some cases, a tubercular cocoon (encysted loops of bowel). Large bowel strictures are not a common feature, as the disease typically involves the small intestine, particularly the ileum, making large bowel strictures the correct exception(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 631)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: The following tests are used for small intestinal function except
questions.option_d: Wireless motility capsule- gut transit study
questions.ref_book: Dynamic MRI is primarily used for structural imaging (e.g., tumors, Crohn's disease, fistulae), not for functional testing of motility or transit in the small intestine. Functional tests include isotope scintigraphy, antro-duodenal manometry, and wireless motility capsule, all of which measure motility or transit times directly.

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: In Ogilvie's syndrome, there will be
questions.option_a: Colonic dilatation with obstructive symptoms without mechanical obstruction
questions.option_b: Colonic dilatation with non-obstructive symptoms without mechanical obstruction
questions.option_c: Colonic dilatation with obstructive symptoms with mechanical obstruction
questions.option_d: Colonic dilatation without obstructive symptoms with mechanical obstruction
questions.ref_book: Ogilvie's syndrome refers to acute colonic pseudo-obstruction with symptoms mimicking large bowel obstruction (like abdominal distension and pain) but without any actual mechanical cause. It typically occurs in elderly or postoperative patients. Radiologically, it shows colonic dilatation, but mechanical blockage is absent(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 968)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is
questions.ref_book: Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is an autosomal dominant genetic disorder marked by characteristic pigmented spots on lips and mucosa and hamartomatous polyps in the gastrointestinal tract, especially the small intestine. It carries an increased risk of several malignancies and is inherited in a dominant pattern(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 933)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Meckel's diverticulum is
questions.ref_book: Meckel's diverticulum is a true diverticulum arising from the antimesenteric border of the ileum, due to failure of involution of the vitello-intestinal (omphalomesenteric) duct. It may contain ectopic gastric or pancreatic tissue and can cause bleeding, obstruction, or inflammation, especially in children.(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 920)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Colostomy in abdomino-perineal resection is
questions.ref_book: Abdomino-perineal resection (APR) is a surgical procedure done for low rectal cancers where the anus, rectum, and sigmoid colon are removed. Since the anal route is removed, continuity of bowel is not restored, and a permanent end colostomy is created on the abdominal wall to divert feces(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 969)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: All of the following are true about Hirschsprung's disease except?
questions.option_d: The disease is rare in adults
questions.ref_book: Hirschsprung's disease is a congenital megacolon caused by absence of ganglion cells in the distal bowel. The disease classically presents in neonates, and urgent management is often required due to intestinal obstruction or enterocolitis, not elective handling. Hence, the claim that the baby is "dealt with electively" is false(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 945)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Red Currant Jelly stool seen in
questions.ref_book: Red currant jelly stools are a hallmark sign of intussusception, especially in children. The appearance results from a mixture of blood and mucus passed per rectum due to bowel wall ischemia and mucosal sloughing. This symptom, along with abdominal pain and a palpable mass, forms the classic triad in intussusception(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 988)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Irritable bowel syndrome is treated by?
questions.ref_book: Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) is a validated psychological treatment for irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). Other options listed like biofeedback and pelvic floor training are typically used in anorectal dysfunction, not classic IBS. Neuromodulation is not standard first-line for IBS

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: The following statement regarding Ulcerative colitis is true
questions.option_b: Mid transverse colon >4cm is called as toxic megacolon
questions.option_c: Presence of crypt distortion, crypt shortening with increased lymphocytes in biopsy
questions.option_d: Does not present with constitutional symptoms
questions.ref_book: Ulcerative colitis is a chronic inflammatory bowel disease that always involves the rectum and spreads proximally. Histological features include crypt architectural distortion, shortening, and dense lymphocytic infiltration. Toxic megacolon is diagnosed when colonic diameter exceeds 6?cm, not 4?cm. Constitutional symptoms like weight loss and fever are common, not absent(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 951)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Juvenile polyp in the colon is a type of?
questions.ref_book: uvenile polyps are hamartomas, i.e., benign overgrowths of normal tissue elements. They are commonly found in the rectum of young children and are usually not precancerous unless part of a polyposis syndrome(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 957)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Stage C in Duke's classification is?
questions.option_a: Involvement of muscularis propria without lymph node involvement
questions.option_b: Invasion of muscularis propria but without breaching it
questions.option_d: Invasion of serosa without lymph node involvement
questions.ref_book: Duke's staging is a classic system used for colorectal cancer. Stage C indicates that regional lymph nodes are involved, regardless of the depth of bowel wall invasion. It has important implications for prognosis and adjuvant therapy(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 963)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Backwash ileitis occurs in?
questions.ref_book: Backwash ileitis is a condition where inflammation of the terminal ileum occurs in the setting of ulcerative colitis, typically when the disease extends from the colon into the ileum. It affects around 5% of patients with severe pancolitis.(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 951)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: In a 30-year-old female, abdominal colicky pain which is insidious in onset reaches the peak and does not ease of completely between spasms. A possible diagnosis is
questions.ref_book: Ureteric colic presents as severe, colicky pain that often radiates from loin to groin and is accompanied by vomiting, sweating, and restlessness. Unlike classic colic, where the pain may ease between spasms, ureteric pain can remain continuously severe between peaks. The description of pain that does not ease off completely between spasms fits ureteric colic more than small bowel, biliary, or omental causes. Biliary colic may be intense but often has different radiation and associations

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: The cause of pseudomembranous colitis is?
questions.ref_book: Pseudomembranous colitis is an inflammatory condition of the colon caused by Clostridium difficile overgrowth, typically following broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy. It leads to toxin-mediated colonic injury, resulting in the formation of pseudomembranes(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 956)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: USG shows concentric target sign in
questions.ref_book: The "target sign" or "doughnut sign" on ultrasound is a classic diagnostic feature of intussusception, where one part of the intestine telescopes into another. This produces a characteristic concentric ring appearance on cross-sectional imaging.(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 987)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Extra-vaginal torsion of the testis is common in?
questions.ref_book: Extra-vaginal torsion of the testis, also known as neonatal torsion, typically occurs in newborns and is characterized by twisting of the entire spermatic cord along with the tunica vaginalis. This contrasts with intra-vaginal torsion seen in older children and adolescents, where the testis twists within the tunica vaginalis due to a bell-clapper deformity. Since the tunica is not yet adherent in neonates, the entire unit rotates, making this type typical in the neonatal period

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: The ideal time for orchidopexy in a child with palpable undescended testis?
questions.ref_book: (SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 1140)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: An old man presented with tender scrotal swelling and black discoloration of scrotal skin. What is the diagnosis?
questions.ref_book: Fournier's gangrene is a severe, rapidly progressive infection of the perineum and scrotum, typically seen in elderly men, often diabetics. It presents with painful scrotal swelling, tenderness, and black discoloration of the skin, indicating necrosis. The condition is a surgical emergency requiring prompt debridement and antibiotics(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 1128)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: In varicose veins, which is the open surgical technique
questions.ref_book: Saphenofemoral junction ligation is a traditional open surgical procedure for varicose veins. It involves ligating and often stripping the long saphenous vein at its junction with the femoral vein. In contrast, radiofrequency ablation, endovenous laser therapy, and foam sclerotherapy are minimally invasive or endovenous techniques(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 259)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: The following are the risk factors for thrombosis except
questions.ref_book: Thrombosis is associated with several clinical risk factors, including immobilization, hormone replacement therapy, COVID-19 infection, and others. However, female gender alone is not considered an independent risk factor unless associated with specific conditions like pregnancy or estrogen therapy. Therefore, it is correctly excluded in this list

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: According to British classification, Class 2 stockings exerts pressure of
questions.ref_book: The British classification categorizes compression stockings based on the pressure exerted at the ankle. Class 2 stockings provide 18-24 mmHg, making them ideal for treating varicose veins, chronic venous insufficiency, and after sclerotherapy(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 267)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: According to Well's criteria, deep vein thrombosis is most common in?
questions.option_b: Patients bed-ridden for more than 3 days
questions.ref_book: The Wells Criteria is a clinical tool used to estimate the probability of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) based on various risk factors. Among the listed options, prolonged immobility (e.g., bedridden for more than 3 days) is a key risk factor that carries significant weight in the scoring system. Although other factors like tachycardia and edema may be associated signs, recent immobilization is one of the most predictive and weighted elements for DVT in Wells' criteria(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 251)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: In Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome, all are true except?
questions.option_d: Large lateral anomalous axial vein will be present
questions.ref_book: Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome is a congenital vascular malformation characterized by a triad of: port-wine stain (naevus flammeus), bone and soft tissue hypertrophy, and venous malformations such as anomalous axial veins or varicose veins. However, the presence of arteriovenous fistulae is not a part of Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome-it defines Parkes-Weber syndrome, a distinct clinical entity. Therefore, option (c) is the correct exception(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 268)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: The following are risk factors for deep vein thrombosis except
questions.ref_book: While cardiac failure, obesity, and pregnancy are well-established risk factors for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) due to stasis and hypercoagulable states, varicose veins are not considered a major independent risk factor for DVT. In fact, SRB notes that DVT is a rare complication (<0.5%) of varicose veins, indicating a weak association. Therefore, option b) varicose vein is the correct answer as it is the exception among listed risk factors(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 248)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Which of the following is not included in the primary survey of a trauma patient?
questions.option_b: CECT abdomen to look for bleeding
questions.ref_book: The primary survey in trauma management is a rapid assessment using the ABCDE approach: Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, and Exposure. It is designed to quickly identify and treat life-threatening conditions. CECT abdomen is a diagnostic investigation, which is part of the secondary survey, not the primary. Hence, it is correctly excluded from the initial assessment(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 32)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Necrotizing fasciitis is caused by the following organism?
questions.ref_book: Necrotizing fasciitis is a severe, rapidly progressive soft tissue infection involving fascia and subcutaneous tissue. The most commonly implicated organism is group A beta-hemolytic streptococci, which releases toxins and enzymes that cause tissue destruction. Early diagnosis and aggressive surgical debridement along with antibiotics are critical due to its life-threatening nature.(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 73)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Criteria for Damage Control Surgery are all except?
questions.ref_book: Damage Control Surgery (DCS) is indicated in patients with the "lethal triad" of hypothermia, acidosis, and coagulopathy, often with elevated serum lactate > 2 mmol/L. A lactate level < 2 implies adequate perfusion and is not an indication for DCS, hence it's the correct exception(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 34)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: All statements are true regarding necrotizing fasciitis except
questions.option_a: Meleney's gangrene is type of necrotizing fasciitis
questions.ref_book: Necrotizing fasciitis is a severe and often polymicrobial soft tissue infection involving rapid fascial and subcutaneous tissue destruction. Meleney's gangrene is a recognized subtype. It is a surgical emergency due to its high mortality, requiring prompt debridement

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: What is the size of the blade used in Incision and Drainage?
questions.ref_book: For incision and drainage (I&D) procedures, especially for abscesses, the No. 11 blade is ideal due to its sharp, pointed tip, allowing for precise stab incisions into fluctuant areas. Other blade sizes like 15 (small curved), 22 (large general), or 13 are not typically preferred for I&D(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 55)

questions.subject: GENERAL SURGERY
questions.que: Damage control surgery depends on the following factors except
questions.ref_book: Damage control surgery (DCS) is a life-saving strategy in trauma patients focused on controlling bleeding and contamination quickly, followed by definitive surgery later. It is primarily indicated when the lethal triad-hypothermia, coagulopathy, and acidosis-is present. Duration of surgery is a consideration but not a defining factor for initiating DCS(SRB's Manual of Surgery,7th Edition, Page No : 34)

questions.que: The normal adult uterus is:

questions.subject: GYNAECOLOGY
questions.que: The middle layer of the uterus is called:
questions.ref_book: The myometrium is the middle muscular layer of the uterus, made up of smooth muscle fibers. It is responsible for uterine contractions during menstruation and labor. The endometrium is the inner mucosal lining, and the perimetrium is the outer serosal covering. Mesometrium, in contrast, refers to a portion of the broad ligament and is not a uterine wall layer(Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology 18th Edition, Page No : 18)

questions.que: Surrogacy is indicated in all except
questions.ref_book:
Surrogacy is indicated when a woman cannot carry a pregnancy due to absent uterus (M?llerian agenesis, hysterectomy), premature ovarian failure with inability to sustain pregnancy, or medical conditions making pregnancy unsafe (including advanced maternal age with poor uterine receptivity).
However, hereditary/genetic diseases are not an indication for surrogacy - instead, preimplantation genetic testing (PGT) or donor gametes are the appropriate options

questions.subject: GYNAECOLOGY
questions.que: Which condition is not commonly associated with PCOS?
questions.ref_book: PCOS is commonly associated with obesity, hirsutism, and hyperinsulinemia due to insulin resistance. However, hyperthyroidism is not a feature of PCOS. Thyroid dysfunction may be evaluated during infertility workup but is not part of the syndrome itself.(Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology 18th Edition, Page No : 321)

questions.subject: GYNAECOLOGY
questions.que: Most common gene mutation in fibroid
questions.ref_book: The most common gene mutation in uterine fibroids (leiomyomas) is in the MED12 gene (Mediator complex subunit 12), seen in about 70% of cases. Other less frequent mutations include HMGA2 rearrangements, FH (fumarate hydratase) mutations, and others. COL4A5-A6 mutations are related to Alport syndrome, not fibroids

questions.subject: GYNAECOLOGY
questions.que: Ulipristal acetate as emergency contraception is effective up to:
questions.ref_book: Ulipristal acetate is an effective emergency contraceptive that works by delaying ovulation. Unlike levonorgestrel, which is effective up to 72 hours, ulipristal is effective up to 120 hours (5 days) after unprotected sex, making it a preferred option in later presentations(Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology 18th Edition, Page No : 274)

questions.subject: GYNAECOLOGY
questions.que: The most reliable method of contraception is:
questions.ref_book: Tubal ligation, a permanent method of contraception, has the lowest failure rate among commonly used methods, making it the most reliable. While IUDs and OCPs are effective, they carry higher typical-use failure rates. Condoms have the highest user-dependent failure rates among the listed options(Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology 18th Edition, Page No : 276)

questions.subject: GYNAECOLOGY
questions.que: OCPs primarily prevent pregnancy by:
questions.ref_book:
Combined oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) work primarily by inhibiting ovulation through suppression of the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis. Estrogen and progestin in the pills prevent the LH surge required for ovulation. Secondary mechanisms include thickening of cervical mucus and altering the endometrial lining, but these are not the primary actions.
(Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology 18th Edition, Page No : 268)

questions.subject: GYNAECOLOGY
questions.que: In a reproductive-age woman with sudden lower abdominal pain and positive pregnancy test, suspect:
questions.ref_book: In a reproductive-age woman presenting with acute lower abdominal pain and a positive pregnancy test, ectopic pregnancy is the most critical diagnosis to consider due to the risk of rupture and hemorrhage. While appendicitis, ovarian cysts, and PID are differential diagnoses, ectopic pregnancy is the most urgent and life-threatening.(Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology 18th Edition, Page No : 232)

questions.subject: GYNAECOLOGY
questions.que: What is the gold standard diagnostic method for endometriosis?
questions.ref_book:
Laparoscopy is considered the gold standard for diagnosing endometriosis because it enables direct inspection of pelvic organs and biopsy of suspected lesions for histopathological confirmation. While ultrasound and MRI may help in detecting certain features, they lack the sensitivity and specificity of laparoscopy.
(Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology 18th Edition, Page No : 175)

questions.subject: GYNAECOLOGY
questions.que: Most appropriate investigation in a 45-year-old woman with AUB:
questions.ref_book: In a 45-year-old woman with abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB), the most appropriate investigation is endometrial biopsy to rule out endometrial hyperplasia or carcinoma, especially in perimenopausal age. While Pap smear and pregnancy tests may be part of the general evaluation, they do not assess the endometrial lining. FSH levels have limited role in AUB workup(Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology 18th Edition, Page No : 131)

questions.subject: GYNAECOLOGY
questions.que: First-line management of AUB due to anovulation in adolescents:
questions.ref_book:
In adolescents, anovulatory cycles are common and lead to abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB). The first-line management is combined oral contraceptive pills (OCPs), which help regulate menstrual cycles and stabilize the endometrium. Hysterectomy is inappropriate, iron is supportive, and D&C is reserved for unresponsive or severe cases.
(Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology 18th Edition, Page No : 131)

questions.que: A molar pregnancy typically presents with:
questions.ref_book: Molar pregnancy (hydatidiform mole) is characterized by vaginal bleeding, a uterus larger than expected, and very high ?-hCG levels. Fetal heart sounds are absent, and uterine size is usually increased-not normal or small(Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology 18th Edition, Page No : 498)

questions.subject: GYNAECOLOGY
questions.que: Treatment of choice for CIN III:
questions.ref_book: CIN III represents high-grade dysplasia or carcinoma in situ and poses a significant risk of progression to invasive cancer. Therefore, LEEP is the treatment of choice as it removes the entire transformation zone and affected tissue. Observation or Pap smear follow-up is inadequate for CIN III, and antibiotics have no role.(Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology 18th Edition, Page No : 426)

questions.subject: GYNAECOLOGY
questions.que: Which gynecologic malignancy has the worst prognosis?
questions.ref_book: Ovarian cancer is the gynecologic malignancy with the worst prognosis, largely because it is usually diagnosed at an advanced stage due to nonspecific symptoms and lack of effective screening. In contrast, cervical and endometrial cancers are often detected earlier, and vulvar cancer generally progresses more slowly(Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology 18th Edition, Page No : 473)

questions.subject: GYNAECOLOGY
questions.que: The most common risk factor for endometrial cancer is:
questions.ref_book: Obesity significantly increases the risk of endometrial cancer because adipose tissue enhances peripheral conversion of androgens to estrogens, resulting in unopposed estrogen stimulation of the endometrium. This promotes hyperplasia and potential malignant transformation. Other factors like smoking or early menopause are less influential, and multiple pregnancies are actually protective.(Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology 18th Edition, Page No : 447)

questions.subject: GYNAECOLOGY
questions.que: Intraoperative ureteral injury is most commonly associated with:
questions.ref_book: Hysterectomy is the leading cause of intraoperative ureteral injury, due to the close anatomical relationship of the ureter with the uterine artery and cervix. The risk increases especially in distorted anatomy or in malignancy.(Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology 18th Edition, Page No : 559)

questions.subject: GYNAECOLOGY
questions.que: Sonohysterography is best for:
questions.ref_book: Sonohysterography (saline infusion sonography) is a specialized ultrasound technique that enhances visualization of the uterine cavity by instilling saline. It is particularly useful for evaluating intrauterine pathologies such as endometrial polyps, fibroids, and adhesions, which are often missed on routine ultrasound. It is not the investigation of choice for cervical cancer staging, ovarian masses, or uterine perforation.(Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology 18th Edition, Page No : 546)

questions.subject: GYNAECOLOGY
questions.que: Difficulties in Minimally Invasive Surgery are all except
questions.ref_book: In minimally invasive (laparoscopic) surgery, the challenges include loss of direct palpation of tissues, restricted movement of instruments due to trocar entry, and counter-intuitive motion (movement of instruments in opposite direction). One drawback is actually the lack of true three-dimensional vision in standard laparoscopy (though robotic systems have improved this). So "presence of 3D vision" is not a difficulty, making it the exception

questions.subject: GYNAECOLOGY
questions.que: The most common symptom of PID is:
questions.ref_book: Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID) typically presents with lower abdominal pain, making it the most common and earliest symptom. While vaginal discharge, dyspareunia, and irregular bleeding can also occur, they are less consistent and secondary in presentation. Prompt recognition is crucial to prevent long-term complications like infertility(Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology 18th Edition, Page No : 345)

questions.subject: GYNAECOLOGY
questions.que: Standard treatment for PID includes:
questions.ref_book: The standard treatment for PID involves broad-spectrum antibiotics that target likely causative organisms, including Chlamydia and Gonorrhea. Regimens typically combine ceftriaxone, doxycycline, and metronidazole. Antifungals and antivirals are not effective, and NSAIDs only offer symptomatic relief but do not address the infection(Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology 18th Edition, Page No : 345)

questions.subject: MICROBIOLOGY(CBME)
questions.que: A renal transplant patient developed fever with bilateral diffuse interstitial pneumonitis after two months. The most probable cause of infection is:
questions.ref_book: In renal transplant patients, cytomegalovirus (CMV) is the most common opportunistic infection occurring within 1-6 months post-transplant. It typically presents with fever, malaise, leukopenia, and bilateral diffuse interstitial pneumonitis, which is considered a hallmark feature. Other options like hepatitis C, herpes simplex, and HPV do not cause this characteristic presentation, making CMV the most probable cause in this case

questions.subject: MICROBIOLOGY(CBME)
questions.que: Best diagnostic marker for rheumatoid arthritis is:
questions.ref_book: The best diagnostic marker for rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is anti-citrullinated peptide antibody (ACPA/anti-CCP) because of its high specificity (?95-98%) for RA, making it superior to rheumatoid factor (RF) or other nonspecific markers. C-reactive protein (CRP) is useful to monitor inflammation and disease activity but is not diagnostic. Antistreptolysin O (ASO) is used for post-streptococcal conditions, not RA. Rapid Plasma Reagin (RPR) is a screening test for syphilis, unrelated to RA

questions.subject: MICROBIOLOGY(CBME)
questions.que: Vaccination is based on the principle of:
questions.ref_book: Vaccination works by exposing the immune system to an antigen in a safe form (killed, attenuated, or component of a pathogen), which stimulates the development of memory B and T lymphocytes without causing disease. On subsequent exposure to the actual pathogen, these memory cells mount a rapid and strong immune response, preventing infection or reducing disease severity. Thus, the fundamental principle behind vaccination is immunological memory

questions.subject: MICROBIOLOGY(CBME)
questions.que: Which of the following is the most common cause of Tinea capitis?
questions.ref_book: Tinea capitis, a dermatophyte infection of the scalp, is most commonly caused by Trichophyton tonsurans, especially in children. It produces both endothrix and ectothrix infections and spreads through direct contact or fomites. While Trichophyton rubrum is the most frequent cause of dermatophytosis in general, it rarely involves the scalp. Microsporum canis can cause tinea capitis but is less common, and Epidermophyton floccosum does not infect hair, so it is not a cause

questions.subject: OBSTETRICS
questions.que: All of the following can cause DIC except:
questions.ref_book: Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is a consumptive coagulopathy triggered by massive tissue injury, release of procoagulants, or endothelial damage. Obstetric causes include abruptio placentae, intrauterine death (retained dead fetus), and amniotic fluid embolism. Diabetes mellitus does not directly cause DIC, though it may predispose to vascular complications

questions.subject: OBSTETRICS
questions.que: Intermittent cell predominance is a cytology seen in
questions.ref_book: In pregnancy, the high levels of progesterone result in the predominance of intermediate cells in vaginal cytology. These cells are distinct from the superficial cells seen under estrogen influence (e.g., pre-ovulatory phase). Intermediate cell dominance is thus a cytological hallmark of the gestational hormonal environment.

questions.subject: OBSTETRICS
questions.que: Not used in hypertensive crisis
questions.ref_book: Methyldopa is not used in hypertensive crisis due to its slow onset; others are used.

questions.subject: OBSTETRICS
questions.que: Likely size of uterus 8 weeks post-partum is
questions.ref_book: Immediately after delivery, the uterus weighs about 1000 g. By the end of the 1st week postpartum, it decreases to ~500 g, by 2 weeks it is around 300 g, and by 6-8 weeks postpartum, it returns close to its non-pregnant size of ~100 g

questions.subject: OBSTETRICS
questions.que: During foetal life, Maximum growth is caused by
questions.ref_book: Insulin plays a major role in promoting fetal growth. Unlike growth hormone, which is not significantly active during intrauterine life, insulin enhances nutrient storage and tissue development by promoting glycogen, protein, and fat synthesis. Fetal macrosomia is commonly seen in diabetic mothers due to elevated fetal insulin levels, highlighting its central role

questions.subject: OBSTETRICS
questions.que: Alpha and Beta segments are not seen in
questions.ref_book: FSH and hCG are glycoprotein hormones made of alpha and beta subunits. These alpha subunits are identical across hormones like TSH and LH, while the beta subunit determines the hormone's function. In contrast, insulin is a peptide hormone composed of A and B chains linked by disulfide bonds-not alpha and beta subunits. Prolactin, while a protein hormone, is a single-chain polypeptide without alpha-beta division.

questions.subject: OBSTETRICS
questions.que: Post partum decidual secretions are known as
questions.ref_book: Lochia is the normal uterine discharge seen in the postpartum period. It contains a mix of blood, mucus, and desquamated decidual tissue, reflecting the involution process of the uterus. It evolves in stages: lochia rubra, serosa, and alba. This is distinct from abnormal vaginal bleeding or pathological conditions like vasa previa(Mudaliar & Menon's Clinical Obstetrics, 13th Edition, Page No: 122)

questions.que: Ritgen manoeuvre is performed in shoulder dystocia
questions.option_a: Delivery of head in breech presentation
questions.option_b: Delivery of legs in breech presentation
questions.option_c: Delivery of head in normal delivery
questions.option_d: Delivery of legs in normal delivery
questions.ref_book: Ritgen manoeuvre is a controlled technique used during normal vaginal delivery to assist in the safe delivery of the fetal head. It involves supporting the perineum and controlling the extension of the head to minimize perineal trauma(Mudaliar & Menon's Clinical Obstetrics, 13th Edition, Page No: 144)

questions.subject: OBSTETRICS
questions.que: Indication of induction of labour is
questions.ref_book: Gestational hypertension at term is a clear and accepted indication for induction of labour because continuing the pregnancy could endanger both the mother and fetus. In contrast, conditions such as placenta previa are contraindications to induction due to the risk of hemorrhage. Breech presentation and maternal heart disease are generally considered for cesarean section(Mudaliar & Menon's Clinical Obstetrics, 13th Edition, Page No: 164)

questions.subject: OBSTETRICS
questions.que: In BISHOP score, all are included except
questions.ref_book:
The Bishop score is used to assess the readiness of the cervix for induction of labour. It includes: dilatation, effacement, cervical consistency, position, and station of the fetal head. The interspinous diameter is a pelvic anatomical measurement and is not part of the Bishop scoring system.
(Mudaliar & Menon's Clinical Obstetrics, 13th Edition, Page No: 166)

questions.subject: OBSTETRICS
questions.que: Submento bregmatic diameter is
questions.ref_book: The submento-bregmatic diameter is the distance between the junction of the floor of the mouth and neck to the bregma (anterior fontanelle). It measures 9.5 cm and represents the presenting diameter in face presentations when the head is fully extended. It is one of the smallest diameters of the fetal skull and can usually pass through the pelvis in face presentation if the mento-anterior position is maintained(Mudaliar & Menon's Clinical Obstetrics, 13th Edition, Page No: 65)

questions.subject: OPHTHALMOLOGY
questions.que: All are true about posterior capsular opacification except
questions.option_c: Lower rates with silicon lenses with square edges
questions.ref_book:
Posterior capsular opacification (PCO, also called after-cataract or secondary cataract) occurs due to proliferation and migration of residual lens epithelial cells, especially subcapsular cells.

It is more common in younger patients because their lens epithelial cells are more metabolically active and proliferative.

The risk is reduced with modern IOL designs, especially acrylic or silicone lenses with sharp square edges, which create a barrier effect.

The incidence of PCO indeed increases with time after surgery, varying with the duration.

?? Hence, the statement "Higher rates with old patients" is false

questions.subject: ORTHOPEDICS
questions.que: Ponsetti cast is used for which condition
questions.ref_book: The Ponsetti method is a non-operative treatment specifically designed for CTEV, commonly known as clubfoot. It uses sequential manipulation and casting (Ponsetti casts) to gradually correct the foot deformities in a defined order: cavus, adduction, varus, and finally equinus. This method is highly effective when started early in life and is the gold standard for managing idiopathic clubfoot(Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 7th Edition, Page No : 210)

questions.subject: ORTHOPEDICS
questions.que: Barlow test is used in which condition
questions.ref_book: Barlow's test is specifically used to detect instability in infants with suspected Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip (DDH). It helps identify a dislocatable but not yet dislocated hip by applying pressure to provoke dislocation. A positive test elicits a ?clunk' as the femoral head exits or re-enters the acetabulum. This makes Barlow's test a key diagnostic tool for early detection of DDH in neonates(Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 7th Edition, Page No : 215)

questions.subject: ORTHOPEDICS
questions.que: Shenton's line in hip X-rays is an imaginary line?
questions.option_a: Along inferior border of Obturator foramen to medial cortex of neck and shaft of femur
questions.option_b: Along superior border of Obturator foramen to medial cortex of neck and shaft of femur
questions.option_c: Not altered in Neck of femur fracture
questions.option_d: Not visible in routine unilateral hip X-ray
questions.ref_book: Shenton's line is a useful radiological landmark seen on X-rays of the pelvis. It is an imaginary curved line formed by the inferior border of the superior pubic ramus (or obturator foramen) and continues along the medial edge of the femoral neck and shaft.(Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 7th Edition, Page No : 217)

questions.subject: ORTHOPEDICS
questions.que: Triple Dislocation of Knee joint is a complication of
questions.ref_book: (Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 7th Edition, Page No : 222)

questions.subject: ORTHOPEDICS
questions.que: Onion Peel appearance on X-ray is seen in
questions.ref_book: The "onion-peel appearance" on X-ray is a classic radiological feature of Ewing's sarcoma, which typically arises in the diaphysis of long bones in children and adolescents. The layered periosteal reaction caused by rapid tumor growth lifts the periosteum, leading to characteristic concentric new bone formation. This finding helps differentiate Ewing's sarcoma from other bone tumors like osteosarcoma (which shows sun-ray appearance) and GCT (which is epiphyseal and soap-bubble in appearance).(Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 7th Edition, Page No : 237)

questions.subject: ORTHOPEDICS
questions.que: The following are ultrasound features of metastatic lymph nodes EXCEPT?
questions.ref_book:
Metastatic lymph nodes typically show:

A hypoechoic pattern on ultrasound due to cellular infiltration.

A rounded shape instead of the normal oval or bean shape.

Loss of the fatty hilum, which is normally seen in healthy nodes.

In contrast, a bean-shaped (oval) node with a visible fatty hilum is characteristic of normal or reactive lymph nodes, not metastatic ones. Hence, "Bean in shape" is the EXCEPTION and the correct answer.

questions.subject: ORTHOPEDICS
questions.que: Hutchinson's teeth is associated with?
questions.ref_book: Hutchinson's teeth are a classical dental abnormality seen in congenital syphilis, caused by intrauterine infection with Treponema pallidum. The teeth are small, widely spaced, and notched incisors. This feature forms part of Hutchinson's triad (with interstitial keratitis and sensorineural deafness), which is pathognomonic for congenital syphilis

questions.subject: ORTHOPEDICS
questions.que: Fallen fragment sign in cystic bone lesions is related to?
questions.ref_book: The fallen fragment sign is a radiological hallmark of a unicameral (simple) bone cyst. It refers to a cortical bone fragment that has broken and fallen into the cyst cavity, visible on X-ray. This sign confirms the presence of a fluid-filled lesion like a simple bone cyst and helps distinguish it from other lytic lesions such as fibrous dysplasia or enchondroma, which do not exhibit this feature(Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 7th Edition, Page No : 245)

questions.subject: ORTHOPEDICS
questions.que: Odontogenic tumor common in jaw and tibia are?
questions.ref_book: Ameloblastoma is a rare odontogenic tumour that most frequently affects the mandible (jaw) and sometimes the tibia. It is slow-growing but locally aggressive, often presenting as a painless swelling and expansion of bone. It is distinctly different from other tumors like fibrous dysplasia or chondrosarcoma, and its location in both jaw and tibia is a characteristic feature, making option d the correct choice(Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 7th Edition, Page No : 245)

questions.subject: ORTHOPEDICS
questions.que: Common arthritis affecting Temperomandibular joints?
questions.ref_book: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory disease that can affect any synovial joint, including the temporomandibular joint (TMJ). While the small joints of the hands and feet are more commonly involved, TMJ arthritis is a recognized feature in longstanding RA. Other types of arthritis like osteoarthritis or gout more commonly affect weight-bearing joints, not TMJ(Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 7th Edition, Page No : 280)

questions.subject: ORTHOPEDICS
questions.que: U slab is used in the treatment of which fracture
questions.ref_book: The U-slab is a type of plaster splint designed specifically to immobilize the humerus, particularly in fractures involving the shaft or proximal region. Its U-shape conforms to the upper arm and shoulder anatomy, preventing angulation and allowing for healing while minimizing motion(Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 7th Edition, Page No : 291)

questions.subject: ORTHOPEDICS
questions.que: Nerve involved in Meralgia Paresthesia
questions.ref_book: Meralgia paraesthetica is caused by compression or entrapment of the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh, often under the inguinal ligament. This results in burning, tingling, or numbness over the anterolateral thigh. It is a purely sensory nerve, and motor function is unaffected(Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 7th Edition, Page No : 305)

questions.subject: ORTHOPEDICS
questions.que: McMurray test is done to detect
questions.ref_book: The McMurray test is a clinical maneuver used to diagnose meniscal tears in the knee. It involves flexing and extending the knee while rotating the tibia. A painful click or snap felt during the maneuver is indicative of a torn meniscus(Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 7th Edition, Page No : 347)

questions.subject: ORTHOPEDICS
questions.que: Shepherd's Crook deformity is a complication of
questions.ref_book: Shepherd's Crook deformity is a pathological varus angulation of the proximal femur, giving it a curved shape resembling a shepherd's crook. It is a classic feature of fibrous dysplasia, where the normal bone is replaced by fibrous tissue, leading to weakening and progressive deformity due to repeated microfractures(Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 7th Edition, Page No : 360)

questions.subject: ORTHOPEDICS
questions.que: Dentinogenesis imperfecta (D1) in osteogenesis imperfecta is?
questions.option_a: Always associated with all cases of osteogenesis imperfecta
questions.option_b: Due to defect in Type II collagen
questions.option_d: Clinically manifests as brown/yellow discoloration of teeth
questions.ref_book: Dentinogenesis imperfecta (D1) occurs in some (not all) cases of osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) and is characterized by defective dentin formation. It more commonly affects the primary (deciduous) teeth, leading to discoloration (blue, brown, or yellow), translucency, and rapid wear due to enamel chipping

questions.subject: ORTHOPEDICS
questions.que: The dose of radiation in mammography is approximately?
questions.ref_book: Mammography is a low-dose X-ray imaging technique used primarily for breast cancer screening. The typical radiation dose per view in mammography is approximately 0.1 centigray (cGy), which is equivalent to 1 milligray (mGy).

questions.subject: ORTHOPEDICS
questions.que: Galeazzi fracture is?
questions.option_b: Fracture of distal radius with distal radio ulnar joint dislocation
questions.option_c: Fracture of radius with dislocation in proximal site and dislocation of elbow
questions.ref_book: A Galeazzi fracture involves a fracture of the distal one-third of the radius coupled with dislocation of the distal radio-ulnar joint (DRUJ). It is an unstable injury requiring accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment to avoid long-term disability of the wrist. This combination is characteristic and helps distinguish it from other forearm fracture patterns like the Monteggia fracture, which affects the proximal ulna and radial head.(Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 7th Edition, Page No : 3)

questions.subject: ORTHOPEDICS
questions.que: Fracture base of 5th metatarsal is?
questions.ref_book: A Jones fracture refers specifically to a fracture at the base of the 5th metatarsal, often resulting from inversion injuries of the foot. It is an important fracture to recognize due to its relatively poor healing because of limited blood supply in that area(Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 7th Edition, Page No : 3)

questions.subject: ORTHOPEDICS
questions.que: What characterizes a Gustilo-Anderson Type IIIA open fracture?
questions.option_b: Contamination with adequate soft tissue coverage
questions.ref_book: Type IIIA open fractures are severe injuries involving extensive soft tissue damage, but they differ from IIIB and IIIC in that the bone still retains adequate soft tissue coverage. This makes surgical management feasible without needing complex plastic reconstructive procedures(Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 7th Edition, Page No : 22)

questions.subject: ORTHOPEDICS
questions.que: A patient is received in Triage with Contaminated wound. The best solution for wound wash is
questions.ref_book: For contaminated wounds, especially in trauma or open fractures, normal saline is the preferred solution for initial wound irrigation. It is isotonic, non-toxic to tissues, and effective in mechanically flushing out debris and bacteria. Other solutions like Betadine can be cytotoxic to tissues, and dextrose-containing solutions are not recommended for irrigation. Hence, normal saline is the safest and most effective choice(Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 7th Edition, Page No : 23)

questions.subject: ORTHOPEDICS
questions.que: Fat embolism is characterized by all EXCEPT?
questions.ref_book: Fat embolism syndrome (FES) typically presents with tachycardia, hypoxemia, and fat globules in urine or sputum. However, thrombocytopenia (low platelet count) is often seen due to platelet consumption during microvascular obstruction-not thrombocytosis (elevated platelet count).(Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 7th Edition, Page No : 44)

questions.subject: ORTHOPEDICS
questions.que: The most reliable early sign of compartment syndrome is:
questions.ref_book: In compartment syndrome, the most dependable early clinical sign is pain on passive stretching of the involved muscles. This pain results from ischaemia and increasing compartmental pressure. Other signs like pallor, paresthesia, or paralysis occur later and are less specific(Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 7th Edition, Page No : 48)

questions.subject: ORTHOPEDICS
questions.que: Avascular necrosis of bone can happen in the following condition?
questions.ref_book: Avascular necrosis (AVN) refers to the death of bone tissue due to loss of blood supply. It commonly occurs following a fracture of the neck of the femur, because the blood supply to the femoral head is precarious and can be easily disrupted(Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 7th Edition, Page No : 51)

questions.subject: ORTHOPEDICS
questions.que: Which of the following is a late complication of fracture
questions.ref_book: Heterotopic ossification, also known as myositis ossificans, is a late complication of fractures, where abnormal bone forms in soft tissues around the injury site. It differs from early complications like fat embolism, compartment syndrome, or gas gangrene, which occur acutely or within days of injury. Heterotopic ossification usually appears weeks after trauma and can restrict joint movement(Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 7th Edition, Page No : 52)

questions.subject: ORTHOPEDICS
questions.que: Foot Drop is seen in which nerve injury
questions.ref_book: Foot drop is characterized by the inability to dorsiflex the foot, resulting in dragging of the toes during walking. This condition is typically due to paralysis of the dorsiflexor muscles, which are supplied by the common peroneal nerve. (Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 7th Edition, Page No : 63)

questions.subject: ORTHOPEDICS
questions.que: A patient complains of flexion of interphalangeal joints and hyperextension of MCP joints of the hand. He is most likely suffering from?
questions.ref_book: Claw hand is a classical deformity due to ulnar nerve palsy, where there is paralysis of the medial two lumbricals and interossei. As a result, the unopposed action of the long extensors causes hyperextension of the MCP joints, while the long flexors cause flexion of the IP joints. This produces a claw-like posture of the hand, especially involving the ring and little fingers(Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 7th Edition, Page No : 64)

questions.subject: ORTHOPEDICS
questions.que: Froment's sign is positive in case of weakness of?
questions.ref_book: Froment's sign becomes positive when there is paralysis or weakness of the adductor pollicis muscle, which is innervated by the ulnar nerve. To compensate for this weakness, the patient recruits the flexor pollicis longus (median nerve) to grip the paper, resulting in flexion at the interphalangeal joint of the thumb - a classic positive Froment's sign. This sign indicates ulnar nerve palsy(Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 7th Edition, Page No : 67)

questions.subject: ORTHOPEDICS
questions.que: If a patient is able to tolerate an oropharyngeal airway, it indicates?
questions.option_c: Need for tracheal intubation is more
questions.option_d: It is not a worrisome sign
questions.ref_book: If a patient tolerates an oropharyngeal airway, it typically indicates a reduced level of consciousness, because a conscious patient usually gags or resists its placement. This tolerance suggests airway protective reflexes are impaired, making tracheal intubation more likely to be necessary to secure the airway and prevent aspiration. Therefore, it is not a reassuring sign-it is an indication for escalation in airway management.

questions.subject: ORTHOPEDICS
questions.que: A patient after sustaining high velocity injury due to fall from height was seen in Triage. He was having a deformity in his right upper limb as if a student is raising his hand to ask a doubt. What could be the probable diagnosed?
questions.ref_book: Inferior dislocation of the shoulder, also called luxatio erecta, is rare but has a distinctive clinical appearance: the arm is hyperabducted and fixed overhead, as if the patient is raising their hand in class. This presentation is classic and helps differentiate it from anterior or posterior dislocations, which have different arm positions. Therefore, the correct diagnosis based on the described posture is inferior shoulder dislocation(Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 7th Edition, Page No : 88)

questions.subject: ORTHOPEDICS
questions.que: Patient presented with paresthesia and loss of sensation over lower part of deltoid. X-ray showed fracture surgical neck of humerus. Likely nerve to be involved is?
questions.ref_book: The axillary nerve is at risk of injury in fractures of the surgical neck of the humerus, due to its close anatomical relationship as it winds around the surgical neck. Clinical signs include paresthesia or loss of sensation over the lower part of the deltoid and deltoid muscle weakness or wasting(Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 7th Edition, Page No : 90)

questions.subject: ORTHOPEDICS
questions.que: Vessel injured in Supracondylar humerus fracture
questions.ref_book: The brachial artery is the most commonly injured vessel in supracondylar fractures of the humerus, particularly in children. This injury occurs due to the sharp edge of the proximal fragment damaging the artery, which may lead to complications such as Volkmann's ischemia or even gangrene. Prompt recognition and management are essential to preserve limb viability(Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 7th Edition, Page No : 97)

questions.subject: ORTHOPEDICS
questions.que: Gunstock deformity is seen in
questions.ref_book: Gunstock deformity, also known as cubitus varus, is a condition where the elbow appears abnormally angled inward when extended. It most commonly results from malunion of a supracondylar fracture of the humerus in children. It is due to improper alignment during healing and is a cosmetic concern rather than a functional one(Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 7th Edition, Page No : 99)

questions.subject: ORTHOPEDICS
questions.que: Gun Stock Deformity is seen in
questions.ref_book: Gunstock deformity, medically termed cubitus varus, is a late complication that occurs due to malunion of a supracondylar fracture of the humerus, especially in children. The arm appears deviated inward (varus) when extended at the elbow, resembling the bent stock of a gun. It is primarily a cosmetic issue and is rarely associated with functional impairment(Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 7th Edition, Page No : 99)

questions.subject: ORTHOPEDICS
questions.que: Bennett's fracture involves
questions.option_a: Fracture of base of first metatarsal bone
questions.option_b: Fracture of base of first metacarpal bone
questions.option_c: Fracture of base of fifth metatarsal bone
questions.option_d: Fracture of base of fifty metacarpal bone
questions.ref_book: A Bennett's fracture is a specific type of intra-articular fracture at the base of the first metacarpal bone (thumb), often accompanied by subluxation or dislocation of the carpometacarpal (CMC) joint. It results from axial force on a partially flexed thumb and requires careful management due to joint involvement and potential functional impairment.(Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 7th Edition, Page No : 115)

questions.subject: ORTHOPEDICS
questions.que: Gardens classification is used to classify which fracture
questions.ref_book: Garden's classification is specifically used to classify fractures of the neck of femur based on the degree of displacement seen on radiographs. It includes four stages, from incomplete/impacted (Stage I) to completely displaced fractures (Stage IV), which helps guide prognosis and management(Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 7th Edition, Page No : 131)

questions.subject: ORTHOPEDICS
questions.que: Trochanteric fracture of femur is best treated by?
questions.option_d: Plaster in abduction and internal rotation
questions.ref_book: Inter-trochanteric (trochanteric) fractures of the femur occur between the greater and lesser trochanters and are common in the elderly. The best and most widely used treatment is surgical fixation using a Dynamic Hip Screw (DHS), which allows controlled compression at the fracture site and promotes healing(Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 7th Edition, Page No : 136)

questions.subject: ORTHOPEDICS
questions.que: Commonest ligament involved in sports injuries
questions.ref_book: The anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) is the most commonly injured ligament in sports, particularly in activities involving sudden stops, jumps, and changes in direction-such as football, basketball, and skiing. ACL tears lead to knee instability and often require surgical reconstruction in athletes(Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 7th Edition, Page No : 147)

questions.subject: ORTHOPEDICS
questions.que: Ankle joint is a type of?
questions.ref_book: The ankle joint is a classic hinge joint, allowing motion primarily in one plane-dorsiflexion and plantarflexion. It is formed by the articulation of the distal tibia and fibula with the talus(Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 7th Edition, Page No : 157)

questions.subject: ORTHOPEDICS
questions.que: McLaughlin's line helps to identify?
questions.ref_book: McLaughlin's line is a radiological reference used to detect shoulder dislocation. It is drawn on an X-ray along the undersurface of the clavicle and the superior border of the scapula. In a normal shoulder, this line passes through the center of the humeral head. If the humeral head is displaced and the line does not pass through its center, a dislocation of the shoulder joint is indicated

questions.subject: ORTHOPEDICS
questions.que: Nerve in Guyon's canal is?
questions.ref_book: The ulnar nerve passes through the Guyon's canal, a fibro-osseous tunnel at the wrist between the pisiform and the hook of the hamate. Compression at this site leads to ulnar nerve entrapment, resulting in sensory loss and intrinsic muscle weakness in the ulnar distribution

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Nodes of Rouviere
questions.ref_book: Nodes of Rouvi?re are retropharyngeal lymph nodes, located posterior to the upper part of the pharynx. These nodes are especially important in children, where infection may lead to a retropharyngeal abscess, presenting with fever, neck stiffness, and stridor(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 457)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: In which surgery Freer incision is used?
questions.ref_book: The Freer incision is a standard approach used in septoplasty, a surgery performed to correct a deviated nasal septum. The incision is typically made on the concave side of the septum to raise a mucoperichondrial flap, allowing access to the underlying cartilage and bone for reshaping. This technique helps in preserving the mucosa and minimizing complications.(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 489)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Contraindications to tonsillectomy are all except
questions.ref_book: Submucous fibrosis is not a contraindication. Acute tonsillitis, bleeding disorders, and polio epidemics are temporary or absolute contraindications.(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 503)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Haemorrhage during tonsillectomy is usually from
questions.ref_book: Most reactionary bleeding is venous, primarily from the peritonsillar venous plexus, which lies close to the tonsillar bed.(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 503)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: A 5-year old child after adenoidectomy developed hypernasality and nasal regurgitation of food. What could be the cause?
questions.ref_book: After adenoidectomy, some children - especially those with unrecognized submucous cleft palate or palatal muscle weakness -may develop velopharyngeal insufficiency (VPI). In VPI, the soft palate fails to close the nasopharynx during swallowing and speech, leading to nasal regurgitation and hypernasal speech(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 508)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Which of the statement is True for Cochlea?
questions.option_a: The coiled tube of this snail-like structure makes 3.25 turns
questions.option_b: Cochlear tube measures 23 mm in length
questions.option_d: Scala tympani and vestibule are filled with endolymph
questions.ref_book: The modiolus, the central bony core of the cochlea, measures 5 mm in length, making this the correct statement. The cochlea makes 2.5-2.75 turns, not 3.25. The scala vestibuli and scala tympani contain perilymph, not endolymph, and the cochlear duct measures around 30-35 mm, not just 23 mm. Hence, only the modiolus length is factually accurate(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 509)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Which of the following nystagmus is noticed in Fitzgerald- Hallpike Bithermal Caloric test normally
questions.ref_book:
The Fitzgerald-Hallpike Bithermal Caloric Test is used to assess vestibular function by irrigating the external auditory canal with cold and warm water. The mnemonic COWS helps remember the expected direction of nystagmus in a normal individual:

Cold water ? nystagmus to the Opposite side

Warm water ? nystagmus to the Same side(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 546)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Galen Anastamosis is between
questions.option_b: Right and left superior Laryngeal nerves
questions.ref_book: The anastomosis of Galen is a communication between the internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve and the recurrent laryngeal nerve, both branches of the vagus nerve (cranial nerve X). This connection provides overlapping sensory and motor innervation to parts of the larynx and may help preserve some laryngeal function in case of nerve injury(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 547)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Kallmann syndrome is associated with loss of
questions.ref_book: Kallmann syndrome is a congenital condition characterized by anosmia (loss of smell) and hypogonadotropic hypogonadism due to defective migration of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) and olfactory neurons during development. Patients typically present with absent or reduced sense of smell and delayed puberty. It is a key example of a disorder where olfactory dysfunction is a diagnostic clue. It does not affect taste, hearing, or balance directly(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 547)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: A 65-year-old diabetic presents with necrosis of External Auditory Canal with foul smelling discharge, the probable organism associated with this condition is
questions.ref_book: In elderly diabetic patients, a foul-smelling, necrotic infection of the external auditory canal is characteristic of malignant otitis externa, also called necrotising otitis externa. It is a life-threatening infection that can spread to the skull base. The most common causative organism is Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which thrives in moist environments and is known for its virulence in immunocompromised individuals(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 548)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Mucormycosis causes necrosis due to
questions.ref_book: Mucormycosis, particularly seen in diabetic and immunocompromised patients, causes tissue necrosis by invading blood vessels (angioinvasion). This leads to thrombosis of affected vessels, reduced blood supply, and ultimately tissue infarction and necrosis(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 548)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Asthmatic patients, frequently, have allergy to
questions.ref_book:
Many asthmatic patients exhibit sensitivity to aspirin, which may trigger bronchospasm. This is especially true in individuals with nasal polyps, forming a well-known association known as Samter's triad:

Asthma

Nasal polyps

Aspirin sensitivity

The reaction is not IgE-mediated, but related to altered arachidonic acid metabolism(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 549)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Autonomy in medical Ethics means
questions.option_a: The doctor has the right to decide which is best for his patient
questions.option_b: The attender have the right to decide which is best for the patient
questions.option_c: The patient has the right to decide which is right for the patient
questions.option_d: The Institute's Medical Board decides what is right for the patient
questions.ref_book:
Explanation (based on standard medical ethics principles):
Autonomy is one of the four foundational principles of medical ethics, along with beneficence, non-maleficence, and justice.

Autonomy means that the patient has the right to make informed decisions about their own medical care.

It emphasizes respect for the individual's personal values and choices, even if the doctor or family members disagree.

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: During ear examination, cough occurs due to stimulation of
questions.ref_book: The auricular branch of the vagus nerve, also known as Arnold's nerve, supplies the external auditory canal and the concha. During otoscopic examination, especially if the canal is stimulated (e.g. with a speculum or cotton swab), this can trigger a cough reflex in some individuals - a phenomenon known as Arnold's reflex. This reflex occurs due to vagal stimulation and is a recognized clinical sign. Therefore, vagus nerve (cranial nerve X) is responsible for this cough response(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 5)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Sensory nerve supply of middle ear cavity is provided by
questions.ref_book: The middle ear cavity receives its sensory innervation primarily through the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX), also called Jacobson's nerve. This nerve forms the tympanic plexus on the promontory of the middle ear, supplying mucosa of the middle ear, Eustachian tube, and mastoid air cells(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 6)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: The following are parts of Temporal Bone except
questions.ref_book: Zygomatic is a separate bone; the temporal bone has parts like squamous, tympanic, mastoid, and petrous, but not zygomatic.(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 8)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Pinna develops from
questions.ref_book: The pinna or auricle develops embryologically from six mesenchymal tubercles (hillocks of His) that arise around the first branchial cleft. These tubercles are derived from the first and second pharyngeal (branchial) arches - the tragus originates from the first arch, while the remaining parts (including helix, antihelix, and lobule) develop from the second arch(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 14)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Tubotympanic recess leads to the formation of
questions.ref_book: The tubotympanic recess is derived from the first pharyngeal pouch during embryological development. It forms the middle ear cavity (tympanic cavity) and the Eustachian tube(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 15)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Function of ear ossicles
questions.ref_book: The ear ossicles - malleus, incus, and stapes - form a lever system that transmits and amplifies sound vibrations from the tympanic membrane to the oval window of the cochlea. This system matches the impedance between the air-filled external ear and the fluid-filled inner ear, preventing most of the sound energy from being lost due to reflection(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 18)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Horizontal semicircular canal responds to
questions.ref_book: The horizontal semicircular canal, like the other two (anterior and posterior), responds to angular (rotational) acceleration - such as turning the head side to side. It is maximally stimulated when the head rotates around a vertical axis, which is why it's key in detecting head turns in the horizontal plane. In contrast, gravity and head tilts are sensed by the otolith organs - the utricle and saccule, not the semicircular canals. Thus, the correct answer is rotational acceleration(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 21)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Angular movements are sensed by
questions.ref_book:
The semicircular canals (anterior, posterior, and horizontal) are specialized for detecting angular movements of the head - such as turning or rotating. Each canal is oriented at right angles to the others, enabling detection of movement in all three planes.

The utricle and saccule detect linear acceleration and head position relative to gravity.

The cochlea is involved in hearing, not balance or motion detection(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 21)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Positive Rinne test indicates
questions.ref_book: The Rinne test compares air conduction (AC) to bone conduction (BC). In a normal ear, or in cases of sensorineural hearing loss, air conduction is better than bone conduction (AC > BC), which is referred to as a positive Rinne test. A negative Rinne test (BC > AC) is typically seen in conductive hearing loss. Hence, a positive Rinne test indicates AC > BC.(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 26)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: In Right Middle Ear pathology, Weber's test will be
questions.ref_book:
Weber's test is a tuning fork test used to differentiate between conductive and sensorineural hearing loss. In cases of conductive hearing loss, like right middle ear pathology, the sound bypasses the external and middle ear and is perceived more loudly on the affected side due to reduced masking by ambient noise.

In sensorineural hearing loss, sound lateralises to the normal ear.

Normal or bilateral symmetric hearing would produce centralised sound(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 26)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que:
A Young man presents with loss of hearing in right ear following an accident. On
otoscopic examination the tympanic membrane was normal. Pure tone audiometry
shows an air bone gap of 55 db in the right with normal cochlea. Which of the
following will be the likely tympanometry finding?
questions.ref_book: In this case, the tympanic membrane is intact, but there is a large air-bone gap (55 dB) with a normal cochlea, suggesting a conductive hearing loss due to ossicular disruption, likely caused by trauma. On tympanometry, ossicular discontinuity is classically associated with Type Ad tympanogram, which shows increased compliance due to hypermobility or disconnection of the ossicular chain. Therefore, the likely finding is Ad type tympanogram(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 29)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: In which disorder, the patient will have flat shaped Audiogram?
questions.ref_book:
A flat-shaped audiogram is a classic finding in otitis media with effusion (OME), also known as glue ear. This occurs due to the accumulation of sterile, thick fluid in the middle ear, which restricts tympanic membrane movement and impairs sound conduction. On impedance audiometry, this appears as a flat tympanogram (Type B), indicating reduced compliance of the middle ear system.

Acute otitis media typically shows conductive loss with congestion but not necessarily a flat audiogram.

Tympanosclerosis and ossicular discontinuity usually produce a notched or irregular conductive loss, not flat.(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 29)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: New Born Screening protocol as per NPPCD is
questions.ref_book: (Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 30)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Stapedial reflex is absent in
questions.ref_book:
The stapedial reflex (also called acoustic reflex) involves:

Afferent limb: Cranial nerve VIII (vestibulocochlear) - detects loud sound.

Efferent limb: Cranial nerve VII (facial) - contracts the stapedius muscle to dampen ossicular movement.

A lesion in the VIII nerve disrupts the sensory input, preventing reflex initiation(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 30)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Ototoxic drugs are following except
questions.ref_book:
Ototoxic drugs are those that can damage the cochlea or vestibular apparatus, leading to hearing loss or balance issues. Common ototoxic drugs include:

Aminoglycosides like gentamycin, kanamycin, and streptomycin

Loop diuretics

Certain antimalarials(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 39)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Hearing loss is not caused by
questions.ref_book:
Kanamycin, an aminoglycoside, and vancomycin, though less commonly, are known to cause ototoxicity, especially affecting the cochlear hair cells, resulting in sensorineural hearing loss. Quinine, an antimalarial, is also ototoxic and can cause temporary or permanent hearing loss and tinnitus.
However, Metronidazole is not classified as ototoxic and is not associated with hearing loss in standard therapeutic use. Therefore, the correct answer is metronidazole(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 39)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Which of the following is not cause for fluctuating hearing loss?
questions.ref_book:
Fluctuating hearing loss is typical of conditions where fluid dynamics or intermittent pressure changes affect the auditory system. These include:

M?ni?re's disease (due to endolymphatic hydrops),

Perilymph fistula (leakage of inner ear fluid),

Otitis media with effusion (middle ear fluid altering sound conduction).

In contrast, presbycusis is a progressive, irreversible sensorineural hearing loss due to aging, which does not fluctuate. It steadily worsens over time, especially affecting higher frequencies. Therefore, presbyacusis is not a cause of fluctuating hearing loss(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 43)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Hennebert's sign is seen in
questions.ref_book: Hennebert's sign is a false positive fistula test, where applying pressure over the tragus or external auditory canal causes vertigo or nystagmus without the presence of an actual labyrinthine fistula. It is classically associated with congenital syphilis, due to labyrinthine degeneration and increased susceptibility of the vestibular system to pressure changes(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 54)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: The Common organism in Otomycosis are
questions.ref_book: Aspergillus and Candida are the most common organisms causing otomycosis, with Aspergillus being more frequent.(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 61)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
