questions.que: Which of the following causes opening of Eustachian Tube?
questions.ref_book: The Eustachian tube connects the middle ear to the nasopharynx, and its active opening is essential for equalizing pressure across the tympanic membrane. The tensor veli palatini muscle is the primary muscle that actively opens the Eustachian tube, especially during swallowing, yawning, and sneezing(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 67)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: In which case, Tympanic membrane appears blue
questions.ref_book: A blue tympanic membrane is a classic clinical sign of cholesterol granuloma, which forms due to chronic hemorrhage and impaired ventilation in the middle ear or mastoid, leading to accumulation of cholesterol crystals and dark fluid. The dark fluid behind the tympanic membrane gives it a bluish appearance(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 85)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Carhart's notch is characteristic in
questions.ref_book: Carhart's notch is seen in otospongiosis and appears as a dip in bone conduction threshold at 2000 Hz due to stapes fixation.(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 103)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Blue Mantle is a sign of
questions.ref_book: Blue mantle refers to bluish appearance behind tympanic membrane due to middle ear effusion, typically seen in secretory otitis media.(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 104)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Which muscle is supplied by Facial nerve?
questions.ref_book: Stylohyoid muscle is supplied by the facial nerve; the others are innervated by glossopharyngeal or hypoglossal nerves.(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 108)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Which segment of Facial canal is the shortest and narrowest?
questions.ref_book: The labyrinthine segment of the facial canal is both the shortest (4.0 mm) and the narrowest part of the facial nerve's intratemporal course. It lies between the fundus of the internal acoustic meatus and the geniculate ganglion, making it especially prone to compression from edema or inflammation, which can lead to facial nerve paralysis(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 108)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Electrogustometry is an investigation for
questions.ref_book: Electrogustometry is a diagnostic test used to measure the taste threshold by delivering small electrical currents to specific areas of the tongue. It helps evaluate the function of the chorda tympani nerve (branch of CN VII) and other taste pathways.(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 117)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: High percentage of SISI score is common in
questions.ref_book:
The Short Increment Sensitivity Index (SISI) test is used to differentiate between cochlear (sensory) and retrocochlear (neural) hearing loss. A high SISI score (70-100%) suggests cochlear pathology, and is classically seen in Meniere's disease, where outer hair cells become hypersensitive to small changes in intensity. In contrast:

Otosclerosis is a conductive condition - SISI not applicable.

Acoustic nerve tumour (vestibular schwannoma) is retrocochlear - SISI score is low (0-20%).

Vestibular neuronitis primarily affects balance, not cochlear function(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 121)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Glomus Jugulare tumour- common location is in
questions.ref_book: Glomus jugulare tumour typically arises in the hypotympanum region of the middle ear near the jugular bulb.(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 128)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: When there is an Unilateral Sensorineural hearing loss in an elderly adult with negative Recruitment we have to rule out which of the following condition
questions.ref_book: Vestibular schwannoma should be ruled out in unilateral SNHL with negative recruitment in elderly, as it indicates retrocochlear pathology.(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 132)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Click stimulus is used for which of the following investigations?
questions.ref_book: Click stimuli are short, broad-frequency sound bursts used in Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) to stimulate the auditory pathway. They generate waveforms (I-VII) that represent neural activity from the cochlea to the brainstem, helping in the assessment of hearing threshold and neural integrity(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 139)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: BAHA means
questions.ref_book: BAHA stands for Bone Anchored Hearing Aid. It is a surgically implanted device used in patients with conductive or mixed hearing loss, especially when conventional hearing aids are not effective or feasible. It bypasses the external and middle ear and transmits sound vibrations directly to the inner ear (cochlea) via bone conduction.(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 142)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: 5-year-old boy- getting recurrent middle ear infections- underwent Grommet insertion. After surgery he developed difficulty in tasting ice cream - Which could be the most likely cause?
questions.ref_book:
The chorda tympani nerve, a branch of the facial nerve (CN VII), runs through the middle ear and carries taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. During grommet insertion (ventilation tube placement) or myringotomy, especially in children with recurrent otitis media, this delicate nerve may be injured. This can lead to altered or diminished taste, commonly noticed in foods like ice cream or sweets.

Cranial nerve VIII (vestibulocochlear) relates to hearing and balance.

Arnold's nerve (auricular branch of the vagus) supplies part of the external auditory canal.

Jacobson's nerve (tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal) supplies the middle ear mucosa but does not carry taste.

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Snail track ulcer with septal perforation was seen in a patient. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.ref_book: Snail track ulcers are superficial, serpiginous mucosal ulcers classically seen in tertiary syphilis. These ulcers can involve the nasal septum and turbinates, and chronic progression can lead to septal perforation due to gummatous necrosis

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Which of the following cartilage has signet ring shape
questions.ref_book: Cricoid cartilage has a complete ring structure, resembling a signet ring, making it unique among laryngeal cartilages.(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 331)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Tensor of vocal cord is
questions.ref_book: The cricothyroid muscle is the main tensor of the vocal cords. It functions by tilting the thyroid cartilage forward, which increases the tension and pitch of the vocal cords(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 332)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Abductor of vocal cord is
questions.ref_book: Posterior cricoarytenoid is the only muscle that abducts (opens) the vocal cords, enabling breathing.(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 333)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Thumb sign in Lateral X-ray of neck is seen in?
questions.ref_book: Thumb sign is seen in epiglottitis and represents a swollen epiglottis on lateral neck X-ray.(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 339)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Steeple sign is seen is
questions.ref_book: The steeple sign is a classic radiological finding seen on an anteroposterior (AP) neck X-ray in cases of croup (acute laryngotracheobronchitis). It represents a tapering of the subglottic trachea, resembling the shape of a church steeple, due to subglottic edema and narrowing(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 339)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: A New Born infant has inspiratory stridor, difficulty in feeding and relieved on prone position, the probable diagnosis is
questions.ref_book:
Laryngomalacia is the most common cause of inspiratory stridor in neonates. It results from floppy supraglottic structures (like the epiglottis and aryepiglottic folds) that collapse into the airway during inspiration. Classic features include:

Stridor soon after birth

Worsening with feeding, crying, or lying supine

Relief in prone position(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 344)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Which of the following is a cause of congenital stridor?
questions.ref_book: Laryngomalacia is the most common cause of congenital stridor. It occurs due to floppy supraglottic structures (like the epiglottis and aryepiglottic folds) that collapse into the airway during inspiration, leading to a high-pitched inspiratory noise (stridor). It typically presents soon after birth and is often relieved in the prone position.(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 344)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Cricothyroid muscle is supplied by
questions.ref_book: The external laryngeal nerve, a branch of the superior laryngeal nerve, innervates the cricothyroid muscle.(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 347)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Sensory nerve supply of larynx below the level of vocal cord
questions.option_a: External branch of superior laryngeal nerve
questions.option_b: Internal branch of superior laryngeal nerve
questions.ref_book:
The sensory innervation of the larynx is divided anatomically at the level of the vocal cords:

Above the vocal cords (supraglottic): supplied by the internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve.

Below the vocal cords (infraglottic): supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve, a branch of the vagus nerve (CN X).(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 347)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: In Superior mediastinum Tumour- Which of the following is compressed commonly
questions.ref_book: The left recurrent laryngeal nerve loops around the arch of aorta in the superior mediastinum, making it particularly vulnerable to compression from mediastinal tumors, such as bronchogenic carcinoma or aortic aneurysms. Its long intrathoracic course contrasts with the right recurrent laryngeal nerve, which loops around the subclavian artery and is less commonly affected by mediastinal pathology(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 348)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Treatment of choice in early vocal cord nodule is
questions.ref_book: Voice rest and speech therapy are first-line treatments for early vocal cord nodules, often caused by vocal abuse.(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 353)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Where is Reinke's space located?
questions.ref_book: Reinke's space is located in the glottis, specifically within the true vocal cords. It is the superficial layer of the lamina propria, situated just below the epithelial lining. This space is critical for vocal cord vibration during phonation, allowing the mucosal wave to occur. Edema in this space leads to a condition called Reinke's edema, which causes hoarseness. (Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 353)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Demonstration of air containing sac after Valsalva's Maneuver suggest
questions.ref_book: A laryngocele is a mucosa-lined, air-filled dilation of the saccule of the laryngeal ventricle, which communicates with the laryngeal lumen. It typically enlarges during activities that raise intralaryngeal pressure such as coughing, straining, or Valsalva's manoeuvre, making it visible or palpable externally. In contrast, branchial cleft cysts, Zenker's diverticulum, and cystic hygromas do not contain air and do not change with Valsalva. Therefore, demonstration of an air-containing sac that enlarges with Valsalva is characteristic of a laryngocele(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 355)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: A wind instrument player has a neck swelling that reduces on its own. The probable diagnosis is
questions.ref_book:
A laryngocele is an air-filled outpouching of the laryngeal saccule that communicates with the laryngeal lumen. It commonly presents as a neck swelling that enlarges with straining, coughing, or playing wind instruments, and reduces spontaneously when pressure normalizes. This condition is especially seen in wind instrument players due to repeated increases in intralaryngeal pressure.

Reinke's edema affects the vocal cords and presents with hoarseness.

Ludwig's angina is a rapidly progressive cellulitis of the submandibular space, not reducible and very painful.

Lymphadenitis is inflammatory and does not reduce spontaneously(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 355)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Juvenile papillomatosis is caused by
questions.ref_book: HPV (Human Papillomavirus), especially types 6 and 11, causes juvenile laryngeal papillomatosis.(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 356)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Hoarseness of Voice occurs early in
questions.ref_book: Hoarseness of voice occurs early in glottic carcinoma because the tumor arises directly from the true vocal cords, which are the primary structures responsible for voice production. Even a small lesion on the vocal cords can interfere with their vibration and closure, leading to noticeable changes in voice quality. This makes hoarseness the earliest and most prominent symptom, often prompting early medical attention. In contrast, supraglottic and subglottic carcinomas may grow considerably before affecting the vocal cords, resulting in delayed onset of hoarseness. Therefore, early hoarseness is a hallmark of glottic carcinoma and is crucial for its early diagnosis(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 360)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Bloom Singer Prosthesis is used for
questions.ref_book: The Bloom Singer prosthesis is a tracheoesophageal voice prosthesis used in patients who have undergone total laryngectomy (removal of the voice box). It is inserted into a surgically created tracheoesophageal fistula and functions as a one-way valve, allowing air from the lungs to pass into the pharynx during exhalation to enable esophageal speech while preventing food or liquids from entering the trachea. It plays no role in hearing, stapedectomy, or maxillectomy procedures(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 365)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: A girl has attended the clinic with aphonia. On indirect laryngoscopy there is evidence of adductor Paralysis: What is the probable cause?
questions.ref_book: In functional aphonia, a psychogenic disorder, there is no organic lesion in the larynx. On laryngoscopy, vocal cords appear abducted (adductor paralysis) during attempted phonation, but the patient can still cough or clear throat normally, confirming intact recurrent laryngeal nerve function. It is most commonly seen in young females, often associated with emotional stress or anxiety. Since the findings mimic adductor paralysis without a neurologic or structural cause, the correct diagnosis is functional aphonia(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 366)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: In dysphonia plica ventricularis sound is produced by
questions.ref_book: Dysphonia plica ventricularis is a voice disorder where the false vocal cords (vestibular folds) are used for phonation instead of the true vocal cords. This compensatory behavior often develops in individuals with true vocal cord paralysis or misuse and produces a rough, hoarse, and low-pitched voice(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 366)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: In a comatose patient, Tracheostomy is indicated to
questions.ref_book: In comatose patients, the cough reflex is diminished or absent, and the patient is unable to clear respiratory secretions. This can lead to airway obstruction, aspiration, or infection. A tracheostomy allows for easy suctioning of secretions - a process called tracheobronchial toileting - and is one of the most important reasons for tracheostomy in unconscious or neurologically impaired patients(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 369)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Tracheostomy is done usually over
questions.ref_book: A tracheostomy is most commonly performed between the 2nd and 3rd tracheal rings, which provides a safe and accessible location below the cricoid cartilage and avoids injury to the vocal cords or first tracheal ring, which are higher up. Performing the incision too high risks damaging the cricoid cartilage or entering the larynx, while too low increases risk to major vessels. Therefore, the standard and safest site is between the 2nd and 3rd tracheal rings(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 371)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Complications of tracheostomy are all except
questions.ref_book: Fracture of the cervical vertebra is not a known complication of tracheostomy; others like pneumothorax, emphysema, and apnoea are recognized complications.(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 373)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Commonest form of Tracheo-oesophageal Fistula
questions.option_a: Both upper and lower segment of the oesophagus enter the trachea
questions.option_b: A blind upper pouch with a lower segment communicating with trachea
questions.option_c: An upper segment entering trachea with blind lower segment
questions.ref_book: The most common type of tracheo-oesophageal fistula (TOF), accounting for about 95% of cases, is one where the upper segment of the oesophagus ends in a blind pouch and the lower segment communicates abnormally with the trachea. This results in feeding difficulties and aspiration in neonates. Other types exist (such as H-type fistulas or double fistulas), but they are much rarer. Thus, the correct answer is "a blind upper pouch with a lower segment communicating with trachea.

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Space of Tucker is seen in
questions.ref_book: It is bounded laterally by the thyroid cartilage, inferomedially by the conus elasticus, medially by the laryngeal ventricle and the quadrangular membrane, and posteriorly (dorsally) by the mucosa of the piriform sinus.

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Nasolacrimal duct opens into
questions.ref_book: The nasolacrimal duct, which drains tears from the lacrimal sac, opens into the inferior meatus of the nasal cavity - the space beneath the inferior nasal turbinate. This anatomical connection explains why crying often causes a runny nose, as tears pass into the nasal cavity. It does not open into the superior or middle meatus, nor into the sphenoethmoidal recess(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 156)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Hiatus semilunaris is present in
questions.ref_book:
The hiatus semilunaris is a crescent-shaped groove located in the middle meatus of the nasal cavity. It serves as the common drainage pathway for:

Frontal sinus

Anterior ethmoid air cells

Maxillary sinus(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 157)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Smell disorder is often associated with all except
questions.ref_book: Smell disorders (anosmia or hyposmia) are commonly seen in conditions that affect the olfactory pathway directly or indirectly. This includes Kallmann's syndrome (a congenital disorder involving anosmia and hypogonadotropic hypogonadism), Turner's syndrome, and atrophic rhinitis (due to mucosal atrophy). However, Osler-Weber-Rendu syndrome (hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia) primarily affects the blood vessels, especially in the nose, lungs, and GI tract, and is known for recurrent epistaxis, not olfactory dysfunction. Hence, it is not typically associated with smell disorders(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 164)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: For a dorsal hump, which type of Rhinoplasty is performed
questions.ref_book: A dorsal nasal hump is a common cosmetic concern involving prominence of the nasal bridge due to excess bone and/or cartilage. The appropriate surgical correction is reduction rhinoplasty, which removes or files down the hump to create a smoother nasal profile.(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 165)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Nasal features of congenital syphilis is
questions.ref_book: In congenital syphilis, the cartilaginous part of the nasal septum may be destroyed, leading to a saddle nose deformity - a characteristic flattening or depression of the nasal bridge. This is due to chronic inflammation and collapse of nasal cartilage. In advanced cases, it may also progress to tapir nose (a beak-like appearance of the nasal tip).(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 165)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: A 40-year-old diabetic patient presented with Nasal discharge and Unilateral Proptosis of the eye, the probable diagnosis could be
questions.ref_book: In a 40-year-old diabetic patient presenting with nasal discharge and unilateral proptosis, the most likely diagnosis is mucormycosis - an aggressive, angioinvasive fungal infection that rapidly spreads from the nasal cavity to the orbit and brain. It is a medical emergency commonly seen in uncontrolled diabetes, especially after ketoacidosis or immunosuppression(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 183)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: A 49-year old diabetic patient presents with black necrotic mass filling the nasal cavity and diplopia of the affected side, Management should be
questions.ref_book:
A diabetic patient presenting with black necrotic nasal tissue and diplopia suggests acute invasive fungal rhinosinusitis, most likely mucormycosis. This is a medical emergency. Management includes:

Intravenous Amphotericin B - the antifungal of choice.

Aggressive endoscopic surgical debridement - to remove necrotic, non-viable tissues and reduce fungal load(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 184)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Side effects of antihistamines are the following except
questions.ref_book: Antihistamines commonly cause drowsiness, dry mouth, and urinary retention, but hypotension is not a typical side effect.(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 196)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Vidian neurectomy advised in
questions.ref_book: Vidian neurectomy is a surgical procedure used in refractory cases of vasomotor rhinitis, a non-allergic, non-infectious condition characterized by nasal hyperreactivity and excessive parasympathetic tone. By cutting the vidian nerve, which carries parasympathetic fibers to the nasal mucosa, the procedure helps reduce nasal secretions and congestion.(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 199)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Recurrent polyp are seen in
questions.ref_book: Ethmoidal polyps arise from the ethmoidal sinuses, are usually multiple and bilateral, and are classically associated with conditions like allergic rhinitis, asthma, and aspirin sensitivity (Samter's triad). These polyps are notorious for their high recurrence rate, even after surgical removal. In contrast, antrochoanal polyps are typically unilateral, solitary, and occur mainly in children, with less chance of recurrence. Concha bullosa is a pneumatised middle turbinate, and hypertrophic turbinate refers to mucosal swelling - neither are nasal polyps(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 201)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Young's syndrome is
questions.option_b: Mitral stenosis with Atrial septal defect
questions.ref_book:
Young's syndrome is a rare disorder seen in males and is characterized by the triad of:

Bronchiectasis

Rhinosinusitis

Infertility (due to abnormal sperm transport)(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 201)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: The artery of Epistaxis is
questions.ref_book: Sphenopalatine artery is the main artery involved in epistaxis, particularly posterior epistaxis.(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 205)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Epistaxis in child is usually due to
questions.ref_book: In children, epistaxis is most commonly caused by vestibulitis or trauma to Littl's area due to nose picking.(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 205)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Woodruff's plexus is located in
questions.ref_book: Woodruff's plexus is a venous plexus found in the posterior part of the nasal cavity, specifically beneath the posterior end of the inferior turbinate (i.e., in the inferior meatus). It is the usual source of posterior epistaxis, which is often more severe and commonly seen in elderly or hypertensive patients(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 205)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: In a 5 year old child, cause of unilateral Epistaxis is
questions.ref_book: In a 5-year-old child, unilateral epistaxis (bleeding from one nostril) is most often caused by a foreign body lodged in the nasal cavity - a common occurrence at this age due to curiosity and lack of supervision. It may be accompanied by foul-smelling nasal discharge or secondary infection. Other options like polyps are typically bilateral and rare in this age group, atrophic rhinitis is seen in older individuals, and maggots (nasal myiasis) are more often seen in debilitated patients or those with poor hygiene(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 206)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Which of the following is maxillary fracture?
questions.ref_book:
Le Fort fractures are a well-known classification of maxillary fractures, based on the horizontal level and pattern of the fracture lines:

Le Fort I - horizontal fracture above the teeth

Le Fort II - pyramidal fracture involving nasal bridge

Le Fort III - craniofacial disjunction(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 211)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Tripod Fracture is seen in
questions.ref_book:
A tripod fracture refers to a fracture of the zygomatic bone at three junctions where it articulates with other facial bones:

Zygomatic arch (with temporal bone)

Zygomaticomaxillary complex

Zygomaticofrontal suture

It is commonly caused by blunt trauma to the cheek and may result in facial flattening, infraorbital nerve injury, and restricted jaw movement. The mandible, maxilla, and nasal bone are not involved in a classic tripod fracture(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 214)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: The usual nerve injured in fracture of Maxilla is
questions.ref_book: Infra-orbital nerve is most commonly injured in maxillary fractures due to its course along the floor of the orbit.(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 215)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Orbital cellulitis most commonly occurs after which sinus infection
questions.ref_book: Ethmoidal sinusitis is the most frequent source of orbital cellulitis, due to the lamina papyracea, a thin bony wall that separates the ethmoid sinus from the orbit. This wall is very thin and may be congenitally dehiscent, making it easy for infection to spread into the orbital cavity. While other sinuses like maxillary or frontal can also cause complications, ethmoidal sinusitis is by far the most common cause of orbital cellulitis(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 233)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Complications of acute sinusitis
questions.ref_book:
Pott's puffy tumor is a serious complication of frontal sinusitis, especially in adolescents, characterized by:

Swelling of the forehead

Subperiosteal abscess

Frontal bone osteomyelitis(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 233)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Neurogenic tumours of nose and Paranasal sinuses are the following except
questions.ref_book: Neurogenic tumours of the nose and paranasal sinuses include schwannoma, olfactory neuroblastoma, and nasal glioma (which is not a true neoplasm but a congenital heterotopia of glial tissue). In contrast, rhinophyma is a sebaceous gland hypertrophy associated with rosacea, not a neurogenic tumor. It presents as a nodular enlargement of the nose, especially in older men, and is dermatological in nature - not related to nerve tissue. Hence, the correct exclusion is rhinophyma(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 236)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Which of the following is a treatment for Inverted Papilloma with in nasal cavity?
questions.ref_book: Inverted papilloma, also called Schneiderian papilloma, arises from the lateral nasal wall or paranasal sinuses and is known for its high recurrence rate and potential for malignant transformation. The treatment of choice is medial maxillectomy, which ensures complete removal of the lesion(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 236)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Most common site for osteoma is
questions.ref_book: Frontal sinus is the most common site for osteoma, which is a benign bony growth often detected incidentally on imaging.(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 240)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Most common malignancy in maxillary antrum
questions.ref_book: The maxillary antrum (sinus) is the most frequently involved paranasal sinus in malignancies, and among these, squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is the most common histological type. It typically presents late due to the large cavity of the sinus and may manifest as cheek swelling, nasal obstruction, or proptosis. Other malignancies like mucoepidermoid, adenocystic, or adenocarcinomas are far less common in this location. Hence, the correct answer is squamous cell carcinoma(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 241)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Radiologically Carcinoma Maxilla is diagnosed mostly by
questions.ref_book: Carcinoma of the maxilla typically shows opacity with bone erosion on imaging, indicating malignant infiltration.(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 242)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Tapir Nose is a result of
questions.ref_book: Tapir nose refers to a beak-like deformity of the nasal tip and is a classical sign of late congenital syphilis. It results from destruction of the nasal cartilage during the disease's progression, leading to distortion and elongation of the nose tip.

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Serum sickness is
questions.ref_book:
erum sickness is a classic example of a Type III hypersensitivity reaction, which is immune complex-mediated. It occurs when antigen-antibody complexes form in the bloodstream and get deposited in tissues, leading to complement activation, inflammation, and tissue damage. It typically presents with fever, rash, joint pain, and lymphadenopathy, and often follows exposure to foreign proteins or antiserum (e.g., antitoxins, non-human monoclonal antibodies).

Type I: IgE-mediated (e.g., anaphylaxis, urticaria)

Type II: Antibody-mediated cytotoxic (e.g., hemolytic anemia)

Type III: Immune complex (e.g., serum sickness, SLE)

Type IV: Delayed-type, T-cell mediated (e.g., contact dermatitis, TB skin test)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: UPSIT means
questions.option_b: Position to correct BPPV (Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo)
questions.option_c: University of Pennsylvania Smell Identification Test
questions.option_d: Upgraded Powered Static Investigation for Tracheo-oesophageal Fistula
questions.ref_book: UPSIT stands for University of Pennsylvania Smell Identification Test, which is a standardized, widely used tool for assessing olfactory function. It uses a series of scratch-and-sniff cards containing different odorants, and the subject must identify each smell from multiple-choice options. It is helpful in diagnosing anosmia, hyposmia, and olfactory disorders due to various neurological or nasal conditions

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que:
Women with vitamin B12 deficiency presents with dysphagia and anaemia.
What is the syndrome mentioned in the presentation?
questions.ref_book: This describes Plummer Vinson syndrome, characterized by iron deficiency anemia, dysphagia, and esophageal web formation.(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 401)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Dysphagia lusoria results from
questions.ref_book: Dysphagia lusoria is a rare form of vascular dysphagia resulting from compression of the esophagus by an aberrant right subclavian artery, which takes an unusual retroesophageal course. This congenital vascular anomaly causes mechanical obstruction, leading to difficulty in swallowing.(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 405)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Premalignant lesions are except
questions.ref_book:
Premalignant lesions are mucosal changes that have potential to transform into oral cancers. These include:

Leukoplakia - white patch with dysplastic risk

Erythroplakia - red patch with even higher risk

Submucous fibrosis - progressive fibrosis with malignant potential

Epulis, however, is a benign, non-premalignant lesion of the gingiva, often inflammatory or fibrous in nature.(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 262)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Frey's syndrome includes
questions.ref_book:
Frey's syndrome, also known as auriculotemporal nerve syndrome, occurs due to aberrant regeneration of the parasympathetic fibers of the auriculotemporal nerve after parotid gland surgery or injury. Instead of reinnervating salivary tissue, the fibers mistakenly connect to sweat glands, causing sweating and flushing over the parotid area during eating - known as gustatory sweating.

Crocodile tears (lacrimation while eating) is associated with facial nerve injury.

Anosmia is loss of smell and unrelated to Frey's syndrome(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 277)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: A Dental surgeon is injecting Local Anaesthesia for a procedure on lower molar tooth. Which nerve the dentist must be blocking
questions.ref_book: For dental procedures involving the lower molar teeth, the dentist must block the inferior alveolar nerve, which is a branch of the mandibular division (V3) of the trigeminal nerve (CN V). This nerve enters the mandibular foramen and supplies the lower teeth, mandible, and lower lip

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Lingual Tonsil is a
questions.ref_book: The lingual tonsil is a part of the Waldeyer's ring, located at the base of the tongue. It is made of lymphoid tissue and plays a role in immune defense. It is not a pathological condition, but rather a normal anatomical structure(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 281)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Passavant's ridge is formed by
questions.ref_book: Passavant's ridge is a dynamic mucosal bulge that appears on the posterior pharyngeal wall during swallowing or phonation. It serves to help close the nasopharyngeal isthmus, preventing nasal regurgitation of food. The ridge is produced by the coordinated contraction of the palatopharyngeus and superior constrictor muscles. Other muscle combinations listed are incorrect anatomically and functionally in forming this ridge(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 283)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Epstein Bart virus may be connected with all except
questions.ref_book:
he Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) is implicated in several diseases including:

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma

Glandular fever (Infectious mononucleosis)

Burkitt's lymphoma

However, nasopharyngeal fibroma, also known as juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma, is a benign, highly vascular tumor of adolescent males and has no connection with EBV. Therefore, the correct exception is nasopharyngeal fibroma(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 289)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Epistaxis in adolescent person is commonest in
questions.ref_book: In adolescents, especially males, the most common cause of recurrent or profuse epistaxis is juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA). It is a highly vascular tumor that originates in the posterior nasal cavity/nasopharynx and may cause nasal obstruction and epistaxis(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 289)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: A 16-year-old male presented with unprovoked torrential nasal bleed that stopped on its own. The probable diagnosis is
questions.ref_book: Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA) is a benign but highly vascular tumor that occurs almost exclusively in adolescent males. It commonly presents with sudden, unprovoked, and torrential episodes of nasal bleeding (epistaxis), which may stop spontaneously but tend to recur. The tumor originates near the sphenopalatine foramen and can extend into surrounding structures(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 289)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Which of the following is the feature of Trotter's triad?
questions.ref_book:
Trotter's triad is a classical clinical presentation associated with nasopharyngeal carcinoma. It includes:

Conductive hearing loss from Eustachian tube obstruction,

Ipsilateral palatal paralysis, and

Trigeminal neuralgia, especially along the mandibular division (V3) of the trigeminal nerve(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 297)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Vincent's angina caused by
questions.ref_book: Vincent's angina, or acute necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis, is caused by Fusiform bacillus and spirochetes.(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 306)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Infection of submandibular space is seen in
questions.ref_book: Ludwig's angina is a serious, potentially life-threatening cellulitis of the submandibular space, often involving the sublingual and submental spaces bilaterally. It is typically caused by dental infections, especially of the lower molars. The floor of the mouth becomes elevated, and there is risk of airway obstruction(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 309)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: In which of the following locations there is collection of pus in the Quinsy?
questions.ref_book: Quinsy, or peritonsillar abscess, is a complication of acute tonsillitis where pus accumulates in the peritonsillar space, the anatomical area between the tonsillar capsule and the superior constrictor muscle. It causes severe throat pain, trismus, and muffled voice. It is not located within the tonsil itself, nor in the parapharyngeal or retropharyngeal spaces, which are deeper neck spaces with different pathologies(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 311)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Most common tumour within para pharyngeal space is
questions.ref_book: Neurogenic tumours are the most common tumours found in the parapharyngeal space.(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 321)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Patients with Plummer- Vinson syndrome are prone to
questions.ref_book:
Plummer-Vinson syndrome is characterized by the triad of:

Iron deficiency anemia

Dysphagia

Esophageal web

It predominantly affects middle-aged women and is a known precancerous condition that significantly increases the risk of developing postcricoid carcinoma, a type of hypopharyngeal cancer. This association is due to chronic mucosal atrophy and nutritional deficiency(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 322)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Zenker's diverticulum is
questions.ref_book: Zenker's diverticulum is a pharyngeal diverticulum, not an esophageal one. It forms at Killian's dehiscence, a weak area between the thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus muscles of the inferior pharyngeal constrictor. It typically presents in older adults with dysphagia, regurgitation of undigested food, and halitosis. Because it arises above the upper esophageal sphincter, it is correctly classified as a pharyngeal pouch, not esophageal or intestinal(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 323)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: In children with Adenoid Hypertrophy- which of the following is a complication
questions.ref_book:
In children, adenoid hypertrophy can cause significant nasal obstruction, leading to mouth breathing, snoring, and in severe cases, Obstructive Sleep Apnoea Syndrome (OSAS) - characterized by interrupted breathing during sleep. It is a well-recognized complication of enlarged adenoids.

Plummer-Vinson syndrome is related to iron deficiency and dysphagia.

Kartagener's syndrome involves ciliary dyskinesia with situs inversus.

Tonsillitis is a separate condition affecting the palatine tonsils(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 326)

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Gerlach Tonsil
questions.ref_book: The tubal tonsil, also known as Gerlach's tonsil, is a part of Waldeyer's ring, which is a ring of lymphoid tissue in the pharynx. It is located near the pharyngeal opening of the Eustachian tube in the nasopharynx

questions.subject: OTORHINOLARYNGOLOGY
questions.que: Oral manifestations of HIV associated with Ebstein Barr Virus is
questions.ref_book: Hairy leukoplakia is a distinctive oral lesion that appears as a white, corrugated patch, typically on the lateral border of the tongue. It is strongly associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) and occurs almost exclusively in immunocompromised individuals, particularly those with HIV/AIDS. It is not premalignant and does not rub off. While oral candidiasis, recurrent aphthous ulcers, and oral carcinoma can also be seen in HIV patients, hairy leukoplakia is the one directly linked to EBV(Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No : 438)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: Which among these is a cyanotic congenital heart disease with decreased pulmonary blood flow?
questions.ref_book: Tetralogy of Fallot is a cyanotic congenital heart disease characterized by decreased pulmonary blood flow due to right ventricular outflow tract obstruction (pulmonary stenosis). This results in a right-to-left shunt through a ventricular septal defect, causing cyanosis(Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 444)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: Under revised Jones criteria for Acute Rheumatic Fever (2015), which additional major criteria is added to the already existing 5 major criteria in moderate, high-risk populations
questions.ref_book: In the 2015 revision of the Jones criteria, for moderate and high-risk populations, polyarthralgia was upgraded from a minor to a major criterion, recognizing its diagnostic significance in populations with higher prevalence of rheumatic fever. This contrasts with low-risk groups where only polyarthritis qualifies as a major joint criterion(Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 459)

questions.que: Plethoric lung field is seen in which CHD
questions.ref_book: (Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 441)

questions.ref_book: (Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 449)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: A 2-year-old child presents with two weeks history of fever, vomiting, and alteration of sensorium. CT scan of the brain reveals basal exudates and hydrocephalus. The most likely etiological agent is
questions.ref_book: (Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 586)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: A 4-year-old child presents with signs and symptoms of Meningitis. A purpuric rash is seen all over the body. What is the most likely etiological agent causing meningitis in this child?
questions.ref_book:
In children older than 2 years, Neisseria meningitidis is a common cause of meningitis. The presence of a purpuric rash is a classical indicator of meningococcemia, strongly pointing to this organism as the cause.
(Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 586)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: Acute Flaccid paralysis is defined as any case of flaccid weakness in children aged less than
questions.ref_book: The Global Polio Eradication Initiative defines AFP as any case of acute flaccid weakness in children below 15 years of age. This threshold is crucial for surveillance programs aimed at identifying and monitoring poliomyelitis and related disorders(Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 611)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: Microcephaly is defined as occipitofrontal circumference of more than how many standard deviations below the mean for a given age?
questions.ref_book: (Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 574)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: Which is NOT a sign of hydrocephalus?
questions.ref_book: (Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 574)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: A 3-year-old child presents with a painless abdominal mass crossing the midline. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.ref_book: In children, a painless abdominal mass that crosses the midline is more typical of neuroblastoma than Wilms tumor. Neuroblastomas often arise from the adrenal glands or sympathetic chain and may cross the midline, in contrast to Wilms tumor which generally does not. While Wilms tumor can present similarly, it more commonly remains confined to one side of the abdomen. Hydronephrosis and polycystic kidney disease are typically bilateral or cause flank masses and are usually associated with other signs(Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 638)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: A 5-year-old boy presenting with fever for 1 week with fatigue and skin bleeds, and noted to have hepatosplenomegaly, is more likely to have:
questions.ref_book: (Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 621)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: Dangerous hyperkalaemia in a child with Acute kidney Injury is treated with all the following drugs except
questions.ref_book: In cases of life-threatening hyperkalemia, treatment includes calcium gluconate for cardiac membrane stabilization, nebulized salbutamol, sodium bicarbonate, and insulin-glucose infusion to drive potassium intracellularly. Magnesium sulfate is not indicated for hyperkalemia and is instead used in hypomagnesemia or preeclampsia/eclampsia management(Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 65)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: Treatment options for hyperkalemia include all except
questions.ref_book: (Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 65)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: In the case of Severe Acute Malnutrition, the first feeding given in the early stabilization phase is with
questions.ref_book: F-75 is the WHO-recommended starter formula for SAM. It provides 75 kcal/100 mL and is designed for the stabilization phase to prevent fluid overload and metabolic stress, unlike the more nutrient-dense F-100 used later in rehabilitation(Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 91)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: As per WHO classification of xerophthalmia, corneal xerosis is
questions.ref_book: (Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 101)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: Deficiency of which vitamin causes dementia, dermatitis and diarrhoea?
questions.ref_book: Niacin (Vitamin B3) deficiency causes pellagra, marked by the classical triad of dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. These symptoms reflect the systemic involvement of skin, gastrointestinal tract, and central nervous system in niacin deficiency(Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 112)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: The classical triad of Pellagra includes all except
questions.ref_book: (Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 112)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: All of the following are criteria to define severe acute malnutrition EXCEPT:
questions.option_a: Bilateral pedal edema of nutritional origin
questions.ref_book: (Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 89)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: Periconceptional supplementation of which vitamin prevents Neural Tube Defects
questions.ref_book: Folic acid plays a critical role in DNA synthesis and cell division, which are essential during early fetal development. Supplementation before conception and during early pregnancy has been proven to reduce the risk of neural tube defects (NTDs) such as spina bifida and anencephaly(Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 113)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: A 5-year-old child presents with a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. Blood glucose is 30 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate management?
questions.ref_book: For a 5-year-old child with hypoglycemia-induced seizure, 10% dextrose (D10W) at a bolus dose of 5 mL/kg IV is the recommended immediate management(Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 92)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: Which condition associated with vitamin deficiency presents with signs of congestive cardiac failure?
questions.ref_book: (Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 110)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: Most common cause of congenital adrenal hyperplasia is
questions.ref_book: (Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 547)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: A 1-year-old child presents with constipation, development delay, goiter and short stature. Which one of the following is the most probable cause?
questions.ref_book: The constellation of features-constipation, delayed development, goiter, and short stature-in a 1-year-old child is classic for congenital hypothyroidism. If not detected and treated early, it can lead to permanent neurodevelopmental deficits and growth retardation(Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 538)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: In girls, the earliest sign of puberty is
questions.ref_book: (Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 553)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: Abnormal curvature of the penis in a child with Hypospadias is called:
questions.ref_book: Chordee is a ventral curvature of the penis commonly seen in children with hypospadias. It results from fibrous tissue on the ventral side of the penis and is often corrected surgically during hypospadias repair(Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 562)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: Steeple sign in neck X-ray is seen in
questions.ref_book: (Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 391)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: A 5-year-old child presents with sudden onset of high-grade fever, sore throat stridor and drooling of saliva. In lateral neck X-ray 'thumb sign' was seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.ref_book: The ?thumb sign' on lateral neck X-ray-caused by swollen epiglottis-along with symptoms like high fever, sore throat, stridor, and drooling, strongly suggests acute epiglottitis, a medical emergency. It must be differentiated from croup (laryngotracheobronchitis), which has a more gradual onset and 'steeple sign' on X-ray.(Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 391)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: The most common cause of wheeze in infants is
questions.ref_book: Bronchiolitis is the leading cause of wheezing in infants, typically caused by RSV and other respiratory viruses. It affects the small airways (bronchioles) and presents with cough, wheezing, and difficulty breathing in children under 2 years(Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 406)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: What is the osmolarity of WHO ORS [Oral rehydration solution]?
questions.ref_book: To improve clinical outcomes and reduce complications like stool output and vomiting, WHO revised the osmolarity of its ORS to 245 mmol/L. This low-osmolarity formula is now universally adopted and is effective across all age groups and types of diarrhea(Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 312)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: A term neonate fails to pass meconium within 48 hours. Which condition should be suspected?
questions.ref_book: Failure to pass meconium within the first 48 hours of life is a red flag for Hirschsprung disease, a congenital condition caused by absence of ganglion cells in the distal colon, leading to functional obstruction. While other conditions like meconium ileus, intestinal atresia, or sepsis may also cause similar symptoms, the most likely and classically associated diagnosis with delayed meconium passage in a term neonate is Hirschsprung disease(Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 302)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: What is the antibiotic of choice in cholera?
questions.ref_book: (Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 322)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: The rate of increase in head size during first 3 months after birth
questions.ref_book: During the first three months of life, head growth is most rapid due to active brain development. The head circumference increases by approximately 2 cm per month in this period. This rate then declines to 1 cm per month between 3-6 months and further to 0.5 cm per month from 6-12 months. Monitoring this growth is crucial for assessing neurodevelopmental health in infants(Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 12)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: Immature Pincer grasp is attained at
questions.ref_book:
The immature pincer grasp, which involves using the thumb and index finger without full tip-to-tip coordination, typically develops around 9 months of age. This grasp is a precursor to the mature pincer grip, which is attained by 12 months and allows finer object manipulation.
(Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 31)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: The term neonate measures a length of ______________ at birth
questions.ref_book: (Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 12)

questions.que: A child copies a triangle at
questions.ref_book: (Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 32)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: A child rides a tricycle by which year?
questions.ref_book: (Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 29)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: What is the age at which child copies a triangle?
questions.ref_book: Copying a triangle is a higher-order fine motor and cognitive task that reflects improved hand-eye coordination and perceptual skills. It is typically achieved by the age of 5 years, whereas earlier shapes like circles and crosses are copied at 3 and 4 years respectively.(Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 34)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: A 2-year-old child presents with delayed speech and poor social interaction. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial screening tool?
questions.option_b: Modified Checklist for Autism in Toddlers (M-CHAT)
questions.ref_book: The Modified Checklist for Autism in Toddlers (M-CHAT) is the most appropriate initial screening tool for a 2-year-old child with delayed speech and poor social interaction, which are early signs of autism spectrum disorder(Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 43)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: Bone age is delayed in which type of short stature?
questions.ref_book: (Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 19)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: What is the age at which a child typically achieves a social smile?
questions.ref_book: A social smile is one of the earliest signs of social interaction and emotional development in infants. It typically emerges around 6 to 8 weeks of age, which corresponds to 2 months(Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 35)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: A child climbs stairs with alternate feet and ride a tricycle. These developments correspond to what age?
questions.ref_book: At 3 years of age, children demonstrate key gross motor milestones including climbing stairs with alternate feet and riding a tricycle.(Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 28)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: In India, which growth chart is officially recommended for monitoring children under 5 years?
questions.ref_book: The WHO MGRS growth charts are the officially recommended charts in India for children under 5 years. These charts are based on data from breastfed infants from multiple countries, including India, and are considered appropriate for assessing growth patterns in healthy children(Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 12)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: Abnormal prothrombin time (PT) with normal activated partial thromboplastin time suggests
questions.ref_book: (Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 370)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: Substitution of valine for glutamic acid at position 6 of beta globin gene results in
questions.ref_book: This classical mutation leads to abnormal hemoglobin S, which polymerizes under deoxygenated conditions, distorting red cells into a sickle shape. These cells are fragile and occlude capillaries, causing the hallmark features of hemolysis, anemia, and vaso-occlusive crises in sickle cell disease.(Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 364)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: Treatment options in idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura include all except
questions.ref_book: (Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 372)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: Hand and foot syndrome is seen in
questions.ref_book: (Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 364)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: Iron deficiency in a child results in:
questions.ref_book: Iron deficiency in children can lead to microcytic hypochromic anemia, cognitive impairment, fatigue, irritability, and delayed development. These effects are serious and may be irreversible if not addressed promptly, hence all the options listed are valid consequences.(Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 354)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: The stain used to measure the iron content in bone marrow is:
questions.ref_book: (Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 354)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: 4-year-old child presents with limping gait and pain in the hip. There is no history of trauma. X-ray shows avascular necrosis of the femoral head. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.ref_book: Legg-Calve-Perthes disease is the most common cause of atraumatic avascular necrosis of the femoral head in children, especially boys aged 4-8 years. It presents with a limp and hip pain, often without systemic signs. The diagnosis is confirmed by X-ray. Other conditions like SCFE are rare under age 10, and septic arthritis or transient synovitis usually show more acute symptoms or systemic features

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: The leading cause of mortality in adolescent boys is:
questions.ref_book: (Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 745)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: A 1-year-old child presents with a history of recurrent infections and albinism. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.ref_book: Chediak-Higashi syndrome is the most likely diagnosis in a child presenting with both recurrent infections and albinism. This syndrome results from a defect in lysosomal trafficking, leading to immune deficiency and pigment dilution. The combination of hypopigmentation and immune dysfunction is highly specific

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: All the below vaccines are administered by subcutaneous route except
questions.ref_book: While MMR, MR, and Varicella vaccines are administered subcutaneously, the pentavalent vaccine (DPT-HepB-Hib) is given intramuscularly. Knowing the route of administration is important for ensuring vaccine efficacy and minimizing local reactions.(Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 196)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: Treatment of category II dog exposure includes all of the following except
questions.ref_book: Category II exposures involve minor, superficial contact with no bleeding. These cases require wound care and anti-rabies vaccine, with no need for rabies immunoglobulin, which is reserved for Category III exposures (e.g., transdermal bites or scratches, contamination of mucous membranes). Tetanus prophylaxis is given if indicated by wound and immunization status(Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 206)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: All the vaccines are given through intradermal route except
questions.ref_book: The BCG and intradermal fIPV (fractional IPV) are administered intradermally. Anti-rabies vaccine can also be given intradermally in specific regimens. Varicella vaccine, however, is administered subcutaneously(Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 204)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: Which of the following is a live vaccine?
questions.ref_book: (Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 186)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: Which of the following is used to prevent severe varicella disease in an exposed neonate?
questions.ref_book: (Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 218)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: What is the type of fever in dengue fever?
questions.ref_book: Dengue fever often follows a biphasic pattern of fever, also called "saddleback" fever-initial fever subsides and then recurs. This feature, along with severe myalgia and rash, helps distinguish dengue from other febrile illnesses.(Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 242)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: A 12-year-old child is brought with a history of passing blood-stained stool. Sigmoidoscopy shows ulcers in the sigmoid colon and biopsy of that area shows flask-shaped ulcers. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.ref_book: The description of flask-shaped ulcers on sigmoidoscopy is characteristic of Entamoeba histolytica colitis. The first-line treatment is metronidazole to eliminate trophozoites, followed by a luminal agent to clear cysts and prevent recurrence(Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 281)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: Which of these is a sign of dengue with warning signs?
questions.ref_book: (Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 243)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: Which of the following is not a steroid sparing agent used in Management of steroid dependent Nephrotic Syndrome?
questions.ref_book: Levamisole, cyclophosphamide, and mycophenolate mofetil are all validated steroid-sparing agents used in managing steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome. Aspirin, however, is not listed among them and has no role in modifying the disease course in nephrotic syndrome; it is not an immunosuppressant or disease-modifying therapy in this context(Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 506)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: A 12-year-old boy presented with gross haematuria for 3 days. He has hard of hearing and vision defects. There is a family history of renal disease in his maternal uncle. What is your diagnosis?
questions.ref_book: Alport syndrome is a hereditary nephritis often presenting in boys with hematuria, sensorineural deafness, and ocular abnormalities. The maternal uncle's history suggests X-linked inheritance. Audiometry and slit-lamp examination are crucial to confirm associated features.(Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 495)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: Nephrotic range proteinuria is
questions.ref_book: (Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 503)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: Verotoxin-producing E. coli (0157) causes which disease?
questions.ref_book: (Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 517)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: All are predisposing factors of UTI in infants except
questions.ref_book: The main predisposing factors for urinary tract infections (UTIs) in infants are structural and functional anomalies like vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) and obstructive uropathy, as well as procedures like catheterization which introduce pathogens into the urinary tract(Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 507)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: A 7-year-old child presents with a history of bedwetting three times a week for the past six months. There is no daytime incontinence. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.ref_book: This 7-year-old child has nocturnal enuresis without any daytime incontinence, and symptoms have been present since infancy. This fits the definition of primary monosymptomatic nocturnal enuresis, which is the most common form and usually related to delayed maturation of bladder control.(Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 527)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: A 6-year-old child presents with a purpuric rash on the lower limbs, abdominal pain, and arthralgia. Urinalysis shows haematuria. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.ref_book: This clinical picture is classic for Henoch-Sch?nlein purpura, a small-vessel vasculitis commonly affecting children. It typically presents with a purpuric rash on the lower limbs, colicky abdominal pain, and joint involvement, often with renal manifestations such as haematuria. The presence of these four features together makes HSP the most likely diagnosis, distinguishing it from ITP (which lacks abdominal or joint symptoms), HUS (which presents with anemia and thrombocytopenia), and SLE (which has more systemic features and positive serology)(Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 660)

questions.subject: PAEDIATRICS
questions.que: A 2-year-old child presents with a high-grade fever, conjunctival injection, strawberry tongue, and cervical lymphadenopathy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.ref_book: The presentation of high-grade fever, conjunctival injection, strawberry tongue, and cervical lymphadenopathy is classic for Kawasaki disease, a pediatric vasculitis that may lead to coronary artery aneurysms if untreated(Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition Page No : 658)

Anti-A (Group A sera): Blue

Anti-B (Group B sera): Yellow

Anti-D (Rh sera): Colourless

Hence, Group B sera is yellow in color.

questions.ref_book: Endometrial serous carcinoma is a type II endometrial carcinoma. Unlike endometrioid carcinoma (type I), it is not associated with endometrial hyperplasia and instead arises in an atrophic endometrium of older women. It is typically high-grade, shows p53 mutations (not MLH1), and is characterized by an aggressive course with poor prognosis

questions.subject: PATHOLOGY
questions.que: HHV-8 genome is found in the following cell of infected subjects
questions.ref_book: Human Herpesvirus-8 (HHV-8), also called Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus, primarily infects B-lymphocytes, endothelial cells, and some epithelial cells. The viral genome persists in B-cells in a latent state, and this plays a key role in the pathogenesis of Kaposi's sarcoma, primary effusion lymphoma, and multicentric Castleman disease. It is not found in T-cells, neutrophils, or monocytes as the main reservoir

questions.subject: PATHOLOGY
questions.que: A low CD4 count before starting ART is an important risk factor for development of
questions.ref_book: In HIV patients, very low CD4 counts predispose to opportunistic fungal infections. Among the options, mucormycosis is strongly associated with severe immunosuppression and uncontrolled diabetes. Tuberculosis is also common in HIV, but it is not strictly dependent on CD4 count levels. Aspergillosis is more frequent in neutropenia rather than low CD4

questions.subject: PATHOLOGY
questions.que: A patient with elevated serum alpha-fetoprotein has a liver mass with crowded cells, thick cords/plates, occasional mitoses, and necrosis. The MOST LIKELY diagnosis is?
questions.ref_book: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is strongly associated with elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP). Histology shows crowded hepatocyte-like cells, thickened trabeculae/cords, mitotic activity, and necrosis. Hepatocellular adenoma and focal nodular hyperplasia do not usually show AFP elevation or such malignant histology. Cholangiocarcinoma is AFP-negative

questions.subject: PATHOLOGY
questions.que: Anemia in humans can be caused by which of the following worms
questions.ref_book: Hookworms (Ancylostoma duodenale, Necator americanus) attach to the intestinal mucosa and suck blood, leading to chronic blood loss and iron-deficiency anemia. Roundworms, tapeworms, and pork worms do not commonly cause significant anemia.

questions.subject: PATHOLOGY
questions.que: Weight of hemoglobin in RBC is
questions.ref_book: Hemoglobin constitutes about 90% of the dry weight of a red blood cell, making it the major functional component responsible for oxygen transport.

questions.subject: PATHOLOGY
questions.que: Red cell membrane defects include the following except
questions.ref_book: Membrane defects cause abnormal RBC shapes such as spherocytosis, ovalocytosis, and echinocytosis. Leptocytosis (target cells) is mainly due to hemoglobin disorders (e.g., thalassemia, liver disease), not a primary membrane defect.

questions.ref_book: Dendritic cells are the most efficient and potent antigen-presenting cells (APCs). While macrophages and B-cells also function as APCs, dendritic cells are the most effective.

questions.que: Total safety factor against edema is
questions.ref_book: The safety factor against edema refers to the combined protective mechanisms that prevent fluid accumulation in the interstitium. These include low interstitial compliance, increased lymphatic drainage, and plasma colloid osmotic pressure. Together, they provide a safety margin of about 17 mm Hg before edema develops

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Blood clotting is an example for
questions.ref_book: Blood clotting is a classic example of positive feedback. When a vessel is injured, platelets adhere to the damaged area and release chemicals that attract more platelets. This amplifying cycle continues until a stable clot forms. Unlike negative feedback, which maintains homeostasis by opposing a change, positive feedback enhances or accelerates the process(Essentials of Medical Physiology by K Sembulingam 10th Edition(2025), Page No - 41)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: What percentage of the total blood volume is plasma?
questions.ref_book: Blood consists of two major components: plasma and formed elements (RBCs, WBCs, and platelets). Plasma accounts for about 55% of the total blood volume, while the cellular components make up the remaining 45%. Plasma is primarily water (about 91-92%) and contains proteins, nutrients, electrolytes, hormones, and waste products.(Essentials of Medical Physiology by K Sembulingam 10th Edition(2025), Page No - 312)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: The plasma proteins exert an oncotic pressure of about
questions.ref_book: Plasma oncotic pressure (also called colloid osmotic pressure) is mainly generated by albumin, the most abundant plasma protein. It plays a critical role in maintaining fluid balance by drawing water into capillaries from the interstitial space. This pressure averages around 25 mm Hg, which helps counterbalance hydrostatic pressure and prevents excessive fluid loss into tissues.(Essentials of Medical Physiology by K Sembulingam 10th Edition(2025), Page No - 56)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which of the following protein transports cell-free hemoglobin?
questions.ref_book: Haptoglobin is a plasma glycoprotein that binds free hemoglobin released during hemolysis. This binding prevents the loss of iron through the kidneys and protects renal tissues from oxidative damage. The haptoglobin-hemoglobin complex is then removed by the reticuloendothelial system, particularly in the liver. Albumin, hemopexin, and transferrin have other transport roles (fatty acids, heme, and iron respectively), not free hemoglobin

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Most of the water in the human body is found in the
questions.ref_book:
Approximately two-thirds (about 66%) of total body water is located inside cells, making the intracellular fluid (ICF) the largest fluid compartment. The remaining one-third is in the extracellular fluid (ECF), which includes plasma and interstitial fluid. Therefore, the ICF holds the majority of the body's water.
(Essentials of Medical Physiology by K Sembulingam 10th Edition(2025), Page No - 46)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which of the following solution is hypertonic?
questions.ref_book:
20% mannitol is a hypertonic solution, meaning it has a higher osmolality than plasma. It draws water out of cells and is commonly used to reduce intracranial pressure or cerebral edema.

0.9% NaCl is isotonic,

5% dextrose is isotonic when infused but becomes hypotonic after glucose metabolism,

Distilled water is strongly hypotonic and dangerous if infused IV.(Essentials of Medical Physiology by K Sembulingam 10th Edition(2025), Page No - 49)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: The total blood volume is
questions.ref_book: The average total blood volume in a healthy adult is approximately 70-80 mL/kg of body weight. This means a 70 kg adult has about 5-5.5 liters of blood. The correct value among the options is 80 mL/kg, which is especially accurate for males and adults in general physiology estimations(Essentials of Medical Physiology by K Sembulingam 10th Edition(2025), Page No - 133)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR) is increased in
questions.ref_book: Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR) reflects the rate at which RBCs settle in a vertical tube over one hour. In anemia, the lower RBC count leads to less resistance to sedimentation, and increased plasma proteins (like fibrinogen and globulins) promote rouleaux formation, thus increasing ESR. In contrast, polycythemia reduces ESR due to higher RBC concentration, and hypofibrinogenemia lowers ESR due to decreased fibrinogen. Spherocytosis also lowers ESR because the altered shape of RBCs resists rouleaux formation.(Essentials of Medical Physiology by K Sembulingam 10th Edition(2025), Page No - 78)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: The H antigen is usually present in individuals of
questions.ref_book: The H antigen is the precursor on which A and B antigens are formed. People with Type O blood lack A or B antigens, so the H antigen remains unmodified and fully expressed. Individuals with Type A, B, or AB have enzymes that convert the H antigen into A or B antigens, thus reducing its availability. Therefore, Type O individuals have the highest amount of H antigen on their red cells.(Essentials of Medical Physiology by K Sembulingam 10th Edition(2025), Page No - 130)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which of the following promotes the rouleaux formation?
questions.ref_book: Fibrinogen promotes rouleaux formation by reducing zeta potential between RBCs, leading to stacking.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 506)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Hypersegmented Neutrophils are seen in
questions.ref_book: In megaloblastic anemia, nuclear maturation is delayed, causing hypersegmentation in neutrophils.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 503)

questions.que: A type of white blood cell in the alveoli of lungs
questions.ref_book: Dust cells are alveolar macrophages responsible for phagocytosing particles and pathogens in lungs.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 623)

questions.que: Bleeding time is prolonged in
questions.ref_book: Bleeding time is a measure of platelet function and capillary integrity. It is prolonged in conditions with platelet deficiency(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 579-580)
