questions.que: Thiosulphate is used to measure the volume of
questions.ref_book: Thiosulfate, inulin, mannitol, and radioactive sodium are indicators used to measure ECF volume because they distribute only in extracellular space.(GK Pal p. 65-66)

questions.que: Aspirin in low dose prevents myocardial infarction by
questions.ref_book: Low-dose aspirin irreversibly inhibits COX-1, reducing thromboxane A2, a potent vasoconstrictor and platelet aggregator.(GK Pal p. 852)

questions.que: Opsonization and phagocytosis of bacteria is carried out by

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: A 30-year-old Rh-negative mother delivered her second child (Rh-positive) with signs of jaundice, anaemia, edema, and kernicterus. What will be your diagnosis?
questions.ref_book: Classic case of hemolytic disease of the newborn due to Rh incompatibility. Features include anemia, jaundice, hydrops fetalis, and kernicterus.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 578)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which of the following methods is NOT used for measurement of body fluid measurement?
questions.ref_book: Radio-iodinated human serum albumin (RISA) is used for plasma volume. Blood volume is calculated using tagged RBCs like 51Cr.(GK Pal,Page 65-66.)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Total cross sectional area is greater in
questions.ref_book: Although individual capillaries are tiny, their enormous number gives them the greatest total cross-sectional area of all vascular segments. This large area reduces blood velocity, allowing efficient exchange of gases, nutrients, and waste products

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: J receptors was discovered by
questions.ref_book: Juxtacapillary (J) receptors are sensory nerve endings in the alveolar walls near pulmonary capillaries, stimulated by pulmonary congestion and edema. They were first described by A. S. Paintal in the 1950s. Stimulation causes rapid, shallow breathing and a feeling of dyspnea.

questions.que: All are causes of obstructive shock except
questions.ref_book: Essentials Of Medical Physiology by K Sembulingam, 9th Edition(2023), Page No : 609

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: In athletes bradycardia is because of
questions.ref_book: Well-trained athletes often have resting bradycardia due to enhanced parasympathetic (vagal) activity and reduced sympathetic drive, which lowers the resting heart rate. It is not due to low venous return or decreased cardiac output, since athletes usually have higher stroke volume and efficient cardiac function

questions.que: "Last ditch stand" pressure control mechanism is by
questions.ref_book: The CNS ischemic response activates when BP falls below 40 mm Hg to maintain perfusion to vital centers.(GK Pal, Page 834)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Frank - Starling's law implies
questions.option_a: Increase in venous return increases cardiac output
questions.option_b: Increased vagal discharge increases cardiac output
questions.option_c: Increased heart rate causes increased cardiac output
questions.option_d: Increased blood pressure increases cardiac output
questions.ref_book: Greater end-diastolic volume stretches myocardium, increasing stroke volume-this is intrinsic regulation.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 550)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: "Machinery murmur" is heard in
questions.ref_book: PDA produces a continuous murmur heard throughout systole and diastole, described as machinery-like.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 556)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Transit time from arteriolar to the venular end of an average-sized capillary is
questions.ref_book: Mean capillary transit time is 3-4 seconds, allowing adequate exchange.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 597)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which of the following is a vasodilator?
questions.ref_book: Bradykinin causes vasodilation by stimulating NO (nitric oxide) release from endothelial cells(GK Pal, Page 837)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Windkessel effect is seen in
questions.ref_book: The elastic recoil of the aorta helps maintain continuous blood flow during diastole - this is the Windkessel effect.(GK Pal, Page 810-811)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which one of the following is the most powerful cardioaccelerator and vasoconstrictor?
questions.ref_book: The CNS ischemic response (activated when BP < 40 mm Hg) is the most potent pressor reflex, increasing BP and HR drastically.(GK Pal, Page 834-835)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: The blood pressure below which the vessels collapse and blood flow ceases is
questions.ref_book: Critical closing pressure is the pressure below which blood vessels collapse, even if not zero, and flow stops.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 581-582)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Delay in impulse conduction in the heart occurs at
questions.ref_book: AV nodal conduction is slow (0.05 m/s) due to small fibers, few gap junctions, and Ca??-based action potentials, causing AV nodal delay (~0.1s)(GK Pal, Page 743-744)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: ___________ acts as a primer pump.
questions.ref_book: The atria contract before the ventricles and pump a small additional volume of blood into the ventricles, acting as a "primer pump" to enhance ventricular filling(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 544)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Cardiotachometer is an instrument used to diagnose
questions.ref_book: A cardiotachometer continuously records heart rate from ECG and is used to detect variations like sinus arrhythmia, where heart rate varies with respiration.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 543)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: The phenomenon of "Overdrive suppression" is seen in
questions.ref_book: Overdrive suppression is the temporary suppression of pacemaker activity in latent pacemakers after a period of faster-than-normal stimulation, observed in cases like Stokes-Adams syndrome(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 551)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Significance of Reynolds number (Re) is to
questions.ref_book: Reynolds number is a dimensionless quantity that predicts whether blood flow will be laminar or turbulent. When it exceeds ~2000, turbulence may occur.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 522)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Wave that is seen in old recovered Myocardial Infarction is
questions.ref_book: A deep or prominent Q wave represents myocardial necrosis and is a typical ECG sign of a previous (old) myocardial infarction.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 557)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which is called "pressure buffer system"
questions.ref_book: The baroreceptor reflex stabilizes short-term fluctuations in blood pressure, acting as a pressure buffer to maintain homeostasis.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 591)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: 80% of the total colloid osmotic pressure of plasma results from ____________
questions.ref_book: Albumin, due to its high concentration and smaller size, contributes about 80% of the plasma colloid osmotic pressure, helping retain fluid within blood vessels.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 491)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Most common site of myocardial infarction is ____________
questions.ref_book: The subendocardial region of the left ventricle is the most vulnerable to ischemia and is the most common site for myocardial infarction due to its high oxygen demand and low perfusion.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 557)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Sympathomimetic drugs have not proved to be beneficial in
questions.ref_book: In neurogenic shock, the issue is loss of vascular tone due to autonomic disruption. Sympathomimetics are often ineffective unless volume is restored and underlying cause addressed.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 614)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which of the following formulae gives mean arterial pressure?
questions.ref_book: Mean arterial pressure ? Diastolic pressure + 1/3 Pulse pressure ((Ganong  24th Edition, Fig. 31-26).(Ganong  24th Edition, Page No -591)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Starling's law gives the relationship between
questions.ref_book: Starling's law: stroke volume is proportional to end-diastolic volume (Frank-Starling curve).(Ganong  24th Edition, Page No -577)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which of the following statements is TRUE about total peripheral resistance?
questions.option_a: It is high in pregnant women because of placenta
questions.option_b: It is due to large arteries
questions.option_c: It is low in septic shock
questions.ref_book: Baroreceptor stimulation increases mean circulatory filling pressure during stress/shock conditions.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page No -592)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which of the following phenomena is responsible for the ST segment of ECG?
questions.option_b: Plateau phase of ventricular action potentials
questions.ref_book: Electrocardiogram (ECG) represents the plateau phase of ventricular action potential, specifically the period between ventricular depolarization and repolarization(Ganong  24th Edition, Page No -571)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Slow waves in the GIT are believed to be initiated by
questions.ref_book: Slow waves are rhythmic fluctuations in membrane potential seen in gastrointestinal smooth muscle. These are not action potentials, but they set the pace for GI motility. They are generated by specialized pacemaker cells called Interstitial cells of Cajal (ICCs), which are located near the myenteric plexus. These cells help coordinate peristalsis by controlling the timing of contractions(Essentials of Medical Physiology by K Sembulingam 10th Edition(2025), Page No - 250)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Acidification of bile occurs in the
questions.ref_book: Bile is secreted by hepatocytes in the liver, but it becomes more concentrated and acidic while stored in the gall bladder. The gall bladder absorbs water, sodium, and bicarbonate, making the bile more acidic and concentrated. This acidification helps with fat emulsification during digestion. The duodenum receives this acidic bile upon stimulation by food, particularly fats(Essentials of Medical Physiology by K Sembulingam 10th Edition(2025), Page No - 228)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Fructose is transported across the apical membrane of enterocyte by
questions.ref_book: Fructose is absorbed in the small intestine by facilitated diffusion via the GLUT 5 transporter located on the apical membrane of enterocytes. It is then transported into the bloodstream via GLUT 2 on the basolateral membrane. Unlike glucose and galactose (which use SGLT-1, a sodium-dependent transporter), fructose absorption is insulin-independent and does not involve GLUT 4(Essentials of Medical Physiology by K Sembulingam 10th Edition(2025), Page No - 147)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which of the following hormone is secreted by the stomach and plays an important role in the central control of food intake?
questions.ref_book: Ghrelin is the only orexigenic (appetite-stimulating) hormone known to be secreted by the stomach. It acts centrally on the hypothalamus, particularly the arcuate nucleus, to stimulate hunger and food intake. While gastrin, CCK, and Peptide YY are gastrointestinal hormones, none of them has a primary role in central appetite regulation like ghrelin. Thus, the correct answer is ghrelin(Essentials of Medical Physiology by K Sembulingam 10th Edition(2025), Page No - 259)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Normally the angle between the anus and the rectum is approximately
questions.ref_book: At rest, the anorectal angle is approximately 90-100?, which helps maintain continence by creating a mechanical barrier. This angle straightens during defecation.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 545 (Figure 27-10))

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: In acute pancreatitis, which of the following causes disruption of pancreatic tissue and necrosis of the surrounding fat?
questions.ref_book: Trypsin activates phospholipase A2, which converts phosphatidylcholine to lyso-phosphatidylcholine (lyso-PC), damaging cell membranes. All listed substances play roles in pathogenesis.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 489)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: The calcium-binding protein that plays a key role in the regulation of smooth muscle cell contraction is
questions.ref_book: Calmodulin binds Calcium and activates MLCK, initiating smooth muscle contraction.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 95)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: The proenzyme pepsinogen is secreted mainly from which of the following structures?
questions.ref_book: Chief cells in the gastric glands of the stomach secrete pepsinogen, a precursor to pepsin.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 512)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: The following are the functions of bile salts except
questions.option_c: Fats are converted into fatty acids and glycerol
questions.ref_book: Bile salts do reduce surface tension, emulsify fats, form micelles, and aid digestion-but do not directly convert fats into fatty acids and glycerol (this is done by lipases, not bile salts).(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 494)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: The myenteric plexus of the oesophagus is deficient at the ?Lower Esophageal Sphincter' in which of the following conditions?
questions.ref_book: The myenteric plexus controls GI motility. Its damage leads to achalasia cardia, where LES fails to relax.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 491)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Hormone that causes secretion of pancreatic juice rich in bicarbonate ions is
questions.ref_book: Secretin, secreted from S cells in the duodenum, stimulates pancreatic duct cells to secrete bicarbonate-rich alkaline juice. It is the key regulator for neutralizing gastric acid in the duodenum.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 525; (GK Pal p. 366-368)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which of the following is true regarding fructose absorption in the intestine?
questions.ref_book: Fructose is absorbed by facilitated diffusion via GLUT5 on the apical membrane and GLUT2 on the basolateral membrane. It does not use sodium cotransport or SGLT1.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 531; (GK Pal p. 423)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which of the following cells in the stomach secretes HCl?
questions.ref_book: Parietal (oxyntic) cells, located in the body of stomach glands, secrete hydrochloric acid (HCl) and intrinsic factor. Other cells (like ECL) release histamine, not acid.(GK Pal p. 350-351; (Ganong  24th Edition, p. 505)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Trypsinogen is converted to trypsin by the action of
questions.ref_book: Enterokinase (enteropeptidase) from duodenal mucosa activates trypsinogen to trypsin, initiating protein digestion.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 530)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Myenteric plexus is present in
questions.ref_book: The myenteric (Auerbach's) plexus lies between the longitudinal and circular layers of smooth muscle and regulates GI motility.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 507)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Frequency of slow waves in the stomach is
questions.ref_book: Gastric slow waves occur at 3 per minute, initiated by interstitial cells of Cajal in the body of the stomach.(GK Pal p. 395)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which of the following is NOT a liver function test?
questions.ref_book: Blood urea reflects kidney function, though the urea is synthesized in liver, it's not a standard liver function test.(GK Pal, Page 373-374)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which of the following statement is FALSE?
questions.option_a: Meissner's plexus is responsible for gastrointestinal motility
questions.option_b: Auerbach's plexus is present in the muscular layer
questions.option_c: Sympathetic nerves inhibit the nervous system and decrease the motility
questions.option_d: Parasympathetic system is responsible for watery secretion
questions.ref_book: Meissner's plexus controls secretion, not motility. Auerbach's plexus controls motility.(GK Pal, Page 331)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which of the following cell is responsible for bone resorption?
questions.ref_book: Osteoclasts are large, multinucleated cells derived from monocyte/macrophage lineage (not osteoblasts or hematopoietic stem cells directly) and are responsible for bone resorption. They secrete enzymes and acids that break down bone matrix, releasing calcium and phosphate into the bloodstream. In contrast, osteoblasts build bone, and osteocytes maintain it(Essentials of Medical Physiology by K Sembulingam 10th Edition(2025), Page No - 380)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: All the following increase Growth hormone secretion Except
questions.ref_book: Growth hormone (GH) secretion is stimulated by factors such as stress, exercise, and fasting, primarily via increased GHRH and decreased somatostatin. However, cortisol, a glucocorticoid, when chronically elevated, inhibits GH secretion and its actions. It leads to catabolic effects and may suppress pituitary function over time, making it the correct exception in this list(Essentials of Medical Physiology by K Sembulingam 10th Edition(2025), Page No - 350)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: The Syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion (SIADH) is characterized by
questions.ref_book: In Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone Secretion (SIADH), there is excessive ADH release, leading to increased water reabsorption in the kidneys. This dilutes the blood, causing hyponatremia and low serum osmolarity. Blood volume may be normal or slightly increased, and blood pressure is usually not severely low. Therefore, the hallmark finding is low serum osmolarity despite inappropriately high ADH levels.(Essentials of Medical Physiology by K Sembulingam 10th Edition(2025), Page No - 357)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Apparent Mineralocorticoid Excess is due to absence of
questions.ref_book: Deficiency of 11?-HSD2 prevents conversion of cortisol to cortisone, leading to cortisol binding mineralocorticoid receptors, mimicking aldosterone excess.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 361)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which of the following actions of catecholamines requires the permissive action of Glucocorticoids?
questions.ref_book: Metabolic actions include lipolysis and calorigenesis. Vasopressor effect is cardiovascular, not metabolic.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 335-336)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Wolff-Chaikoff effect is
questions.option_a: Feedback inhibition of TSH by T3
questions.option_b: Transient inhibition of thyroid hormone synthesis by large doses of iodide
questions.option_c: Movement of iodine into the colloid for organification
questions.option_d: Endocytosis of colloid during release of thyroid hormones
questions.ref_book: The Wolff-Chaikoff effect is a protective response where excess iodine transiently inhibits thyroid hormone synthesis.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 360)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Metabolic syndrome of obesity includes all except
questions.ref_book: Metabolic syndrome includes insulin resistance, central obesity, hyperlipidemia, and hypertension-not decreased insulin levels. In fact, hyperinsulinemia is characteristic.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 255)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: The binding of iodine with the thyroglobulin molecule is called
questions.ref_book: Organification is the process where iodide is oxidized to iodine, which then binds with tyrosine residues in thyroglobulin-a key step in thyroid hormone synthesis.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 328; (GK Pal p. 486)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: All of the following are features of hypothyroidism except
questions.ref_book: Constipation, weight gain, fatigue are common in hypothyroidism. Sleep is often increased, not decreased.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 323)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which of the following hormones acts in the cell nucleus?
questions.ref_book: Thyroid hormones (like steroid hormones) act via intracellular receptors in the nucleus, regulating gene transcription.(GK Pal p. 449)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which one of the following is the clinical feature of acromegaly?
questions.ref_book: Acromegaly leads to soft tissue and bone overgrowth-especially prognathism (jaw protrusion), enlarged hands/feet.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 275)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Wolff-Chaikoff effect is due to
questions.ref_book: Sudden high iodine intake temporarily inhibits organification and thyroid hormone synthesis (Wolff-Chaikoff effect).(GK Pal p. 488)

questions.option_a: ADH secretion is increased despite hyperosmolality
questions.option_b: ADH secretion is increased despite hypoosmolality
questions.option_c: ADH secretion is increased despite isoosmolality
questions.option_d: ADH secretion is decreased despite hypoosmolality
questions.ref_book: In SIADH, ADH is secreted inappropriately even when plasma is hypo-osmolar, leading to water retention and hyponatremia.(GK Pal, Page 477)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Somatomedin deficiency causes:
questions.ref_book: Laron dwarfism is due to GH receptor defect, leading to low IGF-1 (somatomedin C) despite normal/high GH(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 325)

questions.option_d: Increasing the release of interleukin-1 from white blood cells
questions.ref_book: Cortisol stabilizes lysosomal membranes, suppresses cytokine release, and reduces capillary permeability(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 351)

questions.ref_book: VMA is a major metabolite of catecholamines; its increase in urine is diagnostic for pheochromocytoma.(GK Pal, Page 513)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Regression of tissues as in uterine regression after pregnancy is a function of
questions.ref_book: Lysosomes contain powerful digestive enzymes capable of breaking down cellular debris and unwanted organelles. During physiological events like uterine involution after pregnancy, these enzymes facilitate autolysis and removal of excess cells. This function is distinct from secretory vesicles (which release materials), peroxisomes (which handle oxidative reactions), and the nucleus (which controls genetic activity). Thus, lysosomes are the organelles responsible for tissue regression(Essentials of Medical Physiology by K Sembulingam 10th Edition(2025), Page No - 9)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which of the following attaches cells to the basal lamina?
questions.ref_book: Hemidesmosomes are specialized structures that anchor the basal surface of epithelial cells to the basal lamina. Unlike desmosomes (which link cells to each other), hemidesmosomes connect the cell's cytoskeleton to the extracellular matrix via integrins and intermediate filaments, providing strong adhesion between the cell and basement membrane(Essentials of Medical Physiology by K Sembulingam 10th Edition(2025), Page No - 27)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which is the major site of attachment of intracellular actin filaments?
questions.ref_book: The zona adherens (adherens junction) is a type of anchoring junction located just below the tight junctions in epithelial cells. It serves as the main attachment site for actin filaments, linking the actin cytoskeleton of one cell to another via cadherin proteins. Zona occludens (tight junctions) seal spaces between cells, while desmosomes connect intermediate filaments, and hemidesmosomes attach cells to the basal lamina(Essentials of Medical Physiology by K Sembulingam 10th Edition(2025), Page No - 26)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which of the following cellular organelle contain oxidases?
questions.ref_book: Peroxisomes contains oxidases and catalases(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 20-21)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which of the following cytoskeletal proteins serve as conveyor belts for the intracellular transport of vesicles and granules?
questions.ref_book: They serve as conveyor belts along which motor proteins like kinesin and dynein transport vesicles, organelles, and granules.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 25)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which control mechanism operates during rapid movements of the body?
questions.ref_book: In feed-forward control, the controller anticipates the change and initiates a response to prevent the change. This mechanism is important in rapid muscular activities where reliance on feedback would be too slow.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 14-15)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Synthesis of lipid substances in the cell occurs at the
questions.ref_book: Lipid synthesis (e.g., steroid hormones, phospholipids) is primarily carried out in the smooth/agranular endoplasmic reticulum.(GK Pal p. 16-17)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Transport of lipid insoluble substances across the cell membrane through protein channels is an example of
questions.ref_book: Lipid-insoluble substances like glucose and amino acids require secondary active transport, typically via Na?-coupled co-transporters.(GK Pal p. 44-46)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which one of the following measurements is a reasonable indicator of plasma osmolarity?
questions.ref_book: Plasma osmolality is primarily determined by sodium, glucose, and urea. Sodium has the highest contribution (~90%).(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 11)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Positive feedback mechanism is seen
questions.option_a: Secretion of insulin by blood glucose
questions.ref_book: The LH surge before ovulation is the classic example of positive feedback, where rising estrogen levels from the dominant follicle stimulate further LH release.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 440-441)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Diffusion rate depends on all EXCEPT
questions.ref_book: Although temperature influences molecular motion, it is not a variable in Fick's law, which includes concentration gradient, surface area, and membrane thickness as main factors.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 7)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which of the following muscle cannot be tetanized?
questions.ref_book: Cardiac muscle cannot be tetanized due to its long absolute refractory period, which nearly matches the duration of contraction. This prevents the possibility of another contraction being initiated before the first one is over, thus protecting the heart from sustained contractions (tetany) that would be fatal. In contrast, skeletal and smooth muscles can undergo tetanus under continuous stimulation

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: The end plate potential is characterized by
questions.ref_book: An end plate potential (EPP) is a local depolarization of the muscle membrane at the neuromuscular junction. It occurs when acetylcholine binds to nicotinic receptors, allowing sodium to enter and generate a mild, graded depolarization. It does not propagate, nor does it follow the all-or-none law, and it is not a hyperpolarization. Its role is to bring the membrane potential closer to the threshold to trigger an action potential.(Essentials of Medical Physiology by K Sembulingam 10th Edition(2025), Page No - 182)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which one of the following acts postsynaptically, blocking the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors and preventing the excitation of the muscle cell membrane?
questions.ref_book:
Curare (e.g., d-tubocurarine) acts postsynaptically at the neuromuscular junction by blocking nicotinic acetylcholine receptors. This prevents ACh from binding, thereby inhibiting the generation of end plate potentials and blocking muscle contraction.

Botulinum toxin acts presynaptically, preventing ACh release.

Neostigmine inhibits acetylcholinesterase, increasing ACh levels.

Tetrodotoxin blocks voltage-gated Na? channels on neurons, not at the NMJ.(Essentials of Medical Physiology by K Sembulingam 10th Edition(2025), Page No - 182)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: The minimum stimulus intensity that produces a compound action potential in nerve or muscle is called
questions.ref_book:
Rheobase is the minimum current strength (intensity) of infinite duration required to generate a minimal response (i.e., action potential) in a nerve or muscle fiber. It defines the threshold excitability of tissue.

Chronaxie is the minimum time required for a stimulus twice the rheobase intensity to produce a response.

"Twice rheobase" or "twice chronaxie" are not definitions, but derived concepts(Essentials of Medical Physiology by K Sembulingam 10th Edition(2025), Page No - 160)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Contraction of muscles which help in maintaining posture against gravity is an example of
questions.ref_book:
Isometric contractions occur when a muscle generates force without changing its length. This happens when the muscle contracts but does not shorten or lengthen, as in holding a position against resistance.

Maintaining posture-like standing upright or holding the head up-involves muscles contracting without producing movement, just enough to oppose gravity. These static contractions stabilize joints and body segments without visible movement, making isometric contraction the correct type involved in postural maintenance(Essentials of Medical Physiology by K Sembulingam 10th Edition(2025), Page No - 161)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: The T system in cardiac muscle is located at the
questions.ref_book: The T system (transverse tubules) in muscle fibers helps conduct action potentials deep into the muscle. In skeletal muscle, T tubules are found at the A-I junction, but in cardiac muscle, they are located at the Z-lines. This anatomical difference reflects adaptations in excitation-contraction coupling between the two muscle types

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which of the following drugs would likely alleviate myasthenia gravis patient's symptoms?
questions.ref_book: Atropine, a muscarinic antagonist, relaxes bronchial smooth muscle. Neostigmine would worsen bronchospasm.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 117)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which of the following is not true regarding Type I skeletal muscle fibers?
questions.ref_book: Type I fibers are oxidative, with low glycolytic capacity. They rely on aerobic metabolism, rich in mitochondria and myoglobin.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 99)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Initiation of skeletal muscle contraction occurs when Calcium binds with
questions.ref_book: Calcium binds to troponin-C, which induces a conformational change that allows actin-myosin interaction.(GK Pal p. 262-263)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Group B nerve fibers are more susceptible to
questions.ref_book: Type B fibers (preganglionic autonomic) are most sensitive to hypoxia, unlike A fibers (pressure) and C fibers (local anesthetics).(GK Pal p. 238)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: A 45-year-old woman complains of muscle weakness which becomes worse during activity and improved by rest. She may be suffering from
questions.ref_book: Myasthenia gravis shows fatigable muscle weakness that improves with rest. It's due to antibodies against ACh receptors at the neuromuscular junction.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 111)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Depolarization stage of action potential is characterized by:

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: The synapse in cerebral and cerebellar cortex is located commonly in the _________.
questions.ref_book: Many presynaptic neurons terminate on dendritic spines in the cerebral and cerebellar cortex(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 116)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Jendrassik's maneuver facilitates knee jerk due to increased ___________ discharge.
questions.ref_book: The maneuver increases ? motor neuron discharge, enhancing muscle spindle sensitivity(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 233)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Annulospiral endings are
questions.ref_book: Annulospiral endings are primary sensory endings of group Ia afferents on intrafusal fibers(GK Pal, Page 1050)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which of the nucleus plays a major role in cognitive control of motor activity?
questions.ref_book: Caudate nucleus is involved in cognitive functions through its frontal neocortical connections.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 261)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Thalamus contains inhibitory neurons in
questions.ref_book: The thalamic reticular nucleus contains GABAergic inhibitory neurons that modulate activity of other thalamic neurons.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 251)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Mossy fibers in the cerebellum make direct synaptic connection with
questions.ref_book: Mossy fibers synapse with granule cells, which project via parallel fibers to excite Purkinje, basket, and stellate cells.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 233)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Normal CSF pressure when a person is lying in horizontal position averages
questions.ref_book: Normal lumbar CSF pressure in recumbent position is 100-180 mm H?O, with average ~110 mm H?O.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 739)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Nociceptive stimuli are detected by
questions.ref_book: Free nerve endings are responsible for detecting pain (nociceptive stimuli), temperature, and crude touch. They are unencapsulated and widely distributed.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page: 136)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Posterior column carries all sensations except
questions.ref_book: The posterior (dorsal) columns carry fine touch, proprioception, and vibration. Itch and tickle are transmitted via the anterolateral system (spinothalamic tract)(Ganong  24th Edition, Page: 134)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which of the following occurs after parasympathetic stimulation?
questions.ref_book: Parasympathetic stimulation causes contraction of the detrusor muscle (for urination) and constriction of pupils. Bronchodilation and ejaculation are sympathetic effects.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page: 264)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which of the following is negative memory?
questions.ref_book: Habituation is a form of non-associative learning where repeated exposure to a stimulus results in a decreased response. It is termed negative memory because it leads to forgetting or ignoring irrelevant stimuli.(Ganong  24th Edition,  Page: 289)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Planning of sequential movements occurs at
questions.ref_book: The cerebrocerebellum is involved in the planning and timing of complex and sequential voluntary movements.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page: 272)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: The ?positive' apnea test indicates
questions.ref_book: A positive apnea test is used in the confirmation of brain death. It involves removal of ventilatory support to see if spontaneous breathing resumes; absence indicates loss of brainstem function(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 292)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Artificial hypothermia is induced in
questions.ref_book: Hypothermia reduces metabolic demands and is intentionally induced during cardiac surgery to protect organs (especially the brain and heart) from ischemic injury(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 11)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Thermostatic body temperature control center is located in the
questions.ref_book: The preoptic area of the anterior hypothalamus contains thermosensitive neurons and acts as the principal thermoregulatory center.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 740)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Prepotential is due to:
questions.ref_book: The pacemaker potential (prepotential) in SA node is primarily due to the gradual opening of long-lasting Ca?? channels (L-type) and funny Na? channels (If) leading to spontaneous depolarization(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 555)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Type of fibre responsible for carrying motor signals to muscle spindle
questions.ref_book: Gamma motor neurons (A? fibers) innervate intrafusal fibers of the muscle spindle, regulating its sensitivity to stretch.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 253)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Types of muscarinic cholinergic receptors present in CNS are
questions.ref_book: The muscarinic receptors M1, M4, and M5 are found in various regions of the central nervous system, where they modulate neurotransmission and cognitive function.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 124)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: A receptor that never fully adapts is
questions.ref_book: Baroreceptors adapt slowly and never fully adapt, allowing them to continuously monitor changes in arterial pressure and maintain homeostasis.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 523)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Corticospinal and corticobulbar tract neurons are located in __________ of the cerebral cortex
questions.ref_book: Layer V of the cerebral cortex contains the large pyramidal neurons (Betz cells), which give rise to the corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts involved in voluntary motor control.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 260)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Herpes virus infects __________________.
questions.ref_book: Herpes simplex and varicella-zoster viruses remain latent in dorsal root ganglia, from where they can reactivate to cause conditions like shingles.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 133)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: The rate of impulses generated from the vestibular hair cells in resting condition is
questions.ref_book: Vestibular hair cells exhibit a tonic discharge rate of about 100 impulses/second even at rest, allowing detection of changes in position or movement.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 197)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Higher intellectual functions are linked to
questions.ref_book: The prefrontal cortex is responsible for executive functions such as decision-making, planning, reasoning, and social behavior-collectively called higher intellectual functions.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 274)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Botulinum toxin A and E act on ______________ docking protein
questions.ref_book: Botulinum toxins A and E cleave SNAP-25, a SNARE complex protein essential for synaptic vesicle docking and neurotransmitter release at neuromuscular junctions.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 116)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Brown-S?quard syndrome occurs due to
questions.ref_book: Brown-S?quard syndrome results from hemisection of the spinal cord, causing ipsilateral motor loss and proprioception, and contralateral pain and temperature loss.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 134)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which substance activates adrenergic alpha and beta receptors equally?
questions.ref_book: Epinephrine is a non-selective adrenergic agonist that activates both alpha and beta receptors, while norepinephrine has less effect on beta-2 receptors.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 115)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Bilateral removal of hippocampus will lead to
questions.ref_book: The hippocampus is critical for forming new long-term memories. Its bilateral removal leads to anterograde amnesia, an inability to form new memories.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 287)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Appearance of sleep spindles in EEG represents
questions.ref_book: Sleep spindles, along with K-complexes, are EEG features of Stage II non-REM sleep and indicate the onset of true sleep.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 292)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Final common pathway is exhibited by
questions.ref_book: The alpha motor neuron is termed the final common pathway because it is the last neuron in the motor pathway that directly innervates skeletal muscle fibers.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 252)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Area essential for initial processing of visual language
questions.ref_book: The angular gyrus is involved in processing written language and converting visual information (words) into meaningful language.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 284)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: The fastest-conducting nerve fibers in the human body are
questions.ref_book: A? fibers have the largest diameter (12-20 ?m) and the highest conduction velocity (70-120 m/s), primarily mediating proprioception and motor signals.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page No -92)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which of the following is TRUE regarding graded potential?
questions.option_d: It is larger in amplitude than an action potential
questions.ref_book: Unlike action potentials, graded potentials are not all-or-none and can summate to reach threshold, resulting in stronger depolarization.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page No -230)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: The sense of pain and temperature is carried by which tract?
questions.ref_book: Pain and temperature sensations are transmitted by the ventrolateral spinothalamic pathway, which crosses the midline in the spinal cord.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page No -167)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: The receptor for the inverse stretch reflex is
questions.ref_book: The Golgi tendon organ detects tension in muscles and mediates the inverse stretch reflex to prevent muscle damage by inhibiting excessive contraction.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page No -232)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which of the following is a feature of a lower motor neuron lesion?
questions.ref_book: Lower motor neuron damage causes flaccid paralysis, muscle atrophy, fasciculations, and hyporeflexia due to loss of direct motor innervation.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page No -240)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Damage to the Wernicke's Area will cause
questions.ref_book: Wernicke's area (posterior superior temporal gyrus) is responsible for language comprehension; damage results in fluent but nonsensical speech and poor understanding.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page No -291)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which of the following is involved in converting short-term memories to long-term memory?
questions.ref_book: The hippocampus consolidates short-term explicit memory into long-term memory by forming stable synaptic connections.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page No -285-288)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Examination of a patient showed pupillary constriction, drooping of the eyelid, and sinking of the eyeball on one side of the face (enophthalmos). There was also vasodilation of blood vessels (flushing) on the affected side with a lack of sweating. What is the probable cause for these findings?
questions.ref_book: Horner's syndrome involves disruption of sympathetic supply to the eye, causing miosis (pupil constriction), ptosis, and anhidrosis.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page No -189)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: A 25-year-old man develops head injury and fracture of the cribriform plate following a motorcycle accident. Which cranial nerve is most likely to be injured in this patient?
questions.ref_book: Fracture of the cribriform plate can damage the olfactory nerve (CN I), leading to anosmia.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page No -604)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Inability of the kidney to concentrate or dilute urine is called
questions.ref_book: Textbook of Physiology by Dr.A.K.Jain, 8th Edition(2019), Page No : 541

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: The major nephron site where titratable acid is formed
questions.ref_book: Textbook of Physiology by Dr.A.K.Jain, 8th Edition(2019), Page No : 524

questions.que: Atonic bladder occurs in destruction of
questions.option_b: Efferent impulses from the spinal cord.
questions.ref_book: Essentials Of Medical Physiology by K Sembulingam, 9th Edition(2023), Page No : 320

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Identify the correct statement,
questions.option_a: The renal medullary blood flow is high
questions.option_b: Vasa recta creates medullary hyper osmolarity
questions.option_c: Medullary blood flow is less than 5% of total renal blood flow
questions.option_d: The U-shaped structure of vessels do not minimize the loss of solutes
questions.ref_book: Essentials Of Medical Physiology by K Sembulingam, 9th Edition(2023), Page No : 297

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Nephrotic syndrome is due to,
questions.option_a: Increased glomerular permeability leading to loss of proteins
questions.ref_book: Nephrotic syndrome is characterized by massive proteinuria (>3.5 g/day), hypoalbuminemia, edema, and hyperlipidemia. The underlying mechanism is increased permeability of the glomerular basement membrane, allowing plasma proteins (especially albumin) to leak into urine

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: The following are loop diuretics except,
questions.ref_book: Essentials Of Medical Physiology by K Sembulingam, 9th Edition(2023), Page No : 324

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: What fraction of filtered water is reabsorbed in the loop of Henle?
questions.ref_book: About 25% of the filtered water is reabsorbed in the loop of Henle, primarily in the thin descending limb, which is permeable to water. The thick ascending limb is impermeable to water but actively reabsorbs ions, helping concentrate the medullary interstitium. This segment plays a crucial role in establishing the osmotic gradient necessary for urine concentration

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: The diuretic that acts by inhibiting carbonic anhydrase activity exerts its effect in
questions.ref_book: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide) act in the proximal tubule, where carbonic anhydrase facilitates the reabsorption of bicarbonate. By inhibiting this enzyme, bicarbonate and sodium reabsorption is reduced, leading to increased diuresis. Other diuretics (like loop diuretics or thiazides) act at different nephron segments.(Essentials of Medical Physiology by K Sembulingam 10th Edition(2025), Page No - 324)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Destruction of sensory nerve fibers to the bladder leads to
questions.ref_book: An atonic bladder results from damage to afferent (sensory) fibers supplying the bladder. Without sensory input, the micturition reflex is not activated, and the bladder becomes distended and flaccid. The detrusor muscle does not contract properly, leading to urinary retention and overflow incontinence. This differs from a hypertonic or automatic bladder, which involve different patterns of neural injury(Essentials of Medical Physiology by K Sembulingam 10th Edition(2025), Page No - 319)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: The tubular transport maximum for glucose in a healthy young man is about
questions.ref_book: TmG (Transport maximum for glucose) is ~375 mg/min in adult men, above which glucosuria occurs.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 730)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: The obligatory 24 hr urine volume to maintain solute homeostasis in a healthy adult male weighing 65 kg and consuming a balanced 2000 calorie diet is approximately
questions.ref_book: The obligatory 24 hr urine volume to maintain solute homeostasis in a healthy adult is 800 to 1200 ml(Ganong  24th Edition, p 740)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: All of the following drugs inhibit Na+ K+ 2Cl- cotransporter in the thick ascending limb of loop of Henle except
questions.ref_book: Loop diuretics (furosemide, ethacrynic acid, bumetanide) inhibit the Na-K-2Cl cotransporter. Acetazolamide inhibits carbonic anhydrase, not the cotransporter.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 740 (Table 37-8))

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which is the fundamental mechanism generating hypertonicity in the renal medullary interstitium?
questions.option_a: Active transport of NaCl in thick ascending limb
questions.option_b: Action of ADH in the collecting ducts
questions.option_c: Passive recirculation of NaCl in the medullary interstitium
questions.ref_book: Active NaCl transport in thick ascending limb is the fundamental process that initiates the countercurrent multiplier mechanism.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 698)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Most important buffer system present in the distal convoluted tubule is
questions.ref_book: The phosphate buffer system is the main buffering agent in distal convoluted tubule.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 503)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Angiotensin II causes all of the following except
questions.ref_book: Angiotensin II increases BP (vasoconstriction), aldosterone, and thirst. But it does not cause vasodilation; rather, it contracts mesangial cells, reducing GFR.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 690)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Cells responsible for acid secretion in the kidney
questions.ref_book: Type A intercalated cells in the collecting duct are the main source of H? secretion in the kidney. They use H?-ATPase pumps and help regulate acid-base balance.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 662)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which of the following potassium-sparing diuretic drugs is an aldosterone antagonist?
questions.ref_book: Spironolactone acts as a competitive antagonist at aldosterone receptors in the distal nephron, reducing Na? reabsorption and K? excretion.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 685-686)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Renin converts
questions.ref_book: Renin cleaves angiotensinogen (from liver) to form angiotensin I, which is then converted to angiotensin II by ACE.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 675-676)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which of the following is not a feature of diabetes insipidus?
questions.ref_book: Polyuria, polydipsia, and dilute urine are key features of DI. Polyphagia is a feature of diabetes mellitus, not DI.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 682)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which of the following causes relaxation of the mesangial cell?
questions.ref_book: Dopamine, released locally in kidneys, causes vasodilation and relaxation of mesangial cells, increasing GFR.(GK Pal p. 681)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Macula densa in the kidney is located in
questions.ref_book: Macula densa is part of the thick ascending limb of loop of Henle, just before the distal convoluted tubule (DCT) starts.(GK Pal p. 667)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Spastic neurogenic bladder is seen in
questions.ref_book: After recovery from spinal shock, loss of higher control leads to spastic neurogenic bladder due to uninhibited reflex contractions.(GK Pal p. 726)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which of the following is used to measure renal plasma flow?
questions.ref_book: PAH clearance is the gold standard for effective renal plasma flow (ERPF) estimation(GK Pal, Page 674)

questions.que: All are secreted by Sertoli cells EXCEPT
questions.ref_book: Essentials Of Medical Physiology by K Sembulingam, 9th Edition(2023), Page No : 421

questions.ref_book: Essentials Of Medical Physiology by K Sembulingam, 9th Edition(2023), Page No : 351

questions.ref_book: Essentials Of Medical Physiology by K Sembulingam, 9th Edition(2023), Page No : 432

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Inhibin inhibits
questions.ref_book: Essentials Of Medical Physiology by K Sembulingam, 9th Edition(2023), Page No : 424

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Fertilization of the ovum by the sperm usually occurs in the
questions.ref_book: The ampulla of the fallopian tube is the widest part and the most common site of fertilization. After fertilization, the zygote travels to the uterine cavity for implantation. Fimbriae help capture the ovum, but fertilization itself occurs in the ampulla

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Failure rate is maximum in which the following contraceptive method
questions.ref_book: Among common contraceptive methods, barrier methods (condoms, diaphragms, cervical caps) have the highest failure rates (up to 12-18 pregnancies per 100 women per year with typical use). IUDs and surgical sterilization have the lowest failure rates, while oral contraceptives are more effective than barriers if taken correctly

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Sperms become motile in,
questions.ref_book: Spermatozoa released from the testes are immature and non-motile. As they pass through the epididymis, they undergo maturation, acquiring motility and fertilizing capacity. Other accessory glands (prostate, seminal vesicles) only provide secretions to semen but do not confer motility

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Ovulation in a women with normal health occurs,
questions.option_b: 14 days prior to start of menstrual bleeding
questions.ref_book: Essentials Of Medical Physiology by K Sembulingam, 9th Edition(2023), Page No : 453

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Double Bohr effect occurs in
questions.ref_book: The double Bohr effect refers to the phenomenon in the placenta where maternal blood becomes more acidic (promoting oxygen release), and fetal blood becomes more alkaline (promoting oxygen uptake). This pH difference enhances oxygen transfer from the mother to the fetus. It is called "double" because both maternal and fetal hemoglobin respond to pH shifts in a complementary way to maximize fetal oxygenation.(Essentials of Medical Physiology by K Sembulingam 10th Edition(2025), Page No - 467)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which of the following is not true about progesterone?
questions.option_a: Produces duct growth in the breasts
questions.option_b: Stimulates the development of lobules and alveoli in the breast
questions.option_d: Has an antiestrogenic effect on the myometrial cells
questions.ref_book: Ductal growth in the breast is primarily stimulated by estrogen, not progesterone. Progesterone mainly stimulates the development of lobules and alveoli in preparation for milk production. It also has thermogenic effects (raises basal body temperature) and anti-estrogenic action on the myometrium, reducing contractility. Hence, the statement that it produces duct growth is incorrect(Essentials of Medical Physiology by K Sembulingam 10th Edition(2025), Page No - 76)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Mullerian inhibiting substance is secreted by
questions.ref_book: Sertoli cells of the fetal testis secrete MIS/AMH, which causes regression of M?llerian ducts.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 409)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: All of the following are true regarding human chorionic gonadotropin except
questions.option_a: Production of testosterone in male fetuses
questions.option_c: Can be detected in urine 6 days after conception
questions.ref_book: While hCG starts to be produced around day 6-8 post-fertilization, it usually becomes detectable in urine around 10-12 days after ovulation(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 421)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Sheehan syndrome is post partum necrosis of
questions.ref_book: Sheehan syndrome results from ischemic necrosis of the anterior pituitary due to postpartum hemorrhage.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 275)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: In females, the first event during puberty is
questions.ref_book: The first visible sign of puberty in girls is thelarche (breast development), followed by pubarche and then menarche.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 426)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which of the following inhibits synthesis and secretion of prolactin by lactotropes?
questions.ref_book: Dopamine from the hypothalamus inhibits prolactin release from lactotrophes in the anterior pituitary.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 274; (GK Pal p. 462)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Inhibin inhibits
questions.ref_book: Inhibin B, secreted by Sertoli (testis) and granulosa (ovary) cells, provides negative feedback on FSH secretion from the anterior pituitary.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 456)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Sertoli cells are stimulated by
questions.ref_book: FSH stimulates Sertoli cells to support spermatogenesis and secrete inhibin and androgen-binding protein. LH acts on Leydig cells.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 454)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: The menstrual fluid is normally nonclotting because of the presence of
questions.ref_book: Fibrinolysin, released from endometrial tissue, lyses fibrin in menstrual blood, preventing clotting.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 448)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Osteoporosis of bones in postmenopausal women is due to deficiency of
questions.ref_book: Estrogen deficiency leads to increased osteoclast activity and bone resorption, causing osteoporosis.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 455)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Capacitation of spermatozoa takes place in
questions.ref_book: Capacitation occurs in the female reproductive tract and is necessary for fertilization, enhancing sperm motility and acrosomal reaction.(GK Pal p. 609)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which hormone causes milk ejection from the breast during breastfeeding?
questions.ref_book: Oxytocin, from posterior pituitary, causes myoepithelial cell contraction, leading to milk ejection during breastfeeding.(Ganong  24th Edition, p. 433)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Fern pattern of cervical mucus is due to
questions.ref_book: Estrogen increases cervical mucus quantity and alters its structure, producing fern-like pattern seen on microscopic examination.(GK Pal p. 618)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Differentiation of external genitalia in males requires
questions.ref_book: DHT (via 5?-reductase) is critical for development of male external genitalia.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 403)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: All of the following endocrine-related changes occur during pregnancy EXCEPT:
questions.ref_book: During pregnancy, thyroxine levels rise (due to increased TBG and hCG cross-reactivity), not decrease.(GK Pal, Page 618)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Placental hormone which reduces the possibility of fetal rejection is
questions.ref_book: Progesterone has immunosuppressive properties that prevent maternal immune rejection of the fetus.(GK Pal, Page 614)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Spontaneous respiration ceases after
questions.option_a: Transection of the brainstem above the pons.
questions.option_b: Transection of the brainstem at the caudal end of the medulla.
questions.option_d: Bilateral vagotomy combined with transection of the brainstem at the superior border of the pons.
questions.ref_book:
Transection of the brainstem at the caudal end of the medulla
Explanation: The respiratory centers are located in the medulla and pons. Transection at the caudal end of the medulla destroys the basic rhythm-generating centers (dorsal and ventral respiratory groups), leading to cessation of spontaneous respiration

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: The respiratory centre which acts as a off switch point is
questions.ref_book: The pneumotaxic center (in the upper pons) limits inspiration by sending inhibitory impulses to the inspiratory center. It acts as an "off switch" for inspiration, thus regulating the respiratory rate and preventing over-inflation of the lungs

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Apex of the lung are predisposed to tuberculosis because the alveolar air there has ,
questions.ref_book: The lung apex has higher ventilation but lower perfusion compared to the base, leading to a higher ventilation-perfusion ratio (V/Q >1). This results in higher alveolar PO? and lower PCO? at the apex. Mycobacterium tuberculosis thrives in areas with high oxygen tension, which explains the apical predilection

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: In bends disease the gas responsible for the pathological effects is,
questions.ref_book: Essentials Of Medical Physiology by K Sembulingam, 9th Edition(2023), Page No : 683

questions.option_a: Low at the apex and high at the base
questions.option_b: Low at both apex and base
questions.option_c: High at apex and low at base
questions.option_d: High at both apex and base
questions.ref_book: Essentials Of Medical Physiology by K Sembulingam, 9th Edition(2023), Page No : 680

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: The normal pleural pressure at the beginning of inspiration is
questions.ref_book: At rest (before inspiration), the intrapleural pressure is about -5 cm H?O, which keeps the lungs expanded against the chest wall. During inspiration, it becomes more negative (? -7 to -8 cm H?O) due to thoracic expansion.

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY

questions.ref_book: Essentials Of Medical Physiology by K Sembulingam, 9th Edition(2023), Page No : 683

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Measurement of lung volumes with a body plethysmograph uses
questions.ref_book: Body plethysmography relies on Boyle's law - P?V? = P?V? - to measure thoracic gas volume(GK Pal, Page 896)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: In healthy individuals, Physiological dead space is
questions.option_a: Double that of anatomical dead space
questions.option_d: Triple that of anatomical dead space
questions.ref_book: In normal lungs, alveolar dead space is negligible, so physiological ? anatomical dead space.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 696)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Hering Breuer inflation reflex gets activated when the tidal volume is
questions.ref_book: Reflex is stimulated by lung inflation >500 mL, mainly during deep breathing or exercise.(GK Pal, Page 943)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Primary stimulus for the excitation of the chemosensitive neurons
questions.ref_book: Central chemoreceptors are stimulated by H? in CSF; CO? crosses BBB and increases H? via carbonic acid.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 703)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: When a person is using exclusively fats for metabolic energy, the Respiratory exchange ratio (R) will be
questions.ref_book: RQ for fat is 0.7 (CO? produced / O? consumed)(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 703)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Hypoxia produces vasoconstriction in the
questions.ref_book: Pulmonary arterioles constrict in response to hypoxia - a unique adaptation to divert blood from poorly ventilated areas.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 700)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which of the following type of breathing occurs in diabetic ketoacidosis?
questions.ref_book: Kussmaul's breathing is deep and rapid, triggered by metabolic acidosis (e.g., in DKA)(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 315)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Breathing reserve is equal to
questions.option_b: Maximum breathing capacity - Respiratory minute volume
questions.ref_book: Breathing reserve = MVV - RMV (Maximum Voluntary Ventilation - Minute Ventilation)(GK Pal, Page 967)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Carbon dioxide is mainly transported as
questions.ref_book: ~70% of CO? is transported in blood as bicarbonate (HCO??) due to carbonic anhydrase activity in RBCs.(GK Pal, Page 929)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: The volume of air that remains in the lungs at the end of maximum expiration is called as
questions.ref_book: Residual volume (RV) is the volume left in lungs after maximal forced expiration(GK Pal, Page 893)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: In cystic fibrosis, repeated pulmonary infections occur due to
questions.ref_book: In cystic fibrosis, thick mucus in airways predisposes to recurrent infections. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most common organism found in chronic lung infections in CF patients(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 674)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Factors that shift the Oxygen Dissociation Curve to the Right
questions.ref_book: A rightward shift of the ODC decreases hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen, facilitating oxygen unloading. This is caused by increased 2,3-BPG, H? ions, CO?, and temperature(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 655)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Biot's breathing occurs due to
questions.ref_book: Biot's respiration is irregular breathing with periods of apnea, usually caused by damage to the medullary respiratory centers, such as in raised intracranial pressure or brainstem trauma.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 689)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Cyanide poisoning causes death due to
questions.ref_book: Cyanide inhibits cytochrome oxidase (complex IV) in the electron transport chain, blocking cellular respiration and ATP production, leading to cellular hypoxia and death(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 34)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Dyspnea occurs at rest, when Dyspnoeic Index is reduced to
questions.ref_book: Dyspnoeic Index = (Max voluntary ventilation / Minute ventilation) ? 100. Dyspnea at rest typically appears when this index drops below 70%, indicating compromised respiratory capacity.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 665)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Functional residual capacity is
questions.option_d: Tidal volume + volume expired by forced expiration
questions.ref_book: Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is the amount of air left in the lungs after a normal tidal expiration. It equals Residual Volume + Expiratory Reserve Volume.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 631)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Airway resistance
questions.option_a: Is increased if the lungs are removed and inflated with saline
questions.option_b: Does not affect the work of breathing
questions.option_d: Is increased following bronchial smooth muscle contraction
questions.ref_book: Bronchial smooth muscle contraction reduces airway diameter, thereby increasing resistance to airflow. This is a key mechanism in asthma and bronchoconstriction(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 639)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which of the following has the greatest effect on the ability of blood to transport oxygen?
questions.option_a: Capacity of the blood to dissolve oxygen
questions.option_b: Amount of hemoglobin in the blood
questions.ref_book: Hemoglobin concentration determines the oxygen-carrying capacity of blood. Dissolved oxygen contributes very little compared to hemoglobin-bound oxygen.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 654)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Variations in which of the following components do not affect respiration?
questions.ref_book: Chemoreceptors are sensitive to changes in PaCO?, H?, and O?, but not Na?. Sodium levels do not influence respiratory drive under normal physiology.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 673)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Which serves as progenitor cells after injury in the lungs?
questions.ref_book: Type II alveolar cells proliferate and differentiate into Type I alveolar cells following lung injury, thus acting as progenitor cells.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 650)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Sub-atmospheric intrapleural pressure is due to
questions.option_b: Uniform distribution of surfactant over alveoli
questions.option_c: Presence of cartilage in upper airways
questions.option_d: Opposite recoil of lung and chest wall
questions.ref_book: The lungs tend to recoil inward while the chest wall recoils outward, creating a sub-atmospheric intrapleural pressure (?2.5 mmHg at rest).(Ganong  24th Edition, Page No -628)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Alveolar ventilation per minute for a person with tidal volume of 500 ml, dead space volume of 150 ml and respiratory rate of 10 breaths per minute is
questions.ref_book: Alveolar ventilation = (Tidal Volume ? Dead Space) ? Respiratory Rate. For a tidal volume of 500 ml and dead space of 150 ml at 10 breaths/min, AV = (500 ? 150) ? 10 = 3500 ml/min.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page No -633)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: In the lung, the ventilation-perfusion ratio is
questions.option_a: Low at the apex and high at the base
questions.option_b: Low at both apex and base
questions.option_c: High at apex and low at base
questions.option_d: High at both apex and base
questions.ref_book: Gravity causes less blood flow at the apex, while ventilation remains relatively higher, making the V/Q ratio high at the apex and low at the base.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page No -636)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Oxygen therapy is most useful in
questions.ref_book: Oxygen therapy increases the partial pressure of oxygen in blood, which is beneficial in hypoxic hypoxia but less effective in anemic, stagnant, or histotoxic hypoxia.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page No -653)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: In a patient with decompression sickness, the joint pain is due to the blocking of blood vessels by
questions.ref_book: Decompression sickness occurs due to nitrogen bubbles forming in blood/tissues when a diver ascends rapidly, as nitrogen comes out of solution.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page No -654)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: The tastant which has got highest threshold is
questions.ref_book: Threshold means the minimum concentration required for taste perception. Substances like strychnine (bitter) have the lowest threshold (detected at very low concentrations), while sweet substances like sucrose require much higher concentrations to be perceived. Hence, sucrose has the highest threshold among the options

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Lesion in optic chiasma causes
questions.ref_book: A lesion at the optic chiasm affects nasal fibers of both eyes, leading to loss of temporal visual fields.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 192-193)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Vitamin A is stored in ___________________ of retina
questions.ref_book: Retinal pigment epithelium stores vitamin A, essential for regeneration of rhodopsin in rods.(GK Pal, Page 1170)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: The central fovea contains more of
questions.ref_book: The fovea centralis is densely packed with cones, responsible for high acuity and color vision.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 194)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: When light falls on rods, the rods undergo
questions.ref_book: Unlike most sensory receptors, rods hyperpolarize in response to light due to decreased cGMP and closure of Na+ channels, reducing neurotransmitter (glutamate) release(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 204)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: In which nucleus of thalamus, taste fibers relay?
questions.ref_book: Taste signals from the solitary tract relay to the ventral posteromedial (VPM) nucleus of the thalamus before reaching the gustatory cortex(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 152)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Distorted sense of smell is called as
questions.ref_book: Parosmia refers to a distorted perception of odors, often making pleasant smells seem unpleasant. It is different from anosmia (loss) and hyposmia (reduction).(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 189)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Other name for Reissner Membrane
questions.ref_book: Reissner's membrane separates the scala vestibuli and scala media in the cochlea and is also called the vestibular membrane.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 210)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Loss of accommodation in old age is called
questions.ref_book: Presbyopia is the age-related loss of accommodation due to reduced elasticity of the lens, making it difficult to focus on near objects.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 197)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Endolymph is present in
questions.ref_book: The scala media (cochlear duct) contains endolymph, which is rich in potassium and plays a crucial role in auditory transduction.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 210)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Taste threshold is lowest in which of the following substances
questions.ref_book: The threshold for bitter taste is the lowest (i.e., it is detected at the lowest concentration) - an evolutionary adaptation to detect potentially toxic substances.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page 188)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: Colour blobs are present in
questions.ref_book: Color blobs are clusters of cells in the visual cortex (particularly in V1) that are involved in processing color information.(Ganong  24th Edition,   Page 199)

questions.subject: PHYSIOLOGY
questions.que: A 25-year-old woman comes to the hospital complaining of sudden impairment of taste sensation. Examination of taste revealed loss of taste sensation from the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue. Which cranial nerve is likely involved?
questions.ref_book: The anterior two-thirds of the tongue are innervated by the chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve; damage causes loss of taste.(Ganong  24th Edition, Page No -221-222 )
